questions.text: Which of the following structures acts as a landmark to locate Macewen's triangle?
questions.solution:
The spine of Henle is the structure that acts as a landmark for Macewen's triangle.

The spine of Henle is an important landmark found lateral to the mastoid bone. Determination of the distances between Henle’s spine and the other deeper landmarks can guide the surgeon during surgeries.

MacEwen's or supra meatal triangle can be located posterior and superior to the spine of Henle. MacEwen’s triangle(supra meatal triangle) is an important landmark for locating the mastoid antrum during mastoid surgeries.

Boundaries of MacEwen’s (supra meatal) triangle:

  • Superior- temporal line
  • Anterior-  posterosuperior segment of the bony external auditory canal
  • Posterior- the line drawn as a tangent to the external canal

Given below is an image showing the boundaries of the supra meatal triangle.

Other options:

Option A: Processus cochleariformis demarcates the geniculate ganglion which lies just anterior to it.

Option C: Citelli’s angle or sinodural angle is the angle between the sigmoid sinus plate and tegmen or dural plate. It is an important structure as a boundary while doing cortical mastoidectomy.

Option D: Prussak’s space is the most common site of primary cholesteatoma. It is the space in the epitympanum lying in between pars flaccida and the neck of the malleus.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man came with complaints of long-standing arthralgia in the knee. On examination, bluish-black scleral patches were seen as shown. On further inquiry, he says that the urine turns black on exposure to air. Accumulation of which of the following compounds caused this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of alkaptonuria and the pathological discoloration shown in the image is ochronosis. Accumulation of the compound benzoquinone acetate has caused this condition.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase, the enzyme which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. The defect in this enzyme will lead to the accumulation of homogentisic acid that  oxidizes into benzoquinone acetate. Later, benzoquinone acetate polymerizes and binds to tissues (especially collagen fibres).

This oxidation process produces free radicals that cause tissue damage and incite inflammation. Additionally, the excess homogentisic acid is excreted in the urine. This results in the classical clinical features of alkaptonuria such as- 

  • Homogentisic aciduria- Black discoloration of urine on prolonged exposure to air caused due to oxidation of the excreted homogentisate. 
  • Ochronosis- Bluish-black discoloration of tissues mostly involving ear cartilage, ocular tissue, the skin of the eyelids, forehead, cheeks, and hands, nail beds, and even deeper structures such as the larynx and tendons.
  • Arthropathy- Debilitating arthralgia or arthritis that may be seen after the fourth or fifth decade.

Other options-

Option B- Methyl malonyl-CoA is seen in urine (methylmalonic aciduria) due to deficiency of methylmalonyl Co A mutase which is a vitamin b12 dependent enzyme.

Option C- Increased orotic acid in the blood and urine is seen in ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency.

Option D- Sulfogalactosylceramide is accumulated in metachromatic leukodystrophy due to deficiency of Aryl-sulfatase A.

questions.text: A new factory has been given a license to fortify salt with iodine. What is the minimum recommended content of iodine in salt at the production level?
questions.solution:
The minimum recommended content of iodine in salt at the production level is 30 ppm.

Level of iodization

  • At consumer level: 15 ppm
  • At production level: 30 ppm

Goitrogens are chemical substances that interfere with iodine utilization by the thyroid gland, leading to the development of goiter. The brassica group of vegetables like cabbage and cauliflower contain goitrogens.

The daily requirement of iodine is 150 mcg for adults and 250 mcg in pregnancy.

Disorders due to iodine deficiency:

  • Goiter
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Retarded physical and mental development
  • Intrauterine death (spontaneous abortion and stillbirth)
  • Endemic cretinism

The National Iodine Deficiency Disorders Control Program conducts surveys to assess the magnitude of iodine deficiency disorders. The program conducts a resurvey every 5 years to assess the effect of the impact of iodized salt. They also supply iodized salt and conduct laboratory monitoring of iodized salt and urinary iodine excretion.

Global Iodine Deficiency Disorders Prevention Day is observed on 21st October every year.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man came to the OPD with blurred vision. His fundus examination was done. The fundus appearance is as shown in the image given below. This appearance is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The fundus image shows a Bayoneting sign in the optic disc, which is seen in the advanced stages of glaucoma.

In glaucoma, due to the loss of neuroretinal rim tissue, nasal shifting of retinal vessels occurs, giving the vessels the appearance of being broken off at the margin. This leads to sharp angulation of vessels at the margin of the excavated cup, known as the bayoneting sign.

Glaucomatous changes in the optic disc:

Early glaucomatous changes

  • Slit defects of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Splinter hemorrhages on disc margin
  • Large cup: 0.7 or more
  • Asymmetry of the cups: A difference equal to or more than 0.2 between two eyes is significant
  • Vertical oval cup

Advanced glaucomatous changes

  • Marked cupping (Beanpot cupping)
  • Thinning of neuroretinal rim
  • Bayoneting sign
  • Laminar dot sign

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman is being planned for Ward Mayo's procedure. She has hypertension but doesn't take medications regularly and also has a history of CAD for the last 6 months. Her current BP is 190/100 mmHg. What is her ASA classification?

CAD- Coronary Artery Disease
BP- Blood Pressure
ASA- American Society of Anesthesiologists
questions.solution:
According to ASA, a patient with poorly controlled hypertension with CAD > 3 months falls under ASA class III.

ASA PS (American Society of Anesthesiologists – Physical Status) classification predicts perioperative risks for a patient undergoing surgery. It has 6 classes, ranging from a normal, healthy patient to a dead/moribund patient.

These criteria differ for pediatric and pregnant populations. All pregnant women are considered to be ASA PS II, as they have altered physiology. The addition of ‘E’ denotes emergency surgery. For example, an otherwise healthy pregnant patient posted for emergency LSCS belongs to the ASA PS II E category.

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA-PS Classification:

I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents
V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Ruptured abdominal, thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect
VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

questions.text: A child presents with fever, sore throat, and a rash. On examination, a strawberry tongue is noticed. The throat swab is positive for group A streptococcus. Which of the following statements about the rash is true?

choices.text: It begins around the neck and spreads over the trunk and extremities
It starts as vesicular lesions on the trunk and spreads to the face and extremities in crops
It starts on the extremities and moves centrally
It appears as a faint pink rash on the trunk after the fever resolves

questions.solution:
This patient has a fever, sore throat, rash, and a strawberry tongue, pointing towards the diagnosis of scarlet fever. The rash of scarlett fever begins around the neck and spreads over the trunk and extremities.

Scarlet fever is a complication of Group A streptococcal pharyngitis. The characteristic rash appears within 24-48 hours, beginning around the neck and spreading to the trunk and extremities. It is finely papular, erythematous, and blanches on pressure. It is often accentuated in body creases (Pastia lines). The skin feels rough, like goosebumps (sandpaper-like texture). The rash fades in 3-4 days, followed by desquamation. The cheeks are often erythematous, with pallor around the mouth. Pharyngeal findings are similar to GAS pharyngitis, with a coated tongue and swollen papillae that later give a strawberry appearance.  

Other options:

Option B: The varicella rash starts as vesicular lesions on the trunk and spreads in crops to the face and extremities.

Option C: Rocky Mountain spotted fever (Rickettsia rickettsii) is accompanied by a pale, rose-red blanching maculopapular rash that starts on the extremities (wrists, ankles, lower legs) and spreads to the whole body centrally.

Option D: Roseola is accompanied by a faint pink or rose-colored rash on the trunk, coinciding with the fever's resolution.

questions.text: A middle-aged female with photosensitivity and oral ulcers has the following cell type on histological examination. Which of the following types of arthritis is seen in her?

choices.text: Small and large joint non-erosive arthritis
Small and large joint asymmetrical arthritis

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the image showing the lupus erythematosus(LE) cell suggest systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which leads to small and large joint symmetrical non-erosive arthritis. 

The LE cell is a phagocytic neutrophil or macrophage. Nuclei of damaged cells react with ANAs, lose their chromatin pattern, and become homogeneous to produce LE bodies or hematoxylin bodies. Phagocytic neutrophils or macrophages engulf the denatured nucleus of an injured cell. Demonstration of LE cells in vitro was used in the past for the diagnosis of SLE.

The non-erosive arthropathy seen in SLE is called Jaccoud's arthropathy. It is characterised by ulnar deviation of the second to 5th fingers with metacarpophalangeal joint subluxation and is seen in SLE. 

Other options: 

Options A: Rheumatoid arthritis(RA) is a type of small joint, erosive, symmetrical arthritis. It is an autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the synovial membrane of the joints, leading to joint pain, stiffness, and swelling. While it can cause joint damage and deformity, it often presents with different radiographic findings, including erosions (key hallmark) and periarticular osteopenia. Symmetric polyarthritis occurs in about 40% of psoriatic arthritis. It may be indistinguishable from RA in terms of the joints involved, but other features of psoriatic arthritis are also present.

Option D: Osteoarthritis is a type of large joint, asymmetrical arthritis. It is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of joint cartilage and underlying bone changes. The typical clinical features include chronic joint pain, stiffness, and limited range of motion, as well as radiographic findings of joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and subchondral sclerosis.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms exhibits Gal/GalNAc lectin-mediated binding to colonic mucin oligosaccharides?
questions.solution:
Gal/GalNAc lectin-mediated binding to colonic mucin oligosaccharides is seen with Entamoeba histolytica.

Gal/GalNAc lectin (Galactose/N-Acetylgalactosamine lectin) is a surface adhesion molecule found on Entamoeba histolytica. It plays a key role in colonizing and invading the intestinal mucosa. It facilitates direct contact-dependent lysis of host epithelial cells and contributes to flask-shaped ulcer formation in the colon. The lectin helps E. histolytica evade the host immune response by resisting complement-mediated lysis.

Intestinal amebiasis presents as acute dysentery with lower abdominal discomfort and flatulence or as a chronic disease with occasional diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue. Flask-shaped ulcers are characteristic, primarily affecting the cecum, sigmoid colon, and rectum, with multiple lesions confined to the colon. A granulomatous lesion called an ameboma may form in the cecal or rectosigmoid areas of the colon, which can resemble an adenocarcinoma.

Diagnosis is by stool microscopy and stool antigen testing. Microscopic findings include RBC clumps with a yellowish-brown appearance and Charcot-Leyden crystals (diamond-shaped, clear, and refractile), indicating eosinophil breakdown.

Complications and sequelae of intestinal amoebiasis include fulminant amoebic colitis (toxic megacolon, perianal ulcers, ameboma) and extraintestinal amoebiasis (liver abscess [most common], pulmonary, cerebral, splenic amebiasis).

The most appropriate treatment is metronidazole, followed by a luminal agent (e.g., paromomycin).

Other options:

Option A: Giardia causes fat malabsorption, epigastric pain, and steatorrhea, not dysentery.

Option C: Campylobacter presents with fever, crampy abdominal pain, and watery diarrhea. It can progress to bloody diarrhea resembling dysentery. Campylobacter invades the intestinal mucosa but does not use Gal/GalNAc lectin-mediated binding.

Option D: Shigella causes bacillary dysentery with fever, tenesmus, and lower abdominal tenderness. It invades colonic M cells, replicates intracellularly, and spreads using actin polymerization.

questions.text:
An elderly hypertensive male presents with unilateral weakness of upper limb and slurring of speech. He was last seen normal 5 hours ago. The NCCT image shows a hyperdense MCA sign. Which of the following is the most appropriate management at this stage?

MCA - Middle Cerebral Artery

choices.text: Aspirin therapy and consider mechanical thrombectomy

questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation and hyperdense MCA sign (indicating MCA occlusion) are suggestive of ischemic stroke. Aspirin therapy and mechanical thrombectomy would be preferred in this patient as he presented after the window period of 4.5 hours.

For patients presenting beyond the thrombolysis window but within 24 hours and with a confirmed large vessel occlusion, mechanical thrombectomy is indicated. Additionally, aspirin therapy should be initiated to reduce the risk of further ischemia. The below image shows hyperdense MCA sign.

After the clinical diagnosis of stroke is made, an emergency evaluation should be made to check the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs), hypoglycemia/ hyperglycemia. The main goal is to distinguish it as either an ischemic stroke or hemorrhagic stroke with the help of an emergency non-contrast head CT. 

Management includes:

  • Reduction of blood pressure when: BP >220/120 mmHg, presence of malignant hypertension or concomitant myocardial ischemia, or if blood pressure is >185/110 mmHg in a patient planned for intravenous thrombolysis.
  • Serum glucose maintained between 60 mg/dL - 180 mg/dL.
  • IV mannitol and water restriction may be required to reduce edema which can lead to a mass effect.
  • Intravenous thrombolysis (Option A) with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA), alteplase (0.9 mg/kg) or tenecteplase (0.25 mg/kg) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period (within 4.5 hours of symptom onset).
  • Endovascular mechanical thrombectomy is done in patients who do not respond to thrombolytic therapy or in whom thrombolysis is contraindicated.
  • Oral aspirin with an initial dose of 300 mg should be started within 48 hours of acute ischemic stroke.

Dual antiplatelet therapy (option C) is not standard for acute stroke management in this setting. Supportive care alone (option D) neglects thrombectomy eligibility and is incomplete.

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest radiographic sign of TB spine?

choices.text: Accumulation of pus in paradiscal space

questions.solution:
Narrowing of disc space is the earliest sign of TB spine, especially in the paradiscal type.

In earlier stages of disease, disc space reduction might not be so apparent, but in later stages, disc space might be completely lost. A lateral X-ray of the spine is better to evaluate disc space. This is an important sign because disc space is generally preserved in spinal metastasis and helps in differentiating both of these.

Other radiographic signs of TB spine include:

  • Destruction of vertebral body. It starts with erosion of contiguous margins, followed by wedging of vertebra and then destruction of whole of vertebral body leading to kyphosis. But Posterior elements are rarely involved
  • Appearance of cold abscess. In cervical spine disease, retropharyngeal abscess may be evident. In lower spine involvement, paravertebral abscess may be seen in either a fusiform or globular shape. Thoracic spine disease may be seen as widened mediastinum on AP view.
  • Rarefaction above and below the vertebra
  • Signs of healing - the bone becomes sclerotic and regains its density. The adjacent vertebra may undergo fusion.

questions.text: Acrodynia is seen in poisoning with which of the following metals?
questions.solution:
Acrodynia, or pink disease, is seen in chronic mercury poisoning.

Acrodynia is the dermatological manifestation of mercury poisoning. Children are usually affected by this hypersensitivity reaction. It is characterized by sweating and skin rash, with hands and feet becoming puffy, pinkish, and painful. Associated paresthesia and skin peeling are also seen.

Features of chronic mercury poisoning include:

  • Hydrargyrism - These patients have Danbury tremors, which are coarse, intentional tremors. The advanced condition is called Hatter's shakes/ Glass blower's shakes
  • Acrodynia (pink disease)
  • Minimata disease - caused by the eating of fish poisoned by mercury
  • Erethism - these are psychological symptoms due to mercury toxicity seen in mirror manufacturing firms. It is characterised by shyness, timidity, irritability, loss of confidence, mental depression, loss of memory, and insomnia
  • Mercuria lentis - peculiar eye changes due to exposure to mercury vapor.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with recurrent hemoptysis and renal failure. Renal biopsy revealed crescents in most of the glomeruli. Immunofluorescence finding is shown in the image below. Which of the following is most commonly targetted in this disease?

choices.text: α4 chains of collagen type IV
α3 chain of collagen type IV
α5 chain of collagen type IV
α2 chains of collagen  type IV

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a patient with recurrent hemoptysis and renal failure, along with crescents on renal biopsy and linear immunofluorescence (IF) staining. These findings are characteristic of Goodpasture syndrome, in which antibodies are targeted against the α3 chain of collagen type IV.

In Goodpasture's syndrome, autoantibodies are directed against the α3 chain of type IV collagen found in the glomerular and alveolar basement membranes. This leads to a type II hypersensitivity reaction, which causes pulmonary hemorrhage, leading to hemoptysis, and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, which leads to renal failure.

Renal immunofluorescence studies: In rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) type I and Goodpasture syndrome, immunofluorescence reveals a linear pattern (as shown below), which is a classic feature of anti–glomerular basement membrane disease (anti-GBM) disease. 

Below are various immunofluorescence patterns observed. The image shows negative immunofluorescence, indicative of minimal change disease. There are no Ig or complement deposits.

Granular appearance on immunofluorescence microscopy is shown below, which is seen in:

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis: Immunofluorescent stain demonstrates discrete, coarsely granular deposits of complement protein C3 and IgG corresponding to “humps”.
  • Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis Type II: It is immune-complex mediated and shows granular deposits on the immunofluorescent stain.
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) Type I: Immunofluorescence shows IgG and C3 and early complement components(C1q and C4) deposited in a granular pattern.
  • Membranous nephropathy: Immunofluorescence microscopy demonstrates that the granular deposits contain both immunoglobulins and complement.

Lupus nephritis: Immunofluorescence staining of the kidney biopsy specimen shows positive staining for fibrinogen, IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, λ chain, and k light chain. This is known as a full-house effect.

IgA nephropathy: Immunofluorescence microscopy shows IgA deposition in the mesangium.

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis type 2 (MPGN type 2) or dense-deposit disease: Immunofluorescence shows C3 deposition in irregular granular or linear foci in the basement membranes on either side but not within the dense deposits.

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Immunofluorescence microscopy shows IgM and C3 deposition in the sclerotic areas and/or in the mesangium.

Other options

Option A: A Mutation in the α4 chains of collagen type IV is seen in thin basement membrane nephropathy.

Option C: A Mutation in the α5 chain of collagen type IV is seen in Alport syndrome.

questions.text:
A football hit an 11-year-old child studying in a residential school on the face while playing, resulting in a heavy nosebleed. The child was rushed to the hospital by the headmaster where he was diagnosed with anterior epistaxis and nasal packing was done. The bleeding could not be controlled so after consent from the headmaster, TESPAL was done and the bleeding was arrested successfully. Which doctrine upholds the headmaster’s decision to provide consent for the child?

TESPAL: Transnasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine Artery Ligation
questions.solution:
In case of medical emergencies in a child < 12 years old where the parent is unavailable, consent for medical procedures can be given by the teacher in charge or the headmaster. This is called loco parentis. 

Section 27 of BNS states that an “Act done in good faith for benefit of child or person of unsound mind, by, or by consent of guardian“ cannot be considered an offense.

Informed consent is a prerequisite for medical interventions, but a child under 12 years cannot provide consent for either physical examination or medical procedures. Consent is given by the parent or legal guardian, or under certain circumstances, by the person-in-charge of the child(loco parentis) such as children in residential schools, children on a school tour away from home, etc

Other Options:

Option B: The doctrine of res ipsa loquitur (the thing or the act speaks for itself) is a situation whereby an obvious gross act of negligence leads to damage to the patient. For example prescribing high doses of NSAIDs in a patient with a history of perforated peptic ulcer.

Option C: Captain of the ship doctrine states that if any of the crew members (eg nurse/intern) make mistakes in the operating room, the captain(chief operating surgeon) is liable.

Option D: Implied consent is the form of consent given by adult patients of sound mind who have been adequately informed or are fully aware about some form of medical examination or procedure and cooperate willingly with the doctor. It is differentiated from express consent, where consent is obtained in written or verbal form before any medical procedure or intervention is performed. For example, allowing the nurse to check the temperature is a form of implied consent.

questions.text:
A middle-aged woman presents to the outpatient department with a flesh-colored, firm nodule on her back, as shown below. Genetic analysis reveals a t(17;22) translocation with PDGF-beta overexpression. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the preferred treatment?

PDGF: Platelet-derived growth factor
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points towards dermatofibrosarcoma, and the treatment is wide local excision. 

Dermatofibrosarcoma, also known as dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP), is a rare, slow-growing, and locally aggressive soft tissue tumor arising from the dermis. It presents as a flesh-colored or violaceous nodule within an indurated plaque, which may ulcerate over time. DFSP is characterized by the t(17;22) translocation, leading to PDGF-beta overexpression, which drives tumor growth.

The primary treatment is wide local excision with 2–4 cm margins or Mohs micrographic surgery to minimize recurrence while preserving healthy tissue. Imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, is used for unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic cases due to its efficacy against PDGF-beta-driven proliferation.

Other options:

Option A: Keratoacanthoma presents with a reddish papule with a horny crust in the centre. It is a rapidly evolving tumour of the skin considered as a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma.

Option C: A neurofibroma typically appears as a soft, flesh-colored, and rubbery nodule, often with a smooth surface, and may be associated with café-au-lait spots in neurofibromatosis type 1.

Option D: Seborrheic keratosis presents as well-demarcated plaques or papules, round or oval lesions with a dull, verrucous surface, and a typical stuck-on appearance.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old obese male patient was diagnosed with varicose veins a few months back. He now comes to the outpatient clinic with the finding shown in the image. What is the stage of the clinical classification according to the CEAP guidelines?

CEAP- Clinical etiology anatomy pathophysiology for chronic venous disorders.
questions.solution:
The given image in a patient with a known case of varicose veins is atrophie blanche. It is classified as C4b under CEAP guidelines.

Atrophie blanche is a localized white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and pigmentation, usually seen around the ankle. This is a sign of severe chronic venous disease.

Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology (CEAP) classification system is used to classify chronic lower extremity venous disease.

The clinical class of C4 under CEAP includes changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary to chronic venous disease. It is further classified as follows:

  • C4a-Pigmentation or eczema
  • C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
  • C4c-Corona phlebectatica

Corona phlebectatica is the presence of abnormally visible cutaneous blood vessels. Lipodermatosclerosis is a chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, that appears as a ‘woody’ leg on examination.

Image A shows tortuous dilated veins (C2), Image B is atrophie blanche (C4b), and Image C shows fan-shaped telangiectasia (C4c).

questions.text: A surgeon plans to operate on a 35-year-old male patient who was diagnosed with an Inguinal hernia by closing the defect with mesh hernioplasty. Which of the following is the most appropriate mesh for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate mesh used in hernioplasty is a lightweight mesh with large pores.

Heavyweight meshes provoke a greater reaction, leading to collagen contraction and mesh stiffening, which is associated with impaired elasticity/mobility of the abdominal wall, foreign body sensation and pain. 

Mesh with large pores and thin strands is preferred because they cause less fibrosis and pain. They have better tissue integration and less contracture, leading to more flexibility and comfort.

Based on composition, meshes used in hernioplasty can be:

  • Synthetic mesh
  • Biological mesh

Synthetic meshes are made from polypropylene, polyester, or PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene). 

POLYPROPYLENE POLYESTER PTFE
Monofilament Multifilament Monofilament
Hydrophobic Hydrophilic Hydrophobic
Rigid Elastic Rigid

Biological meshes are acellular matrix materials derived from humans or animals and have fewer complications. They provide a ‘scaffold’ to encourage neovascularisation, fibroblast infiltration and new collagen deposition. The host enzymes break down the biological implant and replace it with normal host fibrous tissue. The rates of enzymatic degradation and collagen deposition vary with different products and also depend on the local environment of the mesh.

The disadvantage is that they are expensive, and in the presence of infection, they break down more rapidly, leading to early hernia recurrence. Biological mesh with chemical cross-linking between the fibrous strands is more resistant to breakdown.

Other options:

Option A: Sapna is the mascot for leprosy.

Option B: The mascot for the 2024 Khelo India Winter Games was a snow leopard named Sheen-e-She or Shan and was chosen to represent Ladakh's cultural heritage and biodiversity.

questions.text:
An upper GI endoscopic biopsy taken from the lower part of the oesophagus showed the presence of glandular columnar epithelium. Which of the following conditions have similar cellular adaptation?
  1. Myositis ossificans
  2. Cachexia in protein-energy malnutrition
  3. Uterine enlargement during pregnancy
  4. Xerophthalmia due to Vitamin A deficiency
questions.solution:
The presence of glandular columnar epithelium instead of squamous epithelium is suggestive of intestinal-type metaplasia seen in Barrett's esophagus. The conditions with similar pathology are myositis ossificans and xerophthalmia due to vitamin A deficiency.

Metaplasia is defined as the replacement of one type of cell with another type.

  • Myositis ossificans is a connective tissue metaplasia and involves bone formation in muscles. It is usually seen after an intramuscular haemorrhage.
  • Vitamin A (retinoic acid) deficiency can lead to epithelial cell metaplasia and keratinisation due to transcription factor dysregulation. The normal lacrimal and mucus-secreting epithelium is replaced by keratinised epithelium. 
  • In Barrett's esophagus, the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by glandular columnar epithelium and goblet cells. Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett's esophagus. It is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease.

The table below shows various types of metaplasia:

Tissue Metaplasia
Airways

Squamous metaplasia:

In the habitual cigarette smoker, the normal ciliated columnar epithelial cells of the trachea and bronchi are often replaced by stratified squamous epithelial cells.

Also, a deficiency of retinoic acid may cause squamous metaplasia.
Urinary bladder Squamous metaplasia: Stones in the excretory ducts of the salivary glands, pancreas, or bile ducts, which are normally lined by secretory columnar epithelium, may also lead to squamous metaplasia. The stratified squamous epithelium can survive better under such circumstances.
Esophagus Columnar metaplasia: In patients with chronic GERD, the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by the glandular columnar epithelium (Barrett's esophagus)
Muscle Connective tissue metaplasia: In some cases, after intramuscular hemorrhage, there may be the formation of bone in the muscle tissue; the condition is known as myositis ossificans.

 

Statement 2- Cachexia in protein-energy malnutrition leads to atrophy of the muscle cells due to the utilisation of skeletal muscle proteins as a source of energy after other reserves, such as adipose stores, have been depleted.

Statement 3- Uterine enlargement during pregnancy is physiological hypertrophy of the smooth muscle fibres. It is stimulated by estrogenic hormone signaling through estrogen receptors that eventually result in increased synthesis of smooth muscle proteins and an increased cell size.

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: A 10-month-old male infant presented with a sausage-shaped lump in the abdomen associated with red currant jelly stools. USG of the abdomen showed the below appearance. Vitals are stable. What is the ideal management, in the absence of a pathological lead point?

choices.text: Resection and anastomosis of the involved bowel

questions.solution:
The image, along with the clinical findings, is suggestive of intussusception. Ileocolic Intussusception in a stable infant without a pathological lead point or any complications is managed by non-operative reduction using air/barium enema.

Intussusception is a condition in which one portion of the gut invaginates into the adjacent portion, which is mostly proximal to distal. It is most commonly seen in children. Ileocolic is the most common type in children and colo-colic in adults.

Pediatric cases below two years are usually idiopathic. Over two years of age, a pathological lead point is identified in ⅓ cases. These include Meckel diverticulum, polyp, duplication, appendix, etc. Idiopathic cases are believed to occur due to inflamed Peyer’s patches following a respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. Vaccination with the Rotavirus vaccine is also considered a potential trigger, although newer vaccines have highly minimal risk. In adults, a pathological lead point is almost always seen and is usually a polyp. Clinical features of intussusception include:

  • Sausage-shaped mass in the abdomen with concavity towards the umbilicus
  • Screaming and crying episodes in infants associated with the drawing up of legs that last for
  • minutes
  • Bilestained vomitus
  • Red currant jelly stools
  • Emptiness in RIF(Sign of Dance)
  • Bloodstained glove on PR examination

Investigations:

  • USG: Doughnut appearance of transverse rings, especially in children(as shown above), pseudo kidney sign longitudinally.
  • Barium enema: Claw sign or coiled spring sign may be seen.
  • Confirmatory investigation: CT scan which shows Target or sausage-shaped soft tissue mass with layering effect or mesenteric vessels within bowel lumen.

Treatment involves IV fluids and antibiotics. NG tube is inserted. In children, when there is no pathological lead point, non-operative reduction with air or barium enema is done. Successful reduction is confirmed by free reflux of air or barium into the bowel and resolution of symptoms and signs.  Contraindications to non-operative reduction include:

  • Profound Shock
  • Peritonitis
  • Evidence of strangulation or perforation
  • Presence of pathological lead point

Operative management includes creating a transverse incision on the right side of the abdomen and reduction by gentle compression of the most distal part of the intussusception towards its origin. No pulling must be attempted. Reduction is most difficult with the last part. Bruising and edema of the appendix and the terminal part of the small bowel may be seen post-reduction. A viability assessment of the bowel must be done before closure. Strangulated bowel requires resection and anastomosis.

questions.text: An 8-month-old child was brought to the pediatrician with complaints of seizures. Examination revealed delayed milestones. Chest and abdominal examination showed no significant findings. Fundoscopy revealed the following image. The enzyme that could be deficient in the child is:
questions.solution:
The presence of seizures, developmental delay, and cherry-red spots in the fundus (seen in the image), in an infant without hepatosplenomegaly, is suggestive of Tay-Sachs disease, which is due to the deficiency of hexosaminidase A.

In this condition, there is an accumulation of the lipid ganglioside. Other features include mental retardation, blindness, and muscle weakness. 

Other options:

Option A: β-Glucosidase deficiency is seen in Gaucher disease, which commonly has a combination of developmental delay and hepatosplenomegaly with the accumulation of glucocerebroside.

Option C: Sphingomyelinase deficiency leads to Niemann-Pick disease, where infants exhibit a combination of hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, interstitial lung disease, and retinal cherry-red spots.

Option D: α-Galactosidase deficiency leads to Fabry disease, which has symptoms of skin rash, kidney, heart failure, and burning pain in the lower extremities.

questions.text: An elderly woman with postmenopausal bleeding being managed for senile endometritis presented with enlarged superficial inguinal lymph nodes. On workup and assessment, the patient was diagnosed to have clear cell endometrial carcinoma with metastasis. What is the appropriate treatment?

choices.text: Simple hysterectomy with Pelvic,Paraaortic and Inguinal Lymphadenectomy

questions.solution:
Metastasis to any extra-abdominal lymph nodes or lymph nodes above renal vessels in case of Endometrial carcinoma is considered Stage 4c—distant metastasis. The most appropriate treatment is palliative treatment. 

Superficial inguinal node involvement is Stage 4c, so brachytherapy, EBRT with adjuvant chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy with progesterone to control symptoms may be attempted.

The staging of Endometrial cancer is surgical, i.e. a staging laparotomy is done, and the stage of the tumor is confirmed except in the case of distant metastases, as is here, where the stage is automatically upgraded to 4c. The components of a staging surgical laparotomy in CA Endometrium are:

  • TAH with BSO (Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy)
  • Pelvic and Paraortic Lymphadenectomy/ lymph node sampling
  • Omentectomy 
  • Peritoneal Washing/Ascitic fluid analysis(if present) along with samples from various parts of the peritoneal cavity such as paracolic gutters.

A simple tabular column is shown below for Endometrial carcinoma stage versus treatment:

STAGE TREATMENT
Stage 1A (Less than half of myometrium involved) Staging laparotomy+radiotherapy (from 1A G2)
Stage 1B (More than half of myometrium involved) Staging laparotomy+radiotherapy
Stage 2 (Involves cervix) Staging laparotomy+radiotherapy
Stage 3 (3a-uterine serosa and/or adnexa, 3b-vagina and/or parametrium, 3c-pelvic and/or paraaortic nodes) Staging laparotomy if undiagnosed on abdominal scans, which is converted to debulking on opening abdomen, Palliative treatment if identified: Debulking surgery+chemoradiotherapy+hormonal therapy
Stage 4(4a-bladder/bowel, 4b- abdominal peritoneal metastasis beyond pelvis, 4c-distant mets including inguinal nodes) Palliative treatment: Debulking surgery+chemoradiotherapy+hormonal therapy. Surgery is avoided if case is very advanced at diagnosis or surgery not possible.

A simple hysterectomy is the removal of the uterus and cervix only.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman came with complaints of headache and nasal discharge since 1 week. She describes the headache to be present as soon as she wakes up, gradually increasing until midday, and then starting to subside. What is the site of drainage of the structure affected in the above case?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the duration of symptoms and the characteristic pattern of headache described are highly suggestive of acute frontal sinusitis, caused by inflammation in frontal sinus cavities, which drain into the middle meatus of the nose.

It is most often associated with an antecedent viral upper respiratory tract infection followed later by bacterial invasion. 

Patients present with frontal headache with characteristic periodicity i.e. present on waking up, gradually increases and reaches its peak by about midday and then starts subsiding. It is also called “office headache” because of its presence only during office hours.

Treatment: Medical - Antimicrobials, decongestion of the sinus ostium and a combination of antihistaminic with oral nasal decongestant (phenylephrine hydrochloride).  Surgical- Trephination of the frontal sinus.

Paranasal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present in the skull bones. These paranasal sinuses have been divided into two groups:

Anterior group: Their ostia drain into the middle meatus through a common drainage pathway known as osteomeatal unit. This group includes:

  • Maxillary sinus (antrum of Highmore)
  • Frontal sinus
  • Anterior ethmoidal sinus

Posterior group: 

  • Posterior ethmoidal sinuses: Opens in the superior meatus (option A)
  • Sphenoid sinus: Opens in sphenoethmoidal recess (option B)

The inferior meatus (option C) has the nasolacrimal duct draining into it with its terminal end being guarded by the Hasner's valve.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is primarily involved in stabilising the pelvis during a single-leg stance and maintaining the extended knee in a locked position through its attachment to the iliotibial band?
questions.solution:
The tensor fascia lata (TFL) aids gluteus medius in stabilising the pelvis over the femur in the frontal plane when standing on one limb. It helps to maintain the extended knee in a locked position through the iliotibial tract and helps in hip abduction, internal rotation, and flexion.

The tensor fascia lata is a muscle that originates from the anterior iliac crest and inserts into the iliotibial band, which continues down to the lateral aspect of the tibia.

The Trendelenburg sign is used to assess the strength of the hip abductors, primarily the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus. A positive Trendelenburg sign on the left indicates weakness in the left hip abductors, causing the pelvis to drop on the right side when the patient stands on the left leg.

Other options:

Option A: Gluteus medius is a primary hip abductor and critical for pelvic stabilization. However, while weakness here can contribute to a positive Trendelenburg sign, it does not significantly assist in knee extension through the IT band.

Option C: Sartorius, primarily involved in hip flexion, abduction, and external rotation, but does not contribute to stabilization through the IT band or knee extension.

Option D: Vastus lateralis is part of the quadriceps group, primarily responsible for knee extension, but does not play a significant role in pelvic stabilization or involve the IT band.

Note: Iliotibial band syndrome (ITBS) is a common overuse injury in runners due to repeated friction of the ITB and the lateral epicondyle during flexion and extension, leading to inflammation of the area in contact with ITB.

questions.text: During the process of capacitation, the membrane of sperm loses its strength as it ascends through the female genital tract. Which of the following plays a key role in regulating the sperm's membrane strength during capacitation?
questions.solution:
The component responsible for regulating the sperm’s membrane strength during capacitation is cholesterol, in the form of cholesterol vesicles, which is important in strengthening the sperm’s membranes. 

Capacitation is a series of changes that activate the sperm for fertilisation upon contact with the female reproductive fluids. Normally, it takes 1-10 hours for the whole process. 

Inside seminiferous tubules, cholesterol vesicles in the free-floating fluid keep attaching and accumulating at the sperm’s membrane. Thus, cholesterol increases the strength of the membrane and prevents the release of enzymes from sperm. The sperm that are deposited in the vagina after ejaculation swims upward into the uterine cavity, away from the cholesterol vesicles. Over the following few hours, they gradually lose a large portion of their other excess cholesterol. By doing this, the sperm's acrosome, or head membrane, weakens significantly.

Option A: Fructose acts as a nutrient/energy source for sperm and plays no role in membrane stability.

Option B: Calcium (not sodium) causes changes at the acrosomal end of the membrane, thus promoting easier and rapid release of enzymes during penetration of layers of the ovum (even more during penetration of Zona pellucida). Calcium helps in locomotion and penetration of sperm and not sodium. As the calcium influx increases, the flagellar motion changes from weak undulating to strong whiplash-like, promoting faster movement through the female genital tract.

Option D: Vitamin C, as citric acid, is a content of seminal fluid and doesn't play a significant role in capacitation as such.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man sustained head trauma and is now being evaluated for aphasia. His comprehension is impaired, and he speaks with increased fluency and made-up words. Which of the following cortical areas is affected?
questions.solution:
The patient described above, with features of impaired comprehension, increased fluency, and made-up words (known as neologism), has Wernicke’s aphasia (also known as receptive or fluent aphasia). This usually occurs due to damage in the posterior end of the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere (marked as 2 in the image).

Aphasia is a language disorder that develops after brain damage. Wernicke's aphasia is marked by the ability to speak fluently but with difficulty understanding language. The patient cannot understand words or recognise symbols, whether it is auditory, tactile or visual. People with this condition often don't recognise that their speech is unclear, and they may experience significant agitation or paranoia as a result. 

Other markings of the image:

1- Primary auditory area- Damage to this area would cause auditory processing deficits, not fluent aphasia with impaired comprehension.

3- Broca’s area- Injury to this area or occlusion of the superior division of the middle cerebral artery leads to Broca's aphasia. In Broca's aphasia, the speech is non-fluent, interrupted by many word-finding pauses with impaired repetition and naming. However, comprehension is preserved.

4- Pre-motor area- It is responsible for planning and organising complex movements before the primary motor cortex executes the movement.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency with lightheadedness and acute onset of severe abdominal pain. She has had amenorrhea for 8 weeks and two episodes of spotting. Her blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg and her pulse rate is 138 beats/minute. Her urine pregnancy test result is positive.  What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: IV fluids followed by oral methotrexate

questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation suggests a diagnosis of ruptured ectopic pregnancy. The most appropriate management for this patient is Salpingectomy. It can be done for both ruptured and unruptured ectopic pregnancy.

The other procedure is salpingostomy (Option D), which involves the removal of only the concepts, while preserving the fallopian tube. This is usually done when the contralateral fallopian tube seems abnormal and when the ectopic pregnancy is unruptured.

Management of tubal ectopic pregnancy:

Medical management is indicated when the patient is asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable. It involves the systemic or local use of chemotherapeutic drugs: 

  • Drugs used: Methotrexate (MTX 50 mg/m2 single dose intramuscularly).
  • Regular monitoring of serum β-hCG

Medical management is likely to be successful when

  • Initial serum hCG level is <5,000 IU/L.
  • Ectopic mass is less than 4 cm.
  • Fetal cardiac activity is absent.
  • Intra-abdominal hemorrhage is absent.

Surgical management of ectopic pregnancy includes laparoscopic salpingostomy/ salpingectomy, and microsurgical laparotomy. 

Indications:

  • Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Failure of medical therapy- 
    • Serum β-HCG levels remain elevated 
    • Persistence of fetal cardiac activity

Estimation of serum β-hCG level should be done weekly until the β-HCG values go down.

          ⇓
Doubles every 2 days
          ⇓
Peaks at 8 to 10 weeks of gestation(~100 IU/mL)
          ⇓
Begins to decline at 10 to 12 weeks
          ⇓
Plateau at 16 weeks till term
 
  • Higher maternal plasma hCG levels- Multifetal pregnancy, erythroblastosis fetalis, gestational trophoblastic disease, Down syndrome.
  • Lower hCG plasma levels -early pregnancy wastage and ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text:
What is the target of Deep Brain stimulation in dyskinesia associated with chronic parkinson's disease in the indirect and direct pathways respectively?

STN - Sub-thalamic nucleus

GPi - Globus Pallidus Interna

VIM - Ventral Intermediate Nucleus

GPe - Globus Pallidus Externa
questions.solution:
The Subthalamic nucleus (STN) in the indirect pathway and Globus Pallidus Internus (GPi) in the direct pathway are the preferred sites of deep brain stimulation in Parkinsonism-associated dyskinesia.

The direct pathway through the basal ganglia to the thalamus, and ultimately the motor areas of the cortex, enhances motor activity, while the indirect pathway reduces the activity of neurons in motor areas of the cerebral cortex.

In the direct pathway, the striatum projects to the GPi. This projection is inhibitory, and the main transmitter is GABA. The GPi projects to the ventroanterior (VA) and ventrolateral (VL) nuclei of the thalamus. These connections also function with GABA and are inhibitory. The indirect pathway involves inhibitory connections from the striatum to the GPe, which in turn sends an inhibitory projection to the subthalamic nucleus, which sends an excitatory projection to GPi.

Parkinson's disease is a disorder characterised by tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. In Parkinson's disease, efferents from the Substantia Nigra Pars Compacta (SNc) to the striatum degenerate. The D1 receptor-mediated activation of the direct pathway is lost, resulting in excessive GPi firing, which causes bradykinesia.

The loss of dopamine diminishes the activity of the direct pathway and increases the activity of the indirect pathway. This results in an increase in the activity of GPi neurons and greater inhibition of neurons in the ventroanterior and ventrolateral nuclei. This further leads to less activation of motor cortex areas, difficulty initiating movement and slowed movement (bradykinesia).

Deep brain stimulation suppresses the activity of the GPi or the subthalamic nucleus by implanting an electrode in these sites which inhibits them and thereby reduce inhibition of VA and VL.

Note:

  • In Hemiballismus, the STN is affected. It is a violent form of choreiform movement composed of wild, flinging, large-amplitude movements most frequently affecting proximal limb muscles on one side of the body (hemiballism).
  • In Huntington’s disease, striatal GABAergic neurons degenerate, contributing to motor dysfunction.

questions.text: There are more osmotically active particles in the cells than in interstitial or intercellular fluid due to the presence of non-diffusible charged proteins in the cells. How is this phenomenon best explained?
questions.solution:
The statement 'there are more osmotically active particles in the cells than in interstitial or intercellular fluid due to the presence of non-diffusible charged proteins in the cells' is explained by the Donnan effect.

The Donnan effect states that, in the presence of a non-diffusible ion such as negatively charged protein, the diffusible ions distribute themselves so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

For example, let's consider that there are two compartments X and Y, containing potassium and chloride ions, which are diffusible, and negatively charged proteins in compartment X.

As the protein is non-diffusible, the potassium and chloride ions diffuse such that their concentration ratios are equal.

The Donnan effect on the distribution of ions has three effects:

  • Due to the presence of non-diffusible negatively charged proteins in the cells, there are more osmotically active particles in cells than in interstitial or inter-cellular fluid. The presence of more osmotically active particles drags water into the cells, which may eventually cause the cells to swell and rupture. This is prevented by the presence of the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, which pumps the ions back out of the cells.
  • At equilibrium, the distribution of the diffusible ions is asymmetric. This causes an electrical difference exists across the membrane.
  • There are more proteins in the plasma than in the interstitial fluid. The resultant Donnan effect is responsible for the movement of the ions across the capillary wall.

Other options:

Option A: Nernst equation is used to determine the magnitude of equilibrium potential. Equilibrium potential is the membrane potential at which an ion exists in equilibrium across the membrane.

questions.text:
A patient with PCOS on an ovulation induction regimen with hMG underwent a USG where she was noted to have 22 follicles. Beta hCG was administered, and soon after, the patient went into shock and became unresponsive. Which of the following drugs could have been given as a preventive measure to avoid this complication?

hMG: Human Menopausal Gonadotropin
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome(OHSS) which occurs more frequently after ovulation induction with Gonadotropin agents like Human Menopausal Gonadotropin(HMG). Beta HCG is used as an ovulation-triggering agent. Cabergoline can be administered as a preventive measure against OHSS.

OHSS is an iatrogenic complication of ovulation induction regimens for assisted reproductive technology in infertile couples. In OHSS, multiple follicles are stimulated to grow under the influence of agents like HMG, clomiphene, etc. These follicles produce growth factors, prostaglandins, and cytokines, which shift fluid from the intravascular to extravascular compartment leading to hypovolemia, third spacing of fluid causing ascites, hydrothorax, etc 

Cabergoline prevents OHSS from manifesting as it is known to have an anti-VEGF activity on the follicles. VEGF is an important molecule secreted by active follicles implicated in the pathogenesis of OHSS, and reduced VEGF activity prevents OHSS.

Risk factors for OHSS are:

  • Young female
  • PCOS undergoing ovulation induction
  • History of OHSS
  • Estradiol level >3000 pg/ml
  • 20 or more small follicles on Abdominal USG
  • FSH/LH(HMG) based regimens>Clomiphene>GnRH for ovulation induction

Complications of OHSS include:

  • CVA, thromboembolic events, DVT
  • Liver dysfunction
  • ARDS due to ascites,hydrothorax
  • Coagulopathies
  • Hypovolemia inducing Renal failure, Shock
  • Hemorrhage and Torsion of ovarian cyst

Preventive measures against OHSS are:

  • hCG should be withheld in a cycle if >20 follicles seen or E2 level rises to >3000pg/ml 
  • Withhold hCG in PCOS patients
  • Albumin 5% infusion in 500 ml RL during and after oocyte retrieval
  • Cabergoline 0.5 mg/day starting day 1 up to 8 days

Other options:

Option A: VEGF is implicated in the pathogenesis of OHSS.It is not used in prevention.

Option B: Mifepristone, an antiprogestin, is not used to prevent OHSS. Rather, there is some evidence that progesterone support may help in OHSS.

Option D:Spironolactone is a diuretic and antiandrogen which has no role in prevention of OHSS. Diuretics exacerbate OHSS symptoms and are contraindicated in its management.

questions.text: A dead body was found in a forest. The postmortem change shown in the image below was prominently seen in the body. Which of the following features will not be present in the body at this time?

choices.text: A reddish frothy fluid coming out of nostrils and mouth

questions.solution:
The appearance shown in the image is marbling. Prominent marbling is seen in 36-48 hours after death. By this time, rigor mortis disappears.

Rigor mortis (cadaveric rigidity or death stiffening) refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. It usually begins 1-2 hours after death and gets well established by 9-12 hours. It then passes off by 18-36 hours. 

Other changes which are seen in 36-48 hours after death:

  • Well distended abdomen
  • Features become bloated and distorted due to the accumulation of gases of decomposition
  • Breast, scrotum, and penis markedly distended
  • A reddish, frothy fluid may get forced out from the nostrils and mouth as the lungs are forced upwards due to the pressure of gases in the abdomen.
  • Appearance of maggots

questions.text: Name the genes altered in the given pathway.
questions.solution:
The correct order is 1. APC gene, 2. K-RAS and 3. p53.

Adenocarcinoma of the colon is the most common malignancy of the GI tract. The pathogenesis of colon cancer can be explained by three distinct pathways of genomic instability:

  1. Chromosomal instability / APC-β-catenin pathway / Classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence.
  2. Microsatellite instability pathway (MSI).
  3. CpG Island Methylator Phenotype pathway.
1. Chromosomal instability / APC-β-catenin pathway / classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence is the most common pathway accounting for 80% of sporadic cancers. The "first-hit" in this pathway is the inherited or acquired mutation of the cancer suppressor gene APC on chromosome 5q21. But, both copies of the APC gene must be inactivated. The "second hit" is due to methylation abnormalities. This results in the loss of both APC alleles. The APC protein normally promotes the degradation of β-catenin. Since it is lost, β-catenin accumulates and translocates to the nucleus. This causes activation of transcription of genes that promote proliferation.
Mutations of K-RAS on chromosome 12p12, TP53 on chromosome 17p13, and LOH at chromosome 18q21 are involved in further steps of the classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence.
 
2. Microsatellite instability pathway (MSI) occurs in patients with DNA mismatch repair deficiency leading to the accumulation of mutations in microsatellite repeats. The main pathogenic mechanisms are mutations of type II TGF-β receptor, leading to uncontrolled cell growth, and loss of pro-apoptotic BAX genes that enhance the survival of genetically abnormal clones.
 
3. CpG island hypermethylation phenotype (CIMP) - The MLH1 promoter region undergoes hypermethylation, reducing MLH1 expression and its repair function. There are also activating mutations in the oncogenes like BRAF. KRAS and TP53 tumor suppressor genes are not mutated. The combination of MSI, BRAF mutation, and methylation of specific targets, such as MLH1, contributes to the development of colorectal cancer through this pathway.

questions.text: You are an intern performing clinical rounds in the casualty. The casualty receives a call asking for arrangements to receive the patients of a road traffic accident that occurred nearby. The trauma PG wants you to assess the severity of the patients, taking the mechanism of injury into account. Which of the following scoring systems will you use?
questions.solution:
The Trauma and Injury Severity Score takes into consideration the "injury mechanism" to calculate the severity of the patient.

The components of TRISS include:

  • Injury Severity Score (ISS)
  • Revised Trauma Score (RTS)
  • Age
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)

Other options :

Injury Severity Score (ISS):

The Injury Severity Score (ISS) is calculated by summing the squares of the Abbreviated Injury Scale (AIS) severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions. The ISS ranges from 1 to 75, with severity groupings being defined as minor injury (ISS less than 9), moderate injury (ISS between 9 and 16), serious injury (ISS between 16 and 25), and severe injury (ISS more than 25). 

Revised Trauma Score (RTS):

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a well-studied physiologic scoring system that characterizes the injured patient’s condition by incorporating the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate. These scores have been of value for research purposes and have been successfully used to make triage decisions.

Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS):

The Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) is the most widely validated classification system. It takes into consideration the following,

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

A score of 7 or higher consistently predicted the need for amputation, whereas all limbs with initial scores of 6 or less remained viable in the long term.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is routinely used for the isolation of the bacteria?
questions.solution:
The method used for the isolation of the bacteria is streak culture.

Streak culture is routinely used for the isolation of bacteria in pure culture from clinical specimens. It is prepared by picking the specimen using platinum loops or straight wires and transferring it onto a well-dried plate. The inoculum is then distributed thinly over the plate by streaking it with the loop in a series of parallel lines in different segments of the plate. 

Other methods used in bacterial culture:

Lawn culture/carpet culture: It is used for bacteriophage typing and antibiotic sensitivity testing. It is prepared by flooding the surface of the plate with a liquid culture.

Stab culture is prepared by puncturing a suitable medium with a long, straight, charged wire. The oxygen-requiring bacteria will grow on the surface, and the bacteria that do not require oxygen will grow at the bottom.

Stroke culture: It provides pure growth of bacterium for slide agglutination and other diagnostic tests.

Pour plate culture: It gives an estimate of viable bacterial count in a suspension. It is prepared by adding appropriate dilutions of the inoculum (1 ml) to the molten (40-45°C) agar, which is mixed and poured into sterile Petri dishes. After incubation, colonies are seen to be distributed throughout the depth of the medium. 

Liquid culture: These are preferred for inocula containing antibiotics and other inhibitory substances. It is prepared by inoculating liquid cultures in tubes, bottles, or flasks by touching them with a charged loop, pipettes, or syringes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with fever, headache, myalgias, and a skin rash on the arm as shown below. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition.

choices.text: It is transmitted by the bite of Ixodid ticks
The causative organism is Borrelia recurrentis
It is associated with cranial nerve palsies

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever, headache, myalgias, and the characteristic bull’s eye rash (erythema migrans) is suggestive of Lyme disease. The causative organism is Borrelia burgdorferi. Hence, option B is the incorrect statement.

Lyme disease is transmitted by the bite of Ixodid ticks (hard tick). The disease occurs in 3 stages:

  • Primary stage - characterized by the characteristic bull’s eye rash. The rash starts as a small macule at the site of the tick bite and gradually expands with central clearing.
  • Secondary stage - characterized by secondary annular skin rashes, migratory arthritis, fever, and generalized lymphadenopathy. This stage can be associated with neurological abnormalities like aseptic meningitis and cranial nerve palsies. Patients may also develop myocarditis with associated AV block.
  • Tertiary stage - characterized by chronic arthritis, cranial nerve palsies, ataxia, and dermatitis. 

Doxycycline is the drug of choice in the initial stages of Lyme disease when there is no CNS involvement. If there is CNS involvement, i.v. ceftriaxone is used for treatment.

Borrelia recurrentis causes relapsing fever. It is characterized by alternating periods of fever followed by an afebrile period. The disease is transmitted by body lice.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male patient was referred to you with features of pituitary adenoma and testicular tumor. While going through his radiological reports, you notice that the patient has a history of parathyroid adenoma. His chromosomal studies show a mutation in the CDKN1B gene. What is the most likely diagnosis?

CDKN1B gene : Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 1b gene
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of pituitary adenoma, parathyroid adenoma, testicular tumor, and a mutation in the CDKN1B gene is suggestive of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 4 (MEN 4).

MEN 4 is an autosomal dominant endocrine tumor syndrome. It occurs due to the germline mutation in the CDKN1B gene in chromosome 12.

MEN 4 often presents with parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, or neuroendocrine cervical cancer with adrenal or renal tumors. 

The clinical presentation in MEN 4 is almost similar to that of MEN1. The difference between MEN1 and MEN4 is in the germline mutation, where MEN 1 occurs due to the mutation of the MEN1 gene.

MEN is a group of autosomal dominant disorders characterized by tumors involving two or more endocrine glands. Depending on the chromosomal location of germline mutation, they are divided into four major forms: MEN 1, MEN 2A, MEN 2B (MEN 3), and MEN 4. MEN 1 is the most common among the four types. 

Other Options:

Option B: MEN 3 is also known as MEN 2B. It occurs due to a mutation of the RET gene. It is associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuroma, and marfanoid features. In contrast with MEN2A, parathyroid hyperplasia is not seen in MEN 2B.

Option C: MEN 2A is also known as Sipple's syndrome. It occurs due to a mutation of the RET gene. It is associated with medullary carcinoma thyroid, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenoma.

Option D: MEN 1 is also known as Wermer's syndrome. It occurs due to a mutation in the MEN1 gene. It is associated with parathyroid adenoma, pancreatic tumors, and pituitary tumors.

  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma

questions.text:
A patient with coronary artery disease who does not tolerate 1st line anti-anginal drugs is prescribed trimetazidine. How would you classify this drug according to its mechanism of action?

pFOX - partial fatty acid oxidation
questions.solution:
Trimetazidine is a pFOX inhibitor.

Trimetazidine partially inhibits fatty acid oxidation in the heart by inhibiting the last enzyme in the beta-oxidation pathway. This causes a shift in heart metabolism to use glucose. Since oxygen required is lesser in glucose metabolism, it is believed to be helpful in ischemia by decreasing the oxygen demand of the heart.

It is used as a second-line anti-anginal drug in case of stable angina when 1st line agents are not tolerated.

Side effects include nausea, vomiting, and gastrointestinal upset. It can also cause hepatic enzyme elevation and thrombocytopenia.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker

questions.text:
A resident is asked to prepare a surgical instruments table for an adenotonsillectomy under general anesthesia. What is the order in which the following instruments are used during surgery?

1)Eve’s tonsillar snare

2)Boyle Davis Mouth Gag

3)Tonsil dissector and anterior pillar retractor

4)St Clair Thompson Adenoid Curette
questions.solution:
The answer is option C: 2,4,3,1. The order in which instruments are used for Adenotonsillectomy is Boyle Davis Mouth Gag -> St Clair Thompson Adenoid Curette -> Tonsil Dissector and Anterior Pillar Retractor -> Eve's Tonsillar Snare.

While performing an adenotonsillectomy, adenoidectomy must always precede the tonsillectomy. Once the adenoids are removed, the nasopharynx should be packed, and only then tonsillectomy is done. The correct sequence of events and instruments used in an adenotonsillectomy are:

  1. Boyle Davis's mouth gag is introduced. Draffin’s bipods are used to hold the mouth gag in place.
  2. Correct size St Clair Thompson Adenoid Curette is introduced into the nasopharynx and with gentle sweeping movement, adenoids are shaved off and hemostasis is achieved. Packing is done.
  3. Tonsil is grasped with tonsil holding forceps and pulled medially.
  4. An incision is made in the mucous membrane reflecting from the anterior pillar to the tonsil. The upper pole of the tonsil is separated from peritonsillar tissue.
  5. The upper pole is held, and traction using the Tonsil Dissector and Anterior Pillar retractor's retractor portion is applied medially and downwards. Dissection can be continued with another Tonsil Dissector and Anterior pillar retractor's dissector portion until the lower pole.
  6. Eve’s snare is passed over the tonsil onto its pedicle, tightened, and cut. The tonsil is removed. Hemostasis is ensured by packing and tying bleeding points with silk using a Negus knot tier.

questions.text: The intravenous pyelogram of a patient with persistent flank pain is given below. What is the most likely condition associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows medial deviation of bilateral ureters giving the appearance of a narrow-waisted maiden. Hence, this is called the maiden waist sign and is seen in retroperitoneal fibrosis. It is associated with IgG4 related systemic disease.

This is an uncommon fibrotic reaction in the retroperitoneum that typically presents with ureteral obstruction. In this condition, there is a medial drawing of the ureter due to the deposition of fibrous tissue in the lumbosacral junction. 

The following images show the maiden waist sign (A) as compared to a normal IVP (B).

Other options:

Option A: PKD1 mutation is seen in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).

Option C: Aberrant blood supply to kidneys is seen in horseshoe kidney.

Option D: Persistent right posterior cardinal vein is seen in retrocaval ureter.
