questions.text:
Hormone X is responsible for the rise in basal body temperature following ovulation. Which of the following does not indicate use for the hormone/its derivatives in routine practice via the oral route?

HRT: Hormone Replacement Therapy
questions.solution:
The hormone X is Progesterone, which is generally not used orally for HRT post hysterectomy.

Basal body temperature(BBT) changes during the menstrual cycle are due to the hormone Progesterone(Hormone X). A rise in BBT by over 0.5 degree Celsius occurs after ovulation due to the hormone progesterone, produced by the corpus luteum in the luteal phase. Progesterone or its derivatives are not routinely used as a solo oral drug in HRT after hysterectomy as there is no role of the endometrial protective activity of progesterone in the absence of a uterus.

The plasma level of progesterone rises after ovulation due to the hormone's production by the corpus luteum and reaches a peak level of 15 ng/mL at the mid-luteal phase. Due to its thermogenic effects, progesterone raises the BBT by 0.5 degrees Celsius.

This is the basis of the BBT method, a natural method of contraception that involves serial monitoring of body temperature to determine when to abstain from intercourse.

HRT or hormone replacement therapy is done in conditions like premature menopause, symptomatic women suffering from estrogen deficiency, high-risk cases for menopause-related complications, gonadal dysgenesis in adults, etc.

Progesterone has the following seminal roles in HRT:

  • Prevents endometrial hyperplasia. Oral progesterone and its derivatives may be given along with oral estrogens in nonhysterectomized women to prevent endometrial hyperplasia that occurs due to estrogen. 
  • Improves bone mineral density.
  • An implant may replace estrogen in estrogen-intolerant women.

Progesterone acts on the enzyme 17 beta hydroxy dehydrogenase, which inactivates estradiol and controls mitotic activity within the endometrial lining. This valuable action can reduce the incidence of endometrial hyperplasia and the development of CA Endometrium. Progesterone implants may replace oral estrogen in those intolerant to it. Mirena IUCD is also used as solo HRT. Oral progestins have multiple side effects and poor tolerance profile and hence are generally not used as solo drugs in HRT, especially in hysterectomized women, where their endometrial protective activity is not relevant.

Other Options:

Option A: Progesterone and its derivatives are used to prevent threatened abortion.

Option C: Third-generation progestogens, with fewer androgenic side effects, are an excellent substitute for danazol in managing symptoms and reducing the size of endometriosis lesions.

Option D: Medroxyprogesterone acetate 1g weekly or 200mg orally is used in advanced endometrial cancers to reduce estrogen receptors and prolong survival as part of palliative care.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with PCOS, anxious to conceive, visits the OPD. She is informed about attempting ovulation induction for the management of her infertility, as shown in the image below. Which of the following satisfies the sonographic criteria used for oocyte retrieval in this method?
questions.solution:
The ultrasonography criteria used for oocyte retrieval is ≥ 3 follicles at ≥ 17mm.

In a woman with PCOS, agents like clomiphene citrate or gonadotropins are commonly used for ovulation induction for infertility management. These drugs are usually given from day 2 or 3 of the cycle & the patient is serially monitored with USG for follicle development until the time for egg retrieval. 

Once there are at least 3 follicles in an ovary of size 17mm, HCG is administered, and the mature follicles are retrieved 36 hrs later. Following IVF, the embryo is reimplanted into the uterus 3-5 days later, and the pregnancy is closely monitored and supported by a progesterone supplement. This is known as the long protocol involving downregulation of the gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist.

Other options:

Option B: ≥ 12 follicles, <10mm that is, 2-9 mm each, is the cut-off for diagnosis of PCOS according to the Rotterdam criteria.

questions.text: In the HIV Sentinel Surveillance program under NACO, the general population is compared to the high-risk group in terms of disease trends. Which group acts as the proxy group for the general population in sentinel surveillance?

choices.text: HIV Testing in Single Male Migrants(SMM)

questions.solution:
In the HIV Sentinel Surveillance program, the Antenatal mothers are taken as the proxy group representing the general population, and HIV testing is done in Antenatal mothers.

Sentinel Surveillance program aims to provide information regarding HIV prevalence and trends by various population groups. The Indian arm of the program is among the largest in a global network of HIV Sentinel Surveillance.

Monitoring of the HIV epidemic is done in three groups: High Risk Groups, Bridge Population and General Population. High Risk Groups have high prevalence of HIV, Bridge group has moderate prevalence and General Population has low prevalence.

High Risk Group Bridge Population General Population

 FSW: Female Sex Workers

MSM: Men who have Sex with Men

IDU: Injecting Drug Users

H/TG:Hijra/Transgender

SMM: Single Male Migrants

LDT: Long Distance Truckers

 

  Represented by Antenatal mothers

The bridge population with moderate prevalence is believed to be the mobile group of individuals who engage in risky sexual behavior and transfer HIV from High-Risk Groups to the General Population.

Among Antenatal women, the LAT: Linked Anonymous Testing approach is done whereby a small portion of the sample taken from ANM is used for HIV testing. Inclusion criteria for ANM are: i. Pregnant woman of age 15-49 years, and ii. Attending the antenatal clinic for the first time during the current round of surveillance. Consent is not obtained, and no identification data is provided for the blood sample. Instead, samples are given reference numbers. Testing is primarily for the study.

Other Options:

Option A) and Option B) Individuals testing positive in STD clinics and Blood Donation do not form part of sentinel surveillance.

Option D) SMM form Bridge population.

questions.text: If the cutoff value of the given screening test is changed from point B to point A, what will happen to the negative and positive predictive values, respectively?
questions.solution:
As the cutoff point shifts from point B to point A, the test's negative predictive value increases and the positive predictive value decreases.

In the given diagram

TN- True negative, FN- False negative, FP- False positive, TP- True positive

Negative predictive value (NPV) is the proportion of negative results that are true negatives, that is, the possibility that a person with a negative test does not have the condition.

NPV = TN/(TN+FN), as False Negative(FN) decreases in the above case, NPV will increase.

Positive predictive value (PPV) is the proportion of positive results that are true positives, that is, the possibility that a person with a positive test result truely has the disease

PPV = TP / (TP + FP), as False Positive (FP) increases in the above case, PPV will decrease.

When the cutoff value is decreased by changing the cutoff towards Point A, the test will now identify everyone with the disease and thus have a very high sensitivity. But at this point, the test would also incorrectly diagnose many healthy individuals as diseased. Therefore, the number of false positive results would also be high, and thus the specificity decreases.

Opposite trends will be seen when the cutoff shifts towards point C, leading to higher specificity but low sensitivity with an increase in PPV and a decrease in NPV. 

Thus, the cutoff points of screening tests are very meticulously chosen to maintain high enough specificity and sensitivity both for clinical practice.

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: What is the most common indication for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The given procedure is PEG tube placement. Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy tube placement is a bedside surgical procedure for which the most common indication is to provide enteral nutrition.

PEG tube placement is done to provide enteral nutrition for severely debilitated patients, patients with facial trauma, in indication for mechanical ventilation for over 4 weeks, risk of aspiration, inability to swallow, etc. It may also be used for the decompression of malignant bowel obstructions.

Contraindications to tube placement are:

  • No endoscopic access- cannot visualise tube entry into stomach cavity
  • Severe immunosuppression-(WBC count <1) high risk of tube site infection 
  • Significant ascites- in-drainable ascites makes tube insertion into the stomach extremely difficult
  • Severe coagulopathy- may cause bleeding
  • Other conditions may be morbid obesity, where it may be nearly impossible to push the tube through a thick layer of fat, and anterior abdominal wall infection, which need to be treated before performing PEG tube placement.

In history of recent or past laparotomy, a pre-procedure CT scan may be done to confirm that there is a window for tube insertion.

Steps of PEG Tube insertion:

  •  Pass a 14-gauge angiocatheter through the abdominal wall into the fully insufflated stomach.
  • Thread a guidewire through the angiocatheter.
  • Grasp the guidewire with snares or forceps and pull it out through the mouth.
  • Secure the tapered end of the PEG tube to the guidewire.
  • Pull the PEG tube into position, exiting through the abdominal wall.
  • Secure the PEG tube without tension against the abdominal wall.
  • Use the tube within hours of placement or connect it to a drainage bag for 24 hours to allow the stomach to seal against the peritoneum.

Complications of PEG tube placement are:

  • Free intraperitoneal air
  • Abdominal wall infection
  • Dislodgement of tube from stomach due to traction
  • Pressure necrosis of stomach wall and spillage of gastric contents into abdominal cavity
  • Other metabolic complications such as dyspepsia, constipation, diarrhea, and electrolyte abnormalities unrelated to tube placement may also occur.

Shown below is a PEG tube:

Other options:

Option A: NG tube is used for removal of ingested toxins.

Option B: Ambulatory pH monitoring is done with the help of a catheter passed through the nose into the esophagus.

Option D: Early diagnosis of Ca Stomach is done with regular screening Endoscopy in susceptible patients and modalities like EUS(Endoscopic Ultrasound).

questions.text:
A middle-aged man presented with hemoptysis and reduced urine output. There is no history of asthma or upper airway disease. On evaluation, he is found to be positive for p-ANCA. Renal biopsy showed non-granulomatous inflammation, with segmental fibrinoid necrosis. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

p-ANCA - perinuclear antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is microscopic polyangiitis.

The above clinical scenario of hemoptysis, reduced urine output, positive p-ANCA antibody, and biopsy showing non-granulomatous inflammation with segmental fibrinoid necrosis is suggestive of microscopic polyangiitis.

Microscopic polyangiitis is characterized by necrotizing vasculitis with few or no immune complexes affecting the small vessels (capillaries, venules, and arterioles). It may have a gradual or acute onset associated with fever, weight loss, and musculoskeletal pain. Renal involvement results in glomerulonephritis which results in renal failure. Hemoptysis occurs due to alveolar hemorrhage.

Laboratory investigations show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, anemia, leukocytosis, and thrombocytopenia. Most cases are associated with positive p-ANCA antibodies. Tissue biopsy would reveal non-granulomatous inflammation with segmental fibrinoid necrosis. 

Other options:

Option A: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is necrotizing arteritis of the medium and small-sized blood vessels. It can affect the skin, peripheral nerves, renal vessels, mesenteric vessels, heart, and brain. Lungs are usually spared in PAN. The disease initially starts with non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, arthralgia, and myalgia. Later, depending on the artery involved, patients may develop the following symptoms:

  • Skin findings - ulcers, digital gangrene, subcutaneous nodules, and livedo reticularis
  • Renal arteries - hypertension and renal failure
  • Mesenteric arteries - abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bleeding, and a bowel perforation

Patients with PAN do not show p-ANCA and c-ANCA positivity. Tissue biopsy reveals segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation associated with luminal thrombosis.

Options B: Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by asthma, peripheral and tissue eosinophilia, extravascular granuloma formation, and vasculitis of multiple organs. The clinical features include non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss. The pulmonary findings are characterized by severe asthmatic attacks and pulmonary infiltrates. Renal disease is less common in these patients. These patients show p-ANCA positivity.

Option D: Wegener's granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by granulomatous vasculitis of the upper and lower respiratory tract with glomerulonephritis. The clinical features include bloody nasal discharge, nasal septal perforation, serous otitis media, hemoptysis, dyspnea, and glomerulonephritis which may lead to rapidly progressive renal failure. These patients show c-ANCA positivity. Tissue biopsy reveals granulomas with geographic patterns of central necrosis and accompanying vasculitis.

questions.text: A patient with chronic constipation presents with severe rectal pain. Physical examination reveals a painful swelling, as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation and a painful swelling as shown in the image point towards a Thrombosed hemorrhoid. 

Haemorrhoids are cushions of submucosal tissue containing venules, arterioles, and smooth muscle fibres located in the anal canal. External haemorrhoids are distal to the dentate line and are covered with anoderm; these may engorge, causing pain. Thrombosis of these external haemorrhoids causes severe rectal pain. 

Other options: 

Option B: Pilonidal sinus is commonly seen in men. Drivers and hairdressers are most widely affected. Physical examination reveals a pit in the natal cleft. The pilonidal sinus opening is usually seen in the midline between the sacrococcygeal joint's level and the coccyx's tip.

Option C: Perianal abscess refers to a collection of pus. Usually located at the anal verge and, if left untreated, can extend into the ischioanal space or intersphincteric space. Physical examination reveals a tender, fluctuant mass near the anus.

Option D: Complete rectal prolapse or full-thickness prolapse involves all the layers of the rectum. It is characterized by the presence of 'concentric rings' as shown in the image below.

questions.text:
In which of the following conditions is it appropriate to use low dose aspirin as prophylaxis against the development of preeclampsia in pregnancy?

1-Overt diabetes mellitus

2-Multifetal gestation

3-APLA Syndrome

4-Kidney disease
questions.solution:
It is appropriate to use low dose aspirin( 81 mg/day) for prophylaxis of pre-eclampsia in 1,2,3,4, i.e, overt diabetes mellitus, multifoetal gestation, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome( APLA), and kidney disease.

According to ACOG Guidelines reaffirmed on October 2022:

Low-dose aspirin (81 mg/d) prophylaxis is recommended for pregnant individuals who have a high risk of developing preeclampsia. This recommendation applies to those who exhibit one or more of the following risk factors:

  • History of preeclampsia, especially when accompanied by an adverse outcome
  • Multifetal gestation
  • Chronic hypertension
  • Pregestational type 1 or 2 diabetes (overt DM)
  • Kidney disease
  • Autoimmune disease (ie, systemic lupus erythematosus, antiphospholipid syndrome)
  • Combinations of multiple moderate-risk factors. 

The following factors are considered to be moderate risk factors: nulliparity, obesity (BMI over 30), family history of preeclampsia (mother or sister), Black race, lower income, 35 years of age or older, personal history factors (e.g., low birth weight, small for gestational age, previous adverse pregnancy outcome, pregnancy interval greater than 10 years), and in vitro fertilization. Other factors that play a role in the prevention of preeclampsia include calcium supplementation in case of deficiency and exercise during pregnancy.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male with a history of smoking presents with flank pain and hematuria. CT scan of the abdomen reveals a mass in the left kidney with characteristics suggestive of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). The tumor is suspected to have infiltrated the IVC. Which of the following is the investigation of choice to assess the extent of vascular invasion in this patient?

IVC: Inferior vena cava
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, MR angiography is the investigation of choice for detecting vascular invasion in a patient with renal cell carcinoma (RCC).

Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC) is diagnosed incidentally or with non-specific symptoms such as hematuria, abdominal pain, and weight loss. A solid mass seen on ultrasound raises suspicion for RCC. Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) is the investigation of choice for evaluating RCC. 

While CT is typically the primary imaging modality for RCC diagnosis, MR angiography is superior in detecting tumour infiltration into the vein wall and the level of thrombus.

Other options:

Option C: PET scans are useful for detecting metastasis and tumor activity but are not typically used to evaluate vascular invasion.

Option D: Inferior Vena Cavography is an invasive procedure, and MRI is preferred for vascular invasion.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is a component of pantothenic acid?
questions.solution:
The amino acid present in pantothenic acid is beta-alanine.

Pantothenic acid (vitamin B5) is an essential nutrient that plays a crucial role in metabolism. It is a key component of coenzyme A (CoA), which is involved in numerous biochemical reactions, particularly in transferring acyl groups.

Functions of Pantothenic Acid in the Body:

  • Facilitates fatty acid oxidation and synthesis.
  • Involved in the formation of succinyl-CoA and acetyl-CoA, essential intermediates in the Krebs cycle.
  • Precursor to HMG-CoA, which is crucial for cholesterol synthesis.
  • CoA participates in acetylation, which modifies proteins, neurotransmitters, and drugs.

The intestinal gut flora synthesizes vitamin B5, so deficiency is rare. Grierson-Gopalan's burning foot syndrome is a rare disorder caused by pantothenic acid deficiency. Its clinical features include burning pain and paresthesia in the lower extremities, staggering gait due to impaired coordination, and sleep disturbance.

Other Options:

Option A: Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid involved in dopamine and melanin synthesis.

Option B: Tryptophan is a precursor for serotonin, melatonin, and niacin (Vitamin B3).

Option D: Arginine is involved in the urea cycle and nitric oxide (NO) synthesis.

questions.text: The most probable diagnosis inferred from the given clinical images is?
questions.solution:
The clinical features shown in the images are periorificial dermatitis and alopecia. These features in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica seen with zinc deficiency.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive condition where the absorption of zinc is defective by the intestinal epithelial cell. Affected infants respond dramatically to zinc supplementation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female came with complaints of painful, pruritic, fissured lesions over the axilla.  A diagnosis of Hailey-Hailey disease was made. Which among the following layers of the epidermis is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
In Hailey-Hailey disease, histology shows acantholysis through the stratum spinosum. In the above image, the most likely affected layer is 3 which is the stratum spinosum.

Hailey–Hailey disease is an autosomal dominant disorder that causes recurrent blisters and erosions, mainly in flexural areas and friction-prone sites. It is caused by the loss of adhesion between keratinocytes in the stratum spinosum, which resembles a dilapidated brick wall. Patients often present with painful, pruritic lesions in flexures. Fissuring and erosion are also seen in the axilla and groin.

From superficial to deep, the layers of the epidermis are marked in the image below.

  1. Stratum corneum
  2. Stratum granulosum
  3. Stratum spinosum
  4. Stratum basale

The thick skin found in the palms and soles has an additional fifth layer, called the stratum lucidum, located between the stratum corneum and stratum granulosum.

questions.text: A couple decided to opt for a government-sponsored permanent method of sterilization in a district hospital. On postoperative day two, the patient faced medical complications arising from the operation. The spouse received a cash sum from the government. This cash sum is covered under?
questions.solution:
The given scenario where medical complications have arisen out of a permanent sterilization operation satisfies the condition for disbursement of money via NFPIS- National Family Planning Indemnity Scheme.

The NFPIS ( also called the Family Planning Indemnity Scheme) was constituted in 2013 by the Government of India. It was created to encourage patients to undergo permanent sterilization. In the event of death, incapacitation, or complication, the government would indemnify the sterilization acceptors and healthcare providers with a predetermined amount of money. This would allow sterilization programs to function even in the face of surgical complications or death, save doctors from litigation, and facilitate more sterilization operations by providing healthcare workers indemnity cover.

NFPIS provisions are, as of the year 2016: ( regional differences in actual amount disbursed may exist)

  • Death following sterilization (inclusive of death during the process of sterilization operation) in hospital or within 7 days from the date of discharge from the hospital: Rs. 2 Lac
  • Death following sterilization within 8-30 days from the date of discharge from the hospital: Rs. 50,000/-
  • Failure of sterilization: Rs. 30,000/-
  • Cost of treatment in the hospital and up to 60 days arising out of complications following sterilization operation (inclusive of complications during the process of sterilization operation) from the date of discharge: Rs. 25,000/-
  • Indemnity per Doctor/Health Facilities, but not more than 4 in a year: Up to Rs. 2 Lakh per claim

Other Options:

Option A: The Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY) is a component of the Ayushman Bharat scheme, which aims to build a comprehensive need-based healthcare service. It provides health insurance coverage of Rs. 5 lakhs per year to poor and vulnerable families seeking secondary and tertiary care. It has been expanded to include all individuals above 70 years, irrespective of socioeconomic status.

Option B: Pradhan Mantri Suraksha Bima Yojana(PMSBY). This renewable Personal Accident Insurance Scheme provides one-year coverage and can be renewed annually. It offers financial protection in the event of death or disability resulting from an accident. In this context, an accident refers to a sudden, unforeseen, and involuntary event caused by external, violent, and visible means. This scheme does not cover hospitalization or any related expenses.

Option D: The Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Janaushadhi Pariyojana (PMBJP), also known as the Janaushadhi Scheme, was launched by the Department of Pharmaceuticals under the Ministry of Chemicals & Fertilizers in November 2008. The scheme aims to provide quality generic medicines at affordable prices to all citizens. To achieve this, dedicated outlets called Janaushadhi Kendras are established to dispense generic medicines at significantly reduced costs.

questions.text: A young man suffered a trauma to his right hand while playing basketball. 3 weeks later, he reports to the orthopedician because of pain and stiffness over the right wrist. On examination, wrist movements are limited and painful. He is diagnosed with Kienböck's disease. This condition involves avascular necrosis of:
questions.solution:
Kienböck's disease involves avascular necrosis of the lunate.

This condition is usually seen in young adults, who present with pain and stiffness in the wrist. A history of trauma may be present. On examination, localized tenderness can be appreciated over the lunate, and a reduction in grip strength can be noted. Limited and painful wrist movements are noted in the later stages of the disease.

It involves four stages: 

  • Stage 1 involves ischemia of the bone, without any clinical or radiographic abnormality 
  • Stage 2 shows trabecular necrosis with reactive new bone formation. There is increased radiographic density, but little/no distortion of the shape
  • Stage 3 involves the collapse of the bone
  • Stage 4 is characterized by disruption of radiocarpal congruence and secondary osteoarthritis

In the initial stages, an X-ray might be normal, therefore an MRI with gadolinium enhancement is the investigation of choice. 

Management includes the use of splints and vascularized bone grafts for the early stages of the disease and total wrist fusion/replacement for advanced disease.

Note: Avascular necrosis of the scaphoid occurs due to a fracture of the waist of the scaphoid bone.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a painless, firm mass near the orbit, along with swelling and proptosis of the eyes as shown in the image. The physician suspects a hematological malignancy affecting the myeloid lineage. Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is most frequently seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario describes Orbital Chloroma in a child. t(8;21) translocation is the most frequent chromosomal abnormality seen in this condition.

Orbital chloroma/Granulocytic sarcoma/Myeloid sarcoma is an extramedullary tumor composed of myeloblasts that disrupts the normal tissue structure. It can occur before, alongside, or after a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in the bone marrow or blood. It is associated with t(8;21) translocation which is also one of the most frequently observed translocation in Acute myeloid leukemia.

It is associated with the M2 class as per the old FAB classification of AML. As per the WHO 2022 classification of Acute myeloid leukemia, they fall under a separate category of “AML with defining genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes).” These tumors, if left untreated, often proceed to full-blown Acute Myeloid leukemia. 

Other Options:

Option A: t(9;22) is seen in Chronic Myeloid Leukemia.

Option C: t(15;17) is seen in Acute pro-myelocytic leukemia (M3 type of AML).

Option D: t(11;18) is seen in Marginal zone lymphomas.

questions.text: According to the Erlanger and Gasser classification, which type of nerve fiber carries proprioceptive signals?
questions.solution:
According to the Erlanger and Gasser classification, proprioception is carried by Aα fiber.

Erlanger and Gasser classified nerve fibers into types A, B, and C, with type A fibers further subdivided into α, β, γ, and δ fibers.

questions.text: A patient who was hospitalized and started on an intravenous antibiotic has developed diarrhea. The findings of the colonoscopy are given below. Which of the following antibiotic is most likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with hospital-acquired diarrhea (nosocomial) following antibiotic administration is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis most likely due to clindamycin. 

Pseudomembranous colitis is an advanced form of clostridium difficile infection (CDI) that is visualized at endoscopy. Pseudomembranes are seen as whitish yellow plaques on the mucosa. Clostridium difficile infection is the most commonly diagnosed nosocomial diarrhea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, that causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora. This leads to the colonization of C. difficile.

Antibiotics that may cause CDI are:

  • Clindamycin
  • Ampicillin
  • Cephalosporins- cefotaxime, ceftriaxone, cefuroxime, and ceftazidime
  • Fluroquinolones- ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, and moxifloxacin

Clinical features include diarrhea, lower abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis. The diagnosis is based on clinical criteria: 

  • Diarrhea without other recognized causes, and
  • Detection of toxin A or B in the stool, toxin-producing C. difficile in the stool 

Discontinuation of the offending antimicrobial, if possible, is the first step in management. Oral vancomycin and fidaxomicin (Option B) are used for the treatment of pseudomembranous colitis, depending on its severity. 

Other options:

Option A: Daptomycin may cause allergic pneumonitis in patients receiving prolonged therapy for more than 2 weeks.

Option D: Chloramphenicol is mainly associated with adverse effects such as bone marrow suppression, and hypersensitivity reactions. When given to infants, it may cause grey baby syndrome.

questions.text: You are assisting a case of superficial parotidectomy as a junior resident. Your consultant asks you to identify the buccal branch of the facial nerve to trace back to the facial nerve trunk. Which of the following anatomical landmarks is used for the identification of the buccal branch of the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
The buccal branch of the facial nerve lies in relation to the parotid duct and is used as an anatomical landmark for the retrograde identification of the facial nerve trunk.

There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk: 

1. Anterograde method: In this method, the facial nerve trunk is identified based on the anatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. They are then traced distally to arrive at the facial nerve trunk. The anatomical landmarks include:

  • Tragal pointer/Conley's pointer: It is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
  • Posterior belly of digastric: The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle. (Option D)
  • Squamotympanic fissure: It is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from TMJ to the tympanic cavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure.
  • Styloid process: The facial nerve lies superficial to it. (Option B)
  • Mastoid process: Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally.

2. Retrograde method: In this method, the main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identified and are then traced proximally until the main tunk is identified. Some of the main branches that are commonly used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include:

  • Buccal branch: It lies in relation to the parotid duct.
  • Marginal mandibular branch: It lies in relation to the facial vessels. (Option A)
  • Temporal branch

questions.text: An infant with an umbilical hernia is brought by his parents to the OPD. He is noted to have coarse facial features, macroglossia, and hepatomegaly on examination. He is diagnosed to have a disease affecting the degradation of mucopolysaccharides in lysosomes. Which of the following cannot differentiate Type I from the Type II subset of this disease?
questions.solution:
The presence of coarse facial features, macroglossia, umbilical hernia, and visceromegaly with defective degradation in lysosomes is suggestive of mucopolysaccharidoses. Intellectual disability can be seen in both Type I and Type II mucopolysaccharidoses and cannot help differentiate the two.

Glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) or mucopolysaccharides are complex carbohydrates made up of amino sugars and uronic acids. They are attached to proteins to form proteoglycans, which make up a large part of the extracellular matrix and connective tissue. Defects in the enzymes that degrade GAGs result in mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS). Accumulation of GAGs in the tissue can result in organomegaly, cartilage and bone abnormalities, facial abnormalities, problems with mental development, etc. These defects are commonly inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

  • Type I MPS or Hurler's syndrome is caused due to deficiency of the α-L-iduronidase enzyme.
  • Type II MPS or Hunter's syndrome is caused due to deficiency of iduronate 2-sulfatase enzyme. 

Both enzyme deficiencies lead to the accumulation of dermatan and heparan sulfate. Common features of both Type I and II MPS include the presence of coarse facial features, intellectual disability, short stature, skeletal dysplasia, and dysostosis multiplex.

questions.text:
A dead fetus is recovered from a crime scene. Certain autopsy findings are given below. The investigator requests you to comment on whether the fetus may have been liveborn or stillborn. What is the most likely inference based on the given findings?
  • Length of fetus: 40 cm
  • Weight of fetus:1.7 kg
  • Lung: Non-crepitant, sharp margins, liver-like consistency
  • Breslau's first and second life tests are negative
questions.solution:
The most likely inference based on the above findings is that it is a stillborn fetus aged approximately 8 months.

Stillbirth refers to a fetus over 28 weeks that was alive in utero but dies during birth without showing signs of life. In this case, the lung has a non-crepitant, liver-like consistency with sharp margins indicating no inflation of air, confirming no breath was taken.

Breslau’s first and second life tests are negative, further supporting stillbirth. Determining whether a fetus was stillborn or live-born is crucial in medicolegal autopsies to distinguish infanticide or post-birth harm.

Age of the fetus can be determined using Haase’s modification of Morrison’s Law, which states that fetal age in the last 5 months is equal to Crown-heel length divided by 5. Age of foetus= 40/5= 8 months

Haase’s law states that fetal age in the first 5 months is the square root of the crown-heel length. To identify whether Haase's law or its modification is applicable, we must look at the fetal length or the gestational age. Fetal length at the end of five months is 25 cm. Here, as the length of this fetus is > 25cm, it indicates that Haase’s modification of Morrison’s law is applicable. 

Breslau's First and Second Life Tests:

Breslau’s First Life Test (Hydrostatic/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test) checks lung flotation in water to determine if respiration occurred. Lungs float due to air entry, which reduces their density.

Breslau’s Second Life Test (Stomach-Bowel Test) involves removing the stomach and duodenum to see if they float in water, indicating respiration. If air bubbles are released from the stomach, it may suggest live birth. However, this test can give false positives due to swallowed air in stillbirths or putrefaction.

Differentiating between a fetus that has breathed and one that has not can give us clues about whether it is a live-born or a stillborn. It is important to note that none of the points are absolute confirmation of live birth; they provide corroborative evidence that live birth is more likely.

AUTOPSY FINDING

FETUS THAT HAS NOT RESPIRED (Evidence supporting stillbirth)

 FETUS THAT HAS RESPIRED (Evidence supporting live birth)
1. Shape of the Chest  Flat, 1-2cm less than the abdomen at level of umbilicus  Arched or drum-shaped
 2. Position of the diaphragm  At the 4th/5th rib  At the 6th/7th rib
 3. Lung margins  Sharp  Rounded
 4. Lung consistency  Dense, firm, non-crepitant  Soft, spongy, elastic, crepitant
 5. Lung weight  1/70 of body weight  1/35 of body weight
 6. Lung color  Uniformly reddish-brown or bluish-red  Mottled/ marbled appearance with rose colored patches.
 7. Hydrostatic test Lung sinks in water Lung floats in water
 8. Stomach  Contains only mucin and sinks in water  Contains mucin and air. Floats in water
 9. Middle ear  Contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue

Air replaces the embryonic tissue

 

 

Related Pearl: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration.

Principle: Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False-negative test in:

  • Atelectasis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis
  • Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration
  • More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration
  • Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False-positive test in:

  • Putrefied foetus
  • Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when:

  • Fetus is monstrous
  • Fetus is macerated or mummified
  • Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation
  • Stomach contains milk
  • Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the image given below :

choices.text: Maternal diabetes is a risk factor
Application of fundal pressure aids delivery

questions.solution:
The image depicts shoulder dystocia and never apply fundal pressure in case of shoulder dystocia as it causes further impaction of the shoulder.

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or the posterior (rare) fetal shoulder impacts on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively.

Risk factors for the development of shoulder dystocia include maternal diabetes mellitus, obesity, postdatism, and prior history, excessive weight gain during pregnancy, etc.

Turtle Sign is positive: This is when the fetal head suddenly retracts back against the mother's perineum after it has emerged from the vagina. The baby's cheeks bulge out, resembling a turtle pulling its head back into its shell. This retraction of the fetal head is caused by the baby's anterior shoulder being caught on the back of the maternal pubic bone, preventing the delivery of the remainder of the baby.

Management of shoulder dystocia

  • 1st line - Mc.Roberts maneuver (flexion and abduction of thigh)
  • 2nd line - Woods corkscrew maneuver (Rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a corkscrew fashion)
  • 3rd line management options include:
    • Zavanelli maneuver (Push the head back and do a C-Section)
    • Cleidotomy (#clavicle of baby)
    • Symphysiotomy (divide pubic symphysis of mother)

Note:

  • In the case of bilateral shoulder dystocia, directly proceed to perform a C-section after doing the Zavanelli maneuver.
  • Never give fundal pressure in shoulder dystocia (suprapubic pressure can be given).

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with low-grade fever and a characteristic slapped cheek appearance. She is suspected to have erythema infectiosum. Which of the following is true regarding the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Erythema infectiosum is caused by parvovirus B19 virus, which is a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus. 

The main manifestation of symptomatic parvovirus B19 virus infection is erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease, which most commonly occurs in children of early school age or infants. Fever and mild constitutional symptoms may accompany the rash, which has a typical slapped cheek appearance.

 Pure red cell aplasia and chronic hemolytic anemia have been reported in patients with immunosuppression. Parvovirus B19V infection during pregnancy can lead to non-immune hydrops fetalis and/or fetal loss.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with fatigue, pallor, and tingling sensations in the hands and feet. On examination, the patient exhibits a smooth, red tongue and has difficulty walking due to a noticeable ataxia. Blood tests reveal a low hemoglobin level and elevated mean corpuscular volume (MCV). The patient also has elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels. Which enzyme is dependent on the vitamin which is deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Features of macrocytic anemia, tingling sensations in the hands and feet, and ataxia suggest Vitamin B12 Deficiency. Methionine Synthase is the enzyme dependent on Vitamin B12.

Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause subacute combined degeneration. Patients present with sensory ataxia (involvement of the dorsal column) and UMN-type motor symptoms such as spasticity and positive Babinski sign (involvement of corticospinal tract). Because of coexisting peripheral neuropathy, deep tendon reflexes can be absent. Some patients also develop cortical defects such as dementia. It can also present with elevated levels of Homocysteine in blood and urine. 

There are 2 enzymes dependent on vitamin B12:

  • Methyl malonyl CoA mutase
  • Methionine synthase

A deficiency of vitamin B12 leads to impairment of methionine synthase and also causes accumulation of homocysteine and trapping folate as methyltetrahydrofolate in addition to causing an increase in the serum methylmalonic acid levels (diagnostic test for Vitamin B12 deficiency).

Note: 

  • MMA and homocysteine elevated – Deficiency of vitamin B12 (does not eliminate the possibility of folate deficiency).
  • MMA normal, homocysteine elevated – Consistent with deficiency of folate. No deficiency of vitamin B12.

questions.text: A 16-month-old child who was immunized in the anterolateral aspect of the thigh with an IM vaccine and sent home returned to the PHC with anxious parents who complained that the child had suddenly gone limp, was not responding to any stimuli, and looked pale. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is true?

choices.text: Start IV corticosteroids and broad spectrum antibiotics
The condition is unrelated to the vaccine and is a coincidental event
Onset of this complication is from 0-48 hours of vaccination
The condition occurs due to error in vaccine handling

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario satisfies the criteria for diagnosis of HHE(Hypotonic Hyporesponsive Episode), a complication of vaccination with DPT occurring in children under 10 years. Onset of the complication is within 0-48 hours of vaccination.

HHE is diagnosed by the triad of:

  • Hypotonia of muscles- presents as limp body
  • Hyporesponsiveness to external stimuli
  • Pallor and/or cyanosis

Occurring in a child immunized with DPT (containing whole cell pertussis component, which is implicated in the development of HHE) within 0-48 hours of vaccination and lasting from a few minutes to hours. The episode may occur immediately or anytime up to 48 hours post-vaccination. 

Other Options:

Option A: HHE is usually not a life-threatening complication, although children may require monitoring and supportive care until stabilization. Corticosteroids and antibiotics are not indicated in the management of HHE. No treatment is usually required. The episode spontaneously resolves without long-term complications. 

Option B and D: This condition is neither coincidental nor related to errors in vaccine handling as a definitive link between DPT( pertussis component) and HHE has been established.

questions.text: A 7-month-old infant presented to OPD with a history of high fever since the last 4 days, which has since subsided. On examination, the infant has a rosy pink maculopapular eruption with surrounding pallor in the neck and trunk associated with ulcers on the palate. What is the probable diagnosis, and how will you manage this infant?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Sixth Disease/Roseola infantum subitum/ Exanthema subitum, which is a self-limiting exanthematous fever commonly seen in children under 2 years of age. It is managed conservatively.

Sixth disease is caused by HHV-6 and manifests in children under 2 years of age with peak incidence from 6-9 months. Clinical features include:

  • High fever for 3-5 days, often up to 40 degrees Celsius
  • High fevers may precipitate febrile seizures in about 13% of patients
  • Morbilliform maculopapular rash that occurs once fever subsides, typically starting in the neck and trunk and spreading to arms, face, and legs. It has surrounding pallor and is rarely vesicular.
  • Hematuria and periorbital edema
  • Irritability 
  • Inflammed tympanic membrane
  • Ulcers of palate and uvula
  • Cervical and occipital lymphadenopathy

Most of the time, all symptoms resolve on their own with supportive care. Febrile seizures are managed with counselling and antipyretics. Rarely complications like encephalitis have been reported. In severe disease, antivirals like ganciclovir may be given. The disease is known to reactivate in immunosuppression.

Option A and C: Fifth disease or erythema infectiosum is an exanthematous fever caused by Parvovirus B19 in children, which is also self-limiting and generally requires supportive care only. Its symptoms include a classical slapped cheek rash, which can evolve into a papular purpuric glove and stocking syndrome. There is usually no prodrome or minimal symptoms before abrupt onset of rash. The virus is known to cause transient myelosuppression and anemia. In very severe disease, IVIG has been tried in some cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is a recently FDA-approved monoclonal antibody for metastatic or non resectable esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC)?
questions.solution:
Tislelizumab is the recently approved monoclonal antibody (FDA 2024) for metastatic or unresectable esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC).

Tislelizumab is a programmed death receptor-1 (PD-1) blocking antibody approved for use in patients who have undergone prior systemic chemotherapy that did not include a PD- (L)1 inhibitor. It is administered as an intravenous infusion once every three weeks. Adverse effects include Infusion reactions, pneumonitis, colitis, and hepatitis.

PD-1 and PD-L1 inhibitors are called Immune checkpoint inhibitors. The interaction of the programmed death-ligand 1 (PDL-1) with its receptor, programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1), is involved in the suppression of the immune system. This concept is manipulated in the treatment of cancers, and the following drugs have been approved for the same 

Antibodies to PD-1 :  

  • Cemiplimab
  • Dostarlimab
  • Nivolumab
  • Pembrolizumab

Antibodies to PD-L1:

  • Atezolizumab
  • Avelumab
  • Durvalumab
  • Other Options:

Option A: Toripalimab is approved for recurrent or metastatic nasopharyngeal carcinoma. 

Option C: Bimekizumab is approved for moderate to severe psoriasis in adults who are candidates for systemic therapy or phototherapy

Option D: Talquetamab is approved for relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma who have received at least 4 prior therapies.

questions.text: Following a term Caesarean delivery, a newborn presents with fast breathing. On examination, respiratory rate is 68/min and the chest is clear. A chest X-ray shows fluid in the intralobar fissures and perihilar pulmonary vascular markings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most prominent diagnosis in a newborn with tachypnea, clear chest, and given X-ray findings of intralobar fluid and perihilar pulmonary vascular markings is transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN).

TTN is a self-limited cause of tachypnea associated with delayed absorption of fetal lung fluid. It is characterized by early-onset tachypnea that is relieved by minimal oxygen supplementation (<40%). There maybe retractions, expiratory grunting, or cyanosis which also resolves with oxygen. On examination, the chest is clear without crackles or wheeze.

The chest X-ray shows prominent pulmonary vascular markings, fluid in the intralobar fissures, and, rarely, small pleural effusions.

Most infants recover usually within 3 days with supportive care.

Other options:

Option A: Hyaline membrane disease- Radiographic findings like hypoaeration, diffuse reticulo-granular pattern, and air bronchograms will be seen.

Option B: Meconium aspiration syndrome occurs in term or post-term infants. The infants are meconium-stained and may be depressed and require resuscitation at birth; The typical chest radiograph is characterized by patchy infiltrates, coarse streaking of both lung fields, and hyperinflation.

Option D: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia presents with respiratory distress, scaphoid abdomen, and bowel sounds heard in the chest wall.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with a history of persistent fever, fatigue, pallor, easy bruising, and gum bleeding. On examination, he has hepatosplenomegaly. Blood tests show severe anemia, thrombocytopenia, elevated white blood cell count, and peripheral blood smear is shown below. Immunohistochemistry: CD33+, MPO+, TdT-.  What is the most appropriate induction therapy regimen for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is highly suggestive of bone marrow failure. The image shows myeloblasts, immature white blood cells typically seen in Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML). Standard induction therapy for AML is Cytarabine and Anthracycline.

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) is the clonal proliferation of myeloid precursor cells in the bone marrow. This leads to impaired hematopoiesis and bone marrow failure, resulting in anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis with dysfunctional white blood cells. AML is most commonly seen in patients above 60 years of age and can present with fatigue, infections, bleeding tendencies, and hepatosplenomegaly due to bone marrow failure.

AML is classified based on genetic mutations and morphological features. The French-American-British (FAB) classification historically divided AML into subtypes (M0-M7) based on cell lineage, while the WHO classification incorporates genetic abnormalities like t(8;21), inv(16), and FLT3 mutations.

A unique subtype, Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APML, AML-M3), with t(15;17), presents as a medical emergency with DIC. Due to its sensitivity to differentiation therapy, it is treated with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA).

Diagnosis is confirmed by peripheral blood smear (PBS) showing myeloblasts, bone marrow biopsy reveals hypercellularity with ≥20% blasts, and immunophenotyping confirms myeloid lineage with markers like MPO (Myeloid Peroxidase)+ and CD33+, distinguishing them from lymphoid leukemias. The TdT (Terminal Deoxynucleotidyl Transferase) test is a biochemical marker used to diagnose leukemias.

  • TdT positive indicates a lymphoid origin of the leukemia, making it characteristic of ALL.
  • TdT negative (as in this patient) suggests the leukemia is not lymphoid in origin, which means it is more likely to be Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML).

 Treatment includes induction chemotherapy with Cytarabine and Anthracycline ("7+3" regimen)

  • Cytarabine (7 days, continuous IV infusion)
  • Anthracycline (Daunorubicin or Idarubicin for 3 days, IV push)

Other Options:

Option B: CHOP (Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Prednisolone) is used to treat Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma (NHL)

Option C: Imatinib is a first-generation tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI). It is used in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

Option D: Vincristine and prednisolone are used during the induction phase of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

questions.text: Which of the following hypolipidemic drugs is FDA-approved as an adjunct therapy for type 2 diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Colesevelam is a bile acid-binding resin that has been FDA-approved as an adjunct therapy for type 2 diabetes mellitus. 

Colesevelam binds bile acids in the intestine, preventing their enterohepatic circulation. This also reduces hepatic cholesterol, which increases the hepatic conversion of cholesterol to bile acids. Decreased intestinal cholesterol delivery stimulates hepatic LDL receptor expression and cholesterol biosynthesis, enhancing LDL clearance from the plasma.

For a given dosage, the maximum reduction in LDL is attained in 1-2 weeks. Because they are not absorbed systematically, they are the safest hypolipidemic drugs. They are often used to lower LDL in cases of statin intolerance or as a second-line treatment alongside statins. Bile acid resins can increase triglyceride levels and should be used cautiously in patients with hypertriglyceridemia.

Adverse effects include dyspepsia, bloating, constipation, and, rarely, hyperchloremic acidosis. They can affect the absorption of other drugs. Hence, the timing of dosage needs to be monitored.

Other Options:

Option A: Ezetimibe is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor that inhibits NPC1L1 transport protein. It is not FDA-approved for type 2 diabetes mellitus treatment.

Option C: Gemfibrozil activates peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-alpha (PPAR-α), increasing lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity and enhancing triglyceride breakdown. It is not FDA-approved for type 2 diabetes mellitus treatment.

Option D: Niacin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase in adipose tissue, reducing free fatty acids (FFA) release into circulation. It is rarely used in diabetic patients as it is associated with insulin resistance.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primi has come for an antenatal ultrasound examination. The sonographic image appears as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the characteristic lemon sign on ultrasound which is seen in neural tube defects.

Signs of neural tube defect on targeted sonography:

  • Small biparietal diameter
  • Ventriculomegaly
  • Frontal bone scalloping or the lemon sign
  • Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna known as banana sign.

Other options:

  • Normal gestational sac shows double decidual sac. The empty head red arrow shows decidua and the filled head red arrow shows yolk sac
  • Intrauterine death shows spalding sign
  • Duodenal atresia shows double bubble sign

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who was operated on for percutaneous nephrolithotomy under spinal anesthesia suddenly became unresponsive in the recovery room. On examination, pulse rate is 40 bpm, BP is 70/40 mmHg and SpO2 is 90%. Which of the following drugs is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of symptomatic bradycardia with hypotension, and altered mental status, following spinal anaesthesia. So, the most appropriate treatment for this patient is Atropine 1 mg bolus (According to the ACLS bradycardia algorithm).

Neuraxial blocks cause hypotension and bradycardia due to sympathetic blockade (T1-L1), leading to venous pooling, reduced cardiac output, and unopposed vagal tone. Higher block levels, particularly T1-T4 blockade, exacerbate these effects by inhibiting cardio-acceleratory sympathetic fibers, increasing the risk of profound hypotension and bradycardia.

According to the ACLS bradycardia algorithm, bradycardia is defined as a heart rate < 50 bpm. Immediate identification of the cause of bradycardia must be done. Symptomatic patients with the following are treated for persistent bradycardia using Atropine 1 mg bolus:

  • Hypotension
  • Acutely altered mental status
  • Signs of shock
  • Ischaemic chest discomfort
  • Acute heart failure

Atropine can be repeated every 3-5 min if there is persistent bradycardia for a maximum of 3 mg. If atropine is ineffective, the following can be done:

  • Transcutaneous pacing
  • Dopamine infusion at 5-20 mcg/kg/min
  • Epinephrine infusion at 2-10 mcg/min

Defibrillation followed by Epinephrine 1 mg 3-5 min is the treatment for Ventricular Fibrillation or Pulseless Ventricular Tachycardia in ACLS - adult cardiac arrest algorithm.

Related Pearl: Adult Bradycardia with Pulse Algorithm

When a patient is in bradyarrhythmia typically with a heart rate of <50 bpm the initial intervention consists of identifying and treating the underlying cause. This includes: 

  • Maintaining a patent airway and assisting breathing as necessary
  • Administering oxygen if hypoxemic
  • Attaching cardiac monitor to identify rhythm; monitor blood pressure and oximetry
  • IV access
  • 12-Lead ECG

questions.text: The dose-response curve of substrate Y is shown below with the green curve. The pink curve demonstrates the effect of drug X on substrate Y.  Which of the following may best represent 'X' and 'Y' in the image below?

choices.text: X - Lead , Y - δ-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase
X - Statin , Y - HMG CoA reductase

questions.solution:
The graph in the question above shows competitive irreversible inhibition. The drug 'X' is Disulfuram, and its substrate 'Y' is Aldehyde dehydrogenase.

The graph shown in the image is a Dose-Response Curve. It is interpreted using Km (Michaelis constant), which represents the substrate concentration at which the reaction rate (or transport rate) is half of the maximum rate (Vmax). 

In competitive irreversible inhibition, the antagonist binds permanently to the active site. Unlike reversible inhibitors, inhibition cannot be reversed by increasing agonist concentration. The curve shifts downward because the maximum transport rate (Vmax) decreases (fewer active receptors are available). 

Disulfiram competes with aldehyde dehydrogenase (ALDH) for the active site and then forms a covalent bond, permanently inactivating the enzyme. This leads to the accumulation of acetaldehyde, which causes adverse effects like flushing and nausea upon alcohol consumption. Disulfiram acts as a competitive irreversible inhibitor by first binding reversibly and then modifying the enzyme irreversibly.

Other options:

Option A: Lithium and Inositol Monophosphatase (IMPase) are examples of uncompetitive inhibition. This lowers both Km and Vmax. Even at high substrate levels, the inhibition remains.

Option B: Lead binds allosterically (binds to the adjacent site, not the catalytic site) to δ-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase, disrupting heme synthesis. It is an example of non-competitive antagonism. Vmax decreases while Km remains unchanged (agonist binding affinity is unaffected).

Option D: Statins show competitive reversible inhibition of HMG-CoA reductase. Since inhibition is reversible, increasing the substrate (HMG-CoA) can reduce the effect of the inhibitor. The curve shifts rightward (higher Km), meaning more agonist is needed to reach the same effect. Vmax remains unchanged since a high enough agonist concentration can outcompete the inhibitor.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures is affected in Huntington chorea?
questions.solution:
The structure affected in Huntington's chorea is the head of caudate, marked as 4 in the given image. 

In Huntington's disease, progressive atrophy of the head of the caudate nucleus can be visualized on MRI.

Huntington's disease (HD), also known as Huntington chorea, is a progressive, fatal, autosomal dominant disorder characterized by an abnormal expansion of the trinucleotide CAG in the Huntington gene on chromosome 4.

Huntington's disease is characterized by rapid, nonpatterned, semi-purposeful, involuntary choreiform movements along with dysarthria, gait disturbance, behavioural disturbance, and cognitive impairment with dementia. The disease predominantly affects the striatum but progresses to involve the cerebral cortex and other brain regions. More diffuse cortical atrophy can be seen in the middle and late stages of the disease. Reduced metabolic activity in the caudate nucleus and putamen and reduced brain metabolites on MR spectroscopy can be seen.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida, at 34 weeks of gestation, who is on her course of steroids, is being posted for elective cesarean section in 7 days. Her haemoglobin is 9 g/dL. What is the best option for treating her anaemia?
questions.solution:
Ferric carboxymaltose intravenous injection is the best treatment option since the time available till elective cesarean section is 7 days, and it requires a lesser number of dosages and a shorter infusion time.

In the given clinical scenario, the patient has haemoglobin of 9 mg/dl, which means she has moderate anaemia and is 34 weeks pregnant, with delivery scheduled in seven days. Here, Ferric carboxymaltose IV is administered for the anticipated acute blood loss due to a Cesarean section since it requires a lesser number of dosages and a shorter infusion time, and moreover, it is a case of moderate anemia, a blood transfusion is not indicated. 

The expected rise in hemoglobin concentration after intravenous parenteral therapy is 0.7 to 1 g/100 mL/week even though the maximum hemoglobin response does not appear before 4 to 9 weeks, an elevated reticulocyte count notes the hematological response. 

The indications of parenteral iron therapy are

  • Contraindications to oral therapy, such as malabsorption
  • The patient is not cooperative in taking oral iron.
  • Cases seen for the first time during the last 8–10 weeks with severe anemia.

Of the given options, iron sucrose, iron dextran, and ferric carboxymaltose are parenteral forms of iron therapy.

Other options:-

Option A: Iron sucrose intravenous injection contains 100 mg/dose. It requires a daily dosage of 10 days.

Option C: Blood transfusion is indicated in severe anemia>36 weeks of gestation. Disadvantages of blood transfusion include premature labor, transfusion reactions, and increased chances of heart failure.

Option D: Iron dextran intramuscular injection contains 50 mg/mL. It requires multiple daily injections till the target amount is reached.

questions.text: A patient who believes that aliens are trying to abduct him and he has been hearing them for the past 6 months is bought to the psychiatric outpatient department.  He also exhibits  reduced emotional expression. Which of the following points to a poor prognosis in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with auditory hallucinations and reduced emotional expression points to a diagnosis of schizophrenia. The presence of anhedonia points to a poor prognosis in this condition.

Schizophrenia is a disorder characterized by delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, negative symptoms, and catatonic behavior.

The symptoms are mainly divided into negative or positive symptoms. Negative symptoms are diminished emotional expression, avolition, anhedonia, alogia, and asociality. Examples of positive symptoms include hallucinations and delusions. 

There are several factors that affect the prognosis of schizophrenia:

Good prognosis Bad prognosis
Late/acute onset Early/insidious onset
Mood disorder symptoms Withdrawn, autistic behavior
Family history of mood disorders  Family history of schizophrenia
Positive symptoms Negative symptoms
Married Single, divorced or widowed
  Neurological signs and symptoms
  Many relapses

Dopamine excess is believed to play an important role in the development of the disease. A genetic component is also implicated. It is equally seen in males and females. 

Some cases may require short stays at the hospital either for patient safety or for stabilization of medications. Anti-psychotics are the mainstay of treatment. They mainly act by antagonizing the postsynaptic dopamine receptors in the brain. Psychosocial therapy also plays an important role and can augment clinical improvement.

questions.text: A medical officer is conducting a case-control study and employs matching to select controls similar to the cases. Which of the following types of bias is likely to be reduced as a result?
questions.solution:
Matching controls to be similar to the cases is likely to reduce confounding bias or bias due to confounding factors.

A confounding factor is one that is related to both exposure and disease and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. Irrespective of being associated with the exposure under study, the confounding factor might itself serve as a risk factor for the disease. Hence, the elimination of these confounding factors is essential before carrying out a case-control study. 

Matching, which is usually done in analytical studies (such as a case-control study), is the process where the participants in two groups (cases and controls in this case) are matched based on factors that are known to influence the outcome of disease (such as age, gender, race, etc.) to stop the potential confounders from distorting the results.

Other strategies to eliminate confounding factors include randomization, stratified randomization, and restriction.

Other options:
Option A - Recall bias in case-control studies occurs because history recollection is better in the case group as they have a stronger exposure than the control group. This bias can be reduced by decreasing the recall period as much as possible.

Option C - Selection bias is a type of sampling bias that occurs because of the nonrandom allocation of subjects such that the study population is not representative of the target population. The best way to reduce this is by randomization to create groups with similar distributions of known and unknown variables. 

Option D - Interviewer bias is a type of bias that occurs because the interviewer is aware of the case group and the hypothesis being tested, which can influence interviews and analysis. This can be reduced by blinding to reduce their influence on interviews and interpretation of outcomes.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought in by her mother. On examination, the child appears emaciated and her feet and ankles show an extensive, pruritic maculopapular rash. Blood examination reveals a hemoglobin of 6 g/dL and the peripheral blood smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia. Identify the egg belonging to the causative organism.
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of chronic hookworm infection (caused by A. duodenale or N. americanus) and image 4 shows the hookworm egg.

Features of the hookworm egg:

  • Oval/ elliptical with a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane.
  • Not bile stained.
  • Floats in a saturated salt solution.
  • Contains a segmented ovum, usually with 4-8 blastomeres when passed in the faeces.
  • A clear space lies between the segmented ovum and the shell.

Filariform larvae penetrate the skin when a person walks barefoot on soil containing larvae, causing a pruritic maculopapular rash at the site of entry (Ground itch). Common sites of entry include the skin between the toes, the dorsum of the foot and the medial part of the sole. It can occasionally lead to a creeping eruption along the path traversed by the larvae, similar to cutaneous larva migrans.

The larvae are then carried in the venous circulation to the heart and lungs, where they may cause mild transient pneumonitis or bronchitis. They migrate up the respiratory tract to the pharynx, are swallowed, and reach the small intestine producing epigastric pain, dyspepsia, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. 

A. duodenale or N. americanus ingest blood, secrete anticoagulants, and interfere with the absorption of iron, B12, and folic acid. This leads to iron deficiency anemia and protein-energy malnutrition resulting from blood loss. 

Diagnosis:

  • Demonstration of characteristic hookworm eggs in feces by direct wet microscopy. The modified Kato-Katz smear technique is useful for the quantitative estimation of eggs in the stool. 20 eggs or more are associated with anemia.
  • Stool culture: Harada-Mori method of stool culture demonstrates filariform larvae which differentiate A. duodenale and N. americanus.
  • Lab investigations characteristically show hypochromic microcytic anaemia, occasionally with eosinophilia or hypoalbuminemia.

Treatment:

  • Anthelmintic drugs- albendazole and mebendazole.
  • Iron replacement.
  • Nutritional support.

Other options:

Option A: Eggs of Ascaris can be fertilized or unfertilized. Unfertilized eggs have a thinner shell, containing a small atrophied ovum with a mass of disorganized granules. Fertilized eggs are always bile-stained, are usually surrounded by a 3 layer membrane, and contain a large unsegmented ovum. Infection is by swallowing fertilized eggs that contain the larvae.

Option B: Eggs of Strongyloides hatch out to rhabditiform larva as soon as they are laid, and are therefore not seen in the stool. Infection occurs when larvae penetrate the skin while walking, or by autoinfection.

Option C: Eggs of Enterobius are colourless, but have a characteristic plano-convex shape, with a double-layered membrane, and contain a tadpole-shaped embryo. Swallowing eggs by autoinfection or contaminated fingers is the mode of infection.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology
