questions.text: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with focal neurological deficits, including unilateral weakness and slurred speech. Her medical history includes hypertension and diabetes mellitus. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain is performed, as shown below. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation, along with the CT findings of small, hypodense lesions, suggest lacunar infarcts.

Lacunar infarcts are small vessel strokes caused by the occlusion of deep penetrating arteries, commonly due to hypertension and lipohyalinosis. These infarcts typically affect subcortical structures such as the basal ganglia, thalamus, and internal capsule, leading to pure motor, sensory, or ataxic hemiparesis syndromes.

On CT imaging, lacunar infarcts appear as small, hypodense lesions in deep brain regions.

The primary goal in lacunar stroke treatment is to ensure blood pressure control, antiplatelet therapy, and assess tPA eligibility. If no intracerebral bleeding is present, IV thrombolysis is given within 4.5 hours, with a BP target of <185/110 mm Hg. For lacunar infarcts outside the tPA window, dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) is started within 24 hours and continued for 21 days.

Other Options:

Option A: Acute subdural hemorrhage, on CT, shows a crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion that crosses the suture lines.

Option B: Normal pressure hydrocephalus presents with a characteristic clinical triad of ataxia in the form of wide-based gait (magnetic gait), urinary incontinence, and dementia. A characteristic MRI of NPH is given below, showing dilated lateral ventricles that are out of proportion to sulcal deepening: 

Option D: Intracranial hemorrhage, on CT, presents as a rapidly expanding hyperdense lesion that causes a midline shift.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the office due to poor weight gain and frequent urination. He is found to have glucosuria on urine analysis. Additional serum laboratory values reveal hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following structure /function combinations is likely defective in this patient?

choices.text: Proximal convoluted tubule  -  Reabsorption of ammonia
Thick ascending loop of Henle - Reabsorption  of sodium chloride
Distal convoluted tubule - Reabsorption of sodium chloride
Proximal convoluted tubule - Reabsorption of bicarbonate

questions.solution:
Poor weight gain and frequent urination in a 2-year-old with hypophosphatemia and hypokalemia with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis suggest Fanconi syndrome. In Fanconi syndrome, there is a defect in the reabsorption of bicarbonate in the Proximal Convoluted Tubule.

Normally, the proximal convoluted tubule is responsible for bicarbonate reabsorption in addition to amino acids, glucose, phosphate, and water. Impaired bicarbonate reabsorption can occur as an isolated defect (Renal tubular acidosis type 2) or as a part of proximal tubular dysfunction (Fanconi syndrome). 

Fanconi syndrome is characterized by Renal tubular acidosis type 2 (proximal type), low-molecular-weight proteinuria, hypophosphatemia glycosuria, phosphaturia, and aminoaciduria. The biochemical abnormalities seen in Fanconi syndrome are hyperchloremic hypokalemic metabolic acidosis.

Other Options:

Option A: Hypoaldosteronism or aldosterone resistance, seen in RTA type 4, causing hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis. Hyperkalemia impairs ammonia genesis in the proximal tubule --> reduces the availability of NH3 to buffer urinary hydrogen ions and decreases hydrogen ion excretion in urine.

Option B: Barter syndrome is caused by a defect in the sodium-potassium 2 chloride transporter in a thick ascending loop of Henle, which impairs sodium chloride reabsorption.

Option C: Gitelmann syndrome is caused by a defect in the sodium chloride cotransporter in the Distal convoluted tubule, which impairs sodium chloride reabsorption.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: A patient complains of severe anxiety and sweating during work presentations, worsening over the past 1 year and impacting his work. He does not have similar symptoms in other situations. Which treatment option is most suitable?
questions.solution:
This patient complaining of severe anxiety before giving presentations is likely suffering from performance anxiety and is managed by taking propranolol shortly before the triggering situation.

Performance anxiety is a type of social anxiety that is restricted to performing or speaking in public. It is characterised by marked fear or anxiety of possible scrutiny by others. These situations are avoided or endured with intense fear or anxiety. The anxiety is persistent, causing impairment in functioning and typically lasts for 6 months or more.

The treatment of performance anxiety involves the use of beta-adrenergic receptor antagonists such as propranolol or atenolol shortly before exposure to a phobic stimulus. Another option is a relatively short or intermediate-acting benzodiazepine, such as lorazepam or alprazolam. Cognitive, behavioral, and exposure techniques are also useful.

Other options : 

Option B: Buspirone is an anxiolytic medication used for long-term management of general anxiety disorder. The therapeutic action of buspirone is slow and not appropriate for performance anxiety. 

Option C: Diazepam is a long-acting benzodiazepine. Short or intermediate-acting benzodiazepines are indicated for performance anxiety.

Option D: Sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, which is not indicated to manage performance anxiety.

questions.text: A 52-year-old alcoholic and a chronic smoker presents with a painless decrease in vision for the last 1 month. He undergoes visual field testing. The finding on the perimetry chart shown below is seen in both his eyes. The patient is suffering from which disease?
questions.solution:
The above perimetry chart reveals the loss of central vision. It can occur due to Nutritional optic neuropathy.

The dotted line in the perimetry chart represents the visual field of the eye and the black area represents vision loss.

Symptoms of Nutritional optic neuropathy include:

  • Gradual, painless loss of central vision.
  • Bilateral visual impairment.
  • Dyschromatopsia (difficulty distinguishing colors, especially red-green).

Management includes smoking cessation and nutritional supplementation (vitamin B12, folate, and thiamine).

Other Options:

Option A: Retinitis Pigmentosa is characterized by loss of peripheral vision. Central vision is preserved. Central vision may eventually be lost after many years.

Option B: Macular fibers are very resistant to glaucomatous changes. So, the central vision is retained till the later stages of glaucoma.

Option C: CRAO usually presents with sudden painless loss of vision occurring over seconds (not months). Patients may give history of transient visual loss (amaurosis fugax) in the past.

Related Pearl: Visual field Defects in Open-Angle Glaucoma

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with low-grade fever, pain, and swelling over the right thigh. On examination, a mass was noted over the diaphysis of the femur. Cytogenetic analysis showed translocation (11:22). The histopathology image is given below. Identify the most likely X-ray feature of this condition:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the histopathology image showing sheaths of small round cells that are PAS-positive are suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma. Onion peel appearance is the most likely X-ray feature of this condition.

Ewing's sarcoma is a highly malignant tumor that occurs mainly in the age group between 10-20 years. The most common site is the diaphysis of long bones. Karyotyping shows a translocation (11:22). 

The gross specimen shows a tumor involving the whole medullary cavity. The bone gets expanded, the periosteum gets elevated and subperiosteal new bone formation occurs in layers.

Microscopically, solid sheaths of small round cells with PAS-positive magenta pink colored cytoplasm are seen. The cells show PAS positivity due to the presence of large amounts of cytoplasmic glycogen. This is an important feature for the differential diagnosis of Ewing's with other small round cell tumors. 

The clinical features include persistent pain, swelling over the area and fever. On X-ray, a lytic lesion in the medullary area on the diaphysis of long bones will be seen. It also shows cortical destruction along with new bone formation. This is called onion peel appearance. 

It is a highly radiosensitive tumor. Radiotherapy for control of local tumor and chemotherapy with vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and adriamycin is considered.

Other options: 

Option A: Sunray appearance is seen in osteosarcoma. It occurs predominantly in the age group of 15- 25 years. The common sites are the metaphysis of the lower end of the femur and the upper end of the tibia.

Option C: Soap bubble appearance is seen in osteoclastoma. It occurs predominantly in the age group of 20-40 years. The common sites are epiphysis of the lower end of the femur, the upper end of the tibia, lower end of the radius.

Option D: Mottled calcification is seen in chondrosarcoma.it occurs predominantly in the age group of 30 - 60 years. The common sites are anywhere in the flat bones and upper end of the femur.

questions.text: A car driver hit his right knee on the dashboard on the sudden application of the brake during a motor vehicle collision. He complains of pain and swelling in the right knee. On examination, there is an excessive backward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur on gently pulling the upper end of the tibia. However, the forward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur appears normal. What is the structure most likely to be injured?

choices.text: Both anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a direct anterior blow to the knees such as dashboard injury and excessive backward movement in the posterior drawer test is suggestive of posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury.

The initial symptoms are very similar to an ACL (anterior cruciate ligament) injury like the immediate swelling. On performing the posterior drawer test, there would be excessive backward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur. The majority of patients with an isolated PCL injury will return to a high level of function with just appropriate quadriceps rehabilitation, without the need for surgical intervention.

On performing the anterior drawer test, the normal forward gliding movement of the tibia in relation to femoral condyles is suggestive of apparently normal anterior cruciate ligaments. 

Dashboard injury can also lead to

  • Posterior hip dislocation
  • Acetabular fracture
  • Patellar fracture
  • Fracture of neck of the femur
  • The shaft of femur fracture
  • Posterior cruciate ligament injury

The image below is an MRI of the knee joint, and the arrow shows the posterior cruciate ligament.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding management of acute urinary retention?

choices.text: Coude catheterization is preferred in men with benign prostatic hyperplasia
The tip of the coude catheter should always point to 12 o’clock when inserted
Suprapubic tube should not be inserted due to the risk of bowel injury
If retention is caused due to hematuria, continuous bladder irrigation is done

questions.solution:
Suprapubic tube insertion is one of the modalities in the management of acute urinary retention. The risk of bowel injury is very low as the bladder is fully distended due to the retention of urine.

Acute urinary retention may be seen in men and women but commonly occurs in men with benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Other causes of acute urinary retention include:

  • Diabetic neuropathy
  • Urethral stricture
  • Parkinson’s disease
  • Multiple sclerosis

Management: Acute urinary retention is managed by placing a urinary catheter as early as possible. In patients with BPH, a specialised catheter called coude catheter may be placed. It is a curved catheter and is useful in passing the catheter through the angulation in the prostatic urethra. Once the curved tip enters the bladder, it is maintained at the 12’O o'clock position.

If catheter placement is not successful:

  • If there is a urethral stricture, it is dilated with a cystoscope, guide wires and urethral dilators and a council tip catheter is inserted. Or
  • A suprapubic catheter may be inserted.

If the retention is caused by hematuria:

  • A large three-way catheter with an additional port for fluid inflow is inserted.
  • The fluid is infused, and continuous bladder irrigation is done to prevent clot formation.
  • Note that the fluid should be infused only under gravity, as infusion under high pressure may cause bladder rupture.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the angle shown in the picture?

choices.text: It is formed by the line of pull of quadriceps tendon & patellar tendon
The angle is greater in males
The angle is increased in genu valgum
It correlates with the risk of recurrent patella dislocation

questions.solution:
The angle shown in the figure is the “Q angle”. The angle is greater in females than in males.

Q angle is formed by the line of pull of the quadriceps & the patellar tendon, the intersection  & the centre of the patella. Anatomical landmarks are the line joining ASIS (anterior superior iliac spine) to the patella & a line from the centre of the tibial tuberosity to the centre of the patella.

The normal value in males is 8-10 degrees and in females is 10-20 degrees. Increased Q angle is seen in :

  • Chondromalacia patella
  • Genu valgum
  • External tibial torsion
  • Tight lateral retinaculum
  • It predisposes to recurrent dislocations of the patella

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given dose-response curve (DRC)?

choices.text: Drug D is the least potent
Drug B is the most efficacious
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D
Drug  B is the least potent

questions.solution:
The greater the shift of the curve towards the left, the more potent the drug is. Hence, drug D is the least potent.

Potency: It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response. The greater the shift of the curve towards the left side, the higher is potency of the drug. This is because the desired response is being achieved at a lower drug dose.

Hence, in the given drug response curve, drug B is the most potent, and drug D is the least potent.

Efficacy: It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug and is determined by the peak of the curve. Hence, in the given drug response curve, drug B has the least efficacy, and drugs A, C, and D are equally efficacious.

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte disturbances are noticed following the administration of low molecular weight heparin?
questions.solution:
Low molecular weight heparins (LMWH) can cause hyperkalemia.

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), such as enoxaparin and dalteparin, is an anticoagulant that primarily inhibits factor Xa, with less impact on thrombin (factor IIa) than unfractionated heparin. It has a more predictable pharmacokinetic profile and a longer half-life. It does not require routine monitoring of coagulation parameters like activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), which makes it convenient for outpatient management. LMWH is commonly used for prophylaxis and treatment of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), and in certain cardiovascular conditions such as acute coronary syndrome.

LMWH is also the preferred choice during pregnancy for the prevention and treatment of thromboembolic events because it does not cross the placenta. Although generally well-tolerated, it can lead to complications such as bleeding, thrombocytopenia, hyperkalemia due to the suppression of aldosterone (which reduces potassium excretion in the kidney), and hyponatremia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes for evaluation of recurrent fetal losses. She has had 4 spontaneous abortions all at <10 weeks of gestational age. She also has a history of recurrent deep venous thromboses. In the past year, she has had 5 events. Her physical exam is unremarkable. Diagnosis is made based on lab investigations and she is started on anticoagulation. Which of the following is not useful in diagnosing this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of Antiphospholipid syndrome. All the above-mentioned antibodies are useful for the diagnosis of Antiphospholipid syndrome except Anti ds DNA antibodies.

The diagnostic criteria for antiphospholipid antibody syndrome are as follows:

Clinical criteria:

Obstetric

  • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks
  • One or more deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks
  • At least one preterm birth before 34 weeks of gestation because of eclampsia, severe preeclampsia, or placental insufficiency

Vascular: One or more episodes of arterial, venous, or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organ.

Laboratory criteria:

  • Presence of lupus anticoagulant
  • Presence of IgG or IgM anti-cardiolipin antibodies
  • Presence of IgG or IgM anti-beta-2 glycoprotein I antibodies

At least one clinical and one laboratory criterion has to be present for a diagnosis to be made.

Management: Women are treated with low-dose aspirin (50 mg/day) and heparin (5,000 units SC twice daily) for up to 34 weeks. Unfractionated heparin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) are equally effective and safe.

Note: Fetal loss in APLA is due to fetal hypoxia.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not commonly associated with hereditary angioedema?
questions.solution:
Pruritus is not associated with the lesions associated with hereditary angioedema (HA).

Hereditary angioedema is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by a deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitors. C1 esterase inhibitors usually target proteases like C1r and C1s, factor XII and the kallikrein system. Therefore, their deficiency leads to unregulated activation of kallikrein, leading to increased bradykinin.

Clinical features include painful swelling of the skin and mucosal surfaces, nausea, vomiting, gastric colic and diarrhea, which may be aggravated after minor trauma or emotional stress. The condition can be treated by giving C1 inhibitor concentrates from human plasma. 

The main inflammatory mediator responsible for these symptoms is bradykinin. Bradykinin is an inflammatory mediator formed by the cleavage of kininogen, in the presence of the enzyme kallikrein. Bradykinin has the following effects:

  • Increases vascular permeability
  • Causes contraction of smooth muscle
  • Dilates the blood vessel 
  • Mediates pain

questions.text: A  woman presents with a 6-month history of cough, dyspnea, and fatigue. Investigations reveal hypercalcemia. She has hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray. Which of the following parameters are likely to be elevated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above symptoms, along with hypercalcemia and chest X-ray findings raise suspicion for Sarcoidosis. ACE levels are elevated in this condition as sarcoid granulomas secrete it.

Significant elevation of ACE levels is seen in Sarcoidosis, Silicosis, Leprosy, Gaucher’s disease, Hyperthyroidism and Disseminated granulomatous infections such as miliary tuberculosis.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous inflammatory condition with multisystem involvement. The most common organs affected are the lungs, liver, eye, and skin. The most widely accepted etiological hypothesis is an inflammatory response to an infectious or non-infectious trigger in a susceptible host.

Two syndromes are associated with the condition.

  • Lofgren's syndrome is characterized by erythema nodosum and hilar adenopathy. Periarticular arthritis can also be seen.
  • Mikulicz syndrome characterised by bilateral involvement of parotid, submaxillary, and sublingual glands. 

The hallmarks of sarcoidosis include:

  • B/L hilar lymphadenopathy
  • Non-caseating granulomas
  • Lupus pernio
  • Erythema nodosum (acute sarcoidosis)

Lupus pernio is seen in cutaneous sarcoidosis and presents as infiltrated erythematoviolaceous plaques involving the nose, cheeks, ears, lips, forehead, and fingers. On the cheeks, telangiectasia is characteristic. It is usually painless. As it does not ulcerate, it is not as mutilating as lupus vulgaris.

Diagnosis may be established based on clinical features and biopsy findings. Chest X-ray findings include:

  • The parenchymal infiltrates are mostly seen in the upper lobe and appear as diffuse reticular infiltrates.
  • Garland triad is a lymph node enlargement pattern seen on the chest radiographs in sarcoidosis.
  • It involves the right paratracheal nodes, right hilar nodes, and left hilar nodes. It is also known as the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign.
  • Gallium-67 scan:
    • Panda sign- It is due to bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands in sarcoidosis, superimposed on the normal uptake in the nasopharyngeal mucosa.
    • Lambda sign- It is seen in thoracic sarcoidosis. Bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes are typically involved which can resemble the lambda symbol (λ).
  • Elevated serum ACE levels: Granulomas in sarcoidosis are known to produce ACE.
  • Hypercalcemia may be seen, due to increased synthesis of calcitriol – 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D, by alveolar macrophages. More commonly, there may be hypercalciuria, which can lead to nephrocalcinosis.
  • Increased CD4/CD8 ratio of these increased lymphocytes in the BAL fluid. A ratio of >3.5 is strongly supportive of sarcoidosis.
  • Bronchoscopy shows the typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa.
  • Pulmonary function test shows a restrictive lung disease, with impaired gas exchange.

The mainstay of treatment is corticosteroids. Systemic therapy is indicated if multiple organs are affected. Immunosuppressants such as mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine, and infliximab can be used in patients who are refractory to steroids. 

Other options: 

Option B: Serum amylase levels are elevated in conditions that affect the pancreas or salivary glands, such as pancreatitis, cancer, sialolithiasis or in the case of Mickulicz syndrome with involvement of the parotid glands.

Option C: Serum calcitonin levels are elevated in medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Option D: Serum PTH levels are elevated in primary hyperparathyroidism.

Related Pearl: Causes of miliary shadow in Chest X-ray

Miliary shadow refers to innumerable, small (1-4 mm) pulmonary nodules scattered throughout the lungs. It is seen in - 

  • Miliary tuberculosis
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Pneumoconiosis – coal workers pneumoconiosis and silicosis
  • Healed varicella

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the procedure shown below?

POG- Period of gestation

choices.text: Can be used in fetus with gestational age less than 34 weeks
Can be used in cases of fetal coagulopathy
Can be used for both vertex and face presentations
Flexion point is 3 cm in front of posterior fontanelle

questions.solution:
The above image shows a vacuum-assisted delivery. The flexion point is about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle. 

A vacuum extractor is an instrument used in operative vaginal delivery by creating a vacuum between it and the fetal scalp. During vacuum-assisted delivery, the suction cup is placed on the fetal head at a point near the occiput, called the flexion point. A flexion point is an imaginary point on the sagittal suture, located about  6 cm from the center of the anterior fontanel or about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle. The flexion point is closer to the posterior fontanelle.

Contraindications of vacuum delivery include:

  • Any presentation other than vertex (such as face/breech)
  • Preterm fetus (less than 34 weeks POG)
  • Suspected fetal coagulation disorder
  • Fetal macrosomia (more than 4 kg estimated weight)

Below is the image of vacuum extractor 

Traction should be abandoned if:

  • There is no decent of the presenting part with each pull
  • Delivery is not imminent after three pulls.

Under any circumstances, the traction should not exceed more than 30 minutes. 

An artificial caput succedaneum (chignon) is produced due to the sucking. It usually disappears within a few hours.

Vacuum delivery has reduced maternal pelvic floor injury, and it is the instrument of the choice in assisted delivery.

Vacuum-assisted vaginal deliveries may fail due to selection of incorrect cup size or accidental inclusion of maternal soft tissues within the cup or incorrect placement of the cup which results in malpresentation of the fetal head.

While in forceps deliveries, it is unlikely to detach from the fetal head and allows the fetal head for rotation. It can be used in premature fetuses and cause relatively less bleeding from the scalp. This makes forceps have a higher success rate as compared to vacuum-assisted delivery. 

Related Pearl: Vacuum delivery- indications and contraindications

  • VBAC

  • Preterm head
  • Face presentation

questions.text: A 40-year-old laborer from Bihar presents with a six-month history of recurrent fever, progressive weakness, and loss of appetite, along with abdominal distension for the past three months. On examination, he has pallor and massive splenomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal pancytopenia. Which of the following culture media is used for diagnosing the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's chronic febrile illness, massive splenomegaly, pancytopenia, and history of residence in Bihar strongly suggest visceral leishmaniasis (Kala-azar) caused by Leishmania donovani. The Novy-MacNeal-Nicolle (NNN) medium is used to diagnose his condition.

Leishmaniasis is a vector-borne disease transmitted by the Phlebotomus Sandfly. It is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh. 

Diagnosis of Leishmania is made by:

  • Demonstration of amastigotes in smears of tissue aspirates is the gold standard 
  • Rapid diagnostic test: The National Vector-Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) in India recommends the rK39 rapid diagnostic test.
  • Demonstrating LD bodies in buffy coat smear, bone marrow, lymph node, or splenic aspirate is confirmatory.
  • Culture using NNN medium or Schneider's liquid medium to demonstrate promastigotes.
  • Aldehyde test of Napier
  • Serological tests for diagnosis include the rapid dipstick test, direct agglutination test, ELISA, indirect fluorescent antibody test, and complement fixation test using the Witebsky, Klingenstein, and Kuhn (WKK) antigen.

Other options:

Option A: Boeck and Drbohlav medium is used for Entamoeba histolytica (intestinal amebiasis).

Option C: Diamond's medium is used for Trichomonas vaginalis (trichomoniasis).

Option D: Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris medium is used for Leptospira species (Leptospirosis).

questions.text: Park-Williams 8 strain used for toxin production belongs to which of the following bacteria?
questions.solution:
Park-Williams 8 strain belongs to Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

It is the standard strain universally used for the toxin production of corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Corynebacterium diphtheriae have been typed as intermedius, gravis and mitis. All strains of gravis and intermedius are toxic, while only about some of mitis strains are toxic. The toxins produced by all strains of the Corynebacterium diphtheria are qualitatively similar. 

Diphtheria toxin is a protein with a lethal dose of about 0.1mcg/kg. It has 2 subunits:

  • A-Active domain-responsible for action
  • B-Binding domain-trigger entry into host cell.

questions.text: Identify the correct statement about the device given below?

choices.text: It is an  implantable dialysis port used for frequent dialysis in chronic renal failure patient
Totally implantable venous access devices used to facilitate chemotherapy administration
Electro-convulsive therapy lead used for monitoring heart rate and rhythm during procedure
It is a gamma radiation quantifier probe used during radiotherapy

questions.solution:
The given image shows a chemo port. It is totally implantable venous access devices used to facilitate chemotherapy administration.

Internal jugular veins and subclavian veins are the commonly used venous access for port placement. These devices are usually retained over a period of 1 to 2 years or more after which the device is explanted.

questions.text:
A newly married couple both of whom are PKU carriers is worried about planning pregnancy. They ask you the odds of transmission of their genes to the offspring. Which of the following will aid in assessing the same?

PKU - Phenylketonuria
questions.solution:
Microsatellite markers are used in assessing the transmission of genes from parent to child. 

Since microsatellite markers are present throughout the human genome and have a high level of polymorphism, they are ideal for differentiating between 2 individuals and following the transmission of the marker from parents to offspring. Assays employing PCR(polymerase chain reaction) amplification of these markers are now routinely used for establishing paternity and criminal investigations. 

Phenylketonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a severe deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH), resulting in hyperphenylalaninemia.

Other options: 

Option A: Karyotyping is the study of chromosomes. It is used to detect chromosomal abnormalities such as aneuploidy and translocations.

Option B: Mutations affecting the length of DNA, like deletions and expansions, can be easily detected by PCR in amplicon length analysis.

Option D: Flow cytometry is a laser-based method that analyses the cells and cell components based on the presence of certain cell surface molecules, which are named as per cluster of differentiation (CD) nomenclature. It is very effective for the study of the immune system and its response to infectious diseases and cancer.

questions.text: A patient with a history of a renal transplant presented with a painless pink papule which is slowly growing on his right forearm. The donor was found to have been infected with polyoma virus. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given vignette with a history of a renal transplant and infection with a polyoma virus in the donor raises concerns for Merkel cell carcinoma(MCC).

The polyoma virus is an oncogenic virus associated with the development of MCC, an aggressive form of skin cancer. It is transmitted via solid organ transplants (usually renal transplants), and the immunosuppression given after a transplant allows it to replicate in the host body and diminishes the prognosis. The virus inactivates p53 and the retinoblastoma genes.

Other Options:

Basal cell carcinoma is associated with cumulative sun exposure and presents as a pink, pearly papule.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments are used in myomectomy?
questions.solution:
The instruments used in myomectomy are Bonney's myomectomy clamp (Image 2) and Doyen Myoma Screw (Image 4).

Bonney's myomectomy clamp is used in open myomectomy. It has two sets of finger grips and a locking ratchet mechanism. It helps in controlling hemorrhage and providing a blood-free environment while performing myomectomy. The clamp is usually applied from the pubic end of the abdominal wound, gripping the round ligaments that contain uterine vessels.

Doyen Myoma Screw is also used in open myomectomy. The handle present in this can be used to distinguish it from a laparoscopic myoma screw which also has a similar tip. It helps in enucleation.

Other images:

Image 1: Sim's curette is a single-ended uterine curette used for dilatation and curettage. It is designed to remove tough tissue from the lining of the uterus for biopsy or excision. The curette features a sharp loop tip to aid in the removal of uterine tissue.

Image 3: The episiotomy scissor is bent on the edge. It has a blunt tip that goes inside the vagina. It is used to perform episiotomy during delivery.

Related Pearl: Myomectomy

Myomectomy

  • Retains uterus and hence preserves childbearing function.
  • Effective for heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure.
  • Disadvantage - formation of new clones of abnormal myocytes.
  • Hysteroscopic myomectomy is the procedure of choice for removing intracavitary myomas.
  • Vaginal myomectomy is performed in case, a fibroid prolapses through the cervix.

questions.text: A middle-aged, previously normotensive, male patient is brought with sudden onset blurring of vision. On examination, BP is 220/110 mmHg and fundoscopy shows papilledema. He was administered an intravenous anti-hypertensive. The analog of which of the following drugs would have been given in the intravenous form?
questions.solution:
Papilledema and an abrupt increase in BP of a previously normotensive patient are suggestive of malignant hypertension and the analogue of enalapril would have been given in the I/V form for treatment.

Enalapril is an oral angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE inhibitor). It is a prodrug that gets hydrolyzed in the liver to form the active agent, enalaprilat.

Enalaprilat is more potent than enalapril, however, it is not absorbed in its oral form. So when oral therapy is not appropriate, such as in the case of a hypertensive emergency, enalaprilat, which is available as a parenteral preparation, is used. The dosage is 0.625–1.25 mg given intravenously over 5 min which may be repeated every 6- 8 hours (maximum 5 mg/dose). 

Hypertensive emergency is characterised by progressive retinopathy, worsening renal function with proteinuria, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and encephalopathy. Other parenteral drugs used to treat hypertensive emergencies include:

  • Labetalol
  • Nitroglycerine
  • Nicardipine
  • Nitroprusside
  • Loop diuretics (Furosemide)
  • Hydralazine

Other options:

Unlike enalapril, all the other ACE inhibitors such as captopril, benazepril, and lisinopril do not have parenteral preparations. 

Option B: Captopril is itself potent and is taken orally.

Option C: Benazepril is a prodrug that is cleaved by hepatic enzymes into benazeprilat that is orally absorbed.

Option D: Lisinopril is itself active and is an analogue of enalaprilat taken orally.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old primigravida presents in labor at 37 weeks of gestation. On examination, the cervix is 6 cm dilated, and NST reveals absent baseline FHR variability and recurrent late decelerations. No improvement in fetal status is observed after giving IV fluid bolus, starting oxygen, and repositioning to the lateral decubitus position. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

NST- Non Stress Test
FHR- Fetal Heart Rate
questions.solution:
The absence of baseline FHR variability and recurrent late decelerations indicates a Category III NST. Managing recurrent late decelerations includes IV fluid bolus, starting oxygen, and repositioning the mother to the lateral decubitus position. If no improvement occurs in fetal status, an Emergency C-section should be done.

Category III NST patterns include: 

  • Absent baseline FHR variability and any of the following:
    • Recurrent late decelerations
    • Recurrent variable decelerations
    • Bradycardia
  • Sinusoidal pattern

Recurrent late decelerations on NST indicate Utero-placental insufficiency. Management of  Recurrent late decelerations includes initial actions (IV fluid bolus, starting oxygen, maternal repositioning to the lateral decubitus position, and stopping oxytocin). If there is no improvement in fetal status, then a C-section should be done.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to you with symptoms of pain on ejaculation, urinary urgency, and burning micturition over the past two days. He has had a history of similar infections for the past two years for which he received treatment. A rectal examination revealed a boggy and tender prostate. A three-tube test yielded the growth of E.coli. Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation suggests a diagnosis of chronic bacterial prostatitis. Ciprofloxacin for 6 weeks is the first-line treatment for this condition.

Chronic bacterial prostatitis is a long-standing prostate infection caused by bacterial pathogens, either because acute infections were not treated adequately or if the patient has had repeated episodes of acute prostatitis. Clinically, patients present with prostatodynia and dysuria. They can also have sexual dysfunction. A rectal examination of the prostate may be normal or may show a soft, boggy, and tender prostate, and a three-glass urine test confirms bacterial presence (e.g., E. coli, Enterococci). Diagnosis of chronic bacterial prostatitis is done via the 3-tube test (also known as the three-glass urine test or Stamey test):

  • First voided (10ml) is taken in a test tube. This comes from the urethra.
  • Then, a midstream sample is taken from the bladder and placed in the test tube. 
  • Then a prostatic massage is done, which gives rise to prostate secretions or threads in the first voided sample post-massage. 
  • These prostatic secretion threads are sent for culture.

Treatment: Antibiotics like ciprofloxacin for 6-12 weeks are the first-line choice as they have excellent prostatic penetration. In case resistance is suspected, TMP-SMX may be tried for 3 months. If the causative organism is chlamydia, azithromycin is advised (Option B). Doxycycline may also be used in a patient with a chlamydial infection.

In contrast, chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CPPS) presents with similar pelvic discomfort and urinary symptoms but lacks a bacterial infection. Patients do not have recurrent UTIs, and urine cultures are negative despite possible inflammatory markers in prostatic secretions. 

Other options:

Option A: CT abdomen and pelvis: Imaging is not indicated unless there are complications like abscess.

Option D: Biopsy is reserved for suspected malignancy, which is unlikely, given the infectious presentation and young age.

questions.text: A male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of fever, joint pain, and urticarial rash. He also reports intermittent abdominal pain and blood-streaked stools over the past few weeks. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. A stool sample microscopy is performed, and the image is shown below. Where does the adult worm of the causative parasite reside in the human body?
questions.solution:
The oval egg with a small lateral knob is characteristic of Schistosoma japonicum. The adult worms of S. japonicum primarily reside in the superior mesenteric vein.

Schistosoma japonicum causes oriental schistosomiasis (Katayama disease). The acute phase presents with Katayama fever, while chronic infection leads to intestinal hyperplasia, hepatosplenomegaly, periportal (clay pipestem) fibrosis, and portal hypertension, which can cause esophageal varices and GI bleeding. Intestinal symptoms include colicky pain, bloody diarrhea, and anemia. The CNS and lungs can be affected, with cor pulmonale or severe epileptic seizures.

The life cycle of Schistosoma japonicum is shown below:

Species differentiation of Schistosoma is based on the location of the spine:

  • Terminal spine: S. haematobium
  • Lateral spine: S. mansoni
  • Small lateral knob: S. japonicum
Schistosoma species: Location of the adult worm:
1. S. mansoni Inferior mesenteric vein (draining the colon)
2. S. haematobium Vesical and Pelvic plexus (urinary bladder, ureters)
3. S. japonicum Superior mesenteric vein draining the ileocecal region. (They are also seen in the Intrahepatic portal venules and Hemorrhoidal plexus of veins.)

 

Related Pearl: Eggs of Schistosoma

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient complained of a right breast lump. On examination, it was 4cm in size, hard, immobile, and had no lymph nodes palpable. On a mammogram, there were microcalcifications in the right upper outer quadrant. Biopsy report shows ductal carcinoma in situ. The patient insisted on preserving the breast. During surgery, the surgeon obtained ‘ink on tumor’ 2 times. Which of the following is the absolute contraindication for breast conservative therapy(BCT)?

choices.text: Size of the lump is 4 cm
Ductal carcinoma in situ on biopsy
Lump in the upper outer quadrant
Ink on tumor obtained for 2 times

questions.solution:
The absolute contraindication for breast conservative therapy in this patient is the presence of cancer cells on the edge inked with dye (persistent positive resection margin that is 2 times ink on tumor).

Breast conservative therapy involves resection of primary breast cancer with a 1 cm margin of normal breast tissue along with adjuvant radiotherapy and assessment of regional lymph nodes via a separate incision in the axilla. Removal of primary breast cancer is also called lumpectomy/ tylectomy/ partial mastectomy/ wide local excision.

Absolute contraindications of BCT:

  • Pregnancy
  • Persistently positive margin (2 microscopy shows positive margins)
  • Multicentric lumps
  • Diffuse microcalcification
  • History of therapeutic radiation to the upper trunk

Relative contraindications of BCT:

  • Active SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus), scleroderma  
  • Large lump to breast ratio (>5 cm size lump)
  • Lump just beneath the nipple-areolar complex
  • Multifocal disease

Related Pearl: Contraindications for Breast Conservative Surgery

Absolute contraindications:

  • 1st-trimester pregnancy
  • Diffuse microcalcifications
  • Persistently positive pathologic margin
  • Multicentric tumor
  • History of therapeutic radiation exposure to the chest wall

Relative contraindications:

  • Connective tissue disorders like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE),  scleroderma and rheumatoid arthritis
  • Large lump-to-breast ratio, i.e., a big lump in small breast
  • Lump beneath the nipple-areola complex
  • Multifocal tumor

NOTE : Some authorities do not consider Rheumatoid Arthritis as a relative contraindication as the data on radiation toxicity in RA is sparse.

questions.text:
Which of the following clinical features are seen in Parkinson's disease?
  1. Anosmia
  2. Intention tremor
  3. Visual hallucinations
  4. Asymmetrical rigidity
  5. Bradykinesia
questions.solution:
Parkinson's disease (PD) is characterized by anosmia, peripheral rigidity, and bradykinesia out of the given statements.

PD is characterized by the following four cardinal motor features. Note that Parkinsonism is a broad term that is used when bradykinesia, rigidity and/or tremor are present together. 

  1. Resting tremor 
  2. Asymmetrical rigidity (statement 4)
  3. Bradykinesia (statement 5)
  4. Dysfunction of the gait and postural instability

Cerebellar lesions are characterized by an action tremor that becomes worse as the patient's hand approaches the target. This gives rise to the term intention tremor (statement 2). It is not seen in PD. 

Although atypical parkinsonism syndromes (such as multiple system atrophy, progressive supranuclear palsy, and corticobasal degeneration) also present with features of parkinsonism, they differ from PD in that they have a more aggressive course, the motor symptoms symmetrically involve both halves of the body, and tremors are usually absent.

The non-motor manifestations of PD include:

  • Anosmia (statement 1)
  • Sensory symptoms such as pain
  • Mood disorders such as depression
  • Sleep disturbances
  • Autonomic issues: orthostatic hypotension, GI disturbances, sexual dysfunction
  • Dementia

In a patient with parkinsonian features, the presence of visual hallucinations (statement 3) points to a diagnosis of dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB). DLB is characterized by the emergence of neuropsychiatric manifestations before or at the same time as motor manifestations. However, in Parkinson's disease dementia, the cognitive decline occurs many years after the motor symptoms have appeared.

questions.text: A 33-year-old fitness enthusiast comes to the clinic with lethargy, muscle pains, and anorexia. On examination, he has dermatitis around the eyes, nose, and mouth. Further evaluation reveals a deficiency of the vitamin that functions as a cofactor in the reaction below. This vitamin is not required for which of these other reactions?
questions.solution:
The given clinical complex describes the symptom complex of a patient with biotin deficiency. The conversion of oxaloacetate to malate (option d) is catalyzed by the enzyme malate dehydrogenase. This reaction does not require biotin as a cofactor.

Biotin serves as an important cofactor in carboxylation reactions, where biotin functions as a carrier for the activated carbon dioxide molecule.

Biotin deficiency is commonly seen in patients who consume large quantities of egg whites (as is possible in this patient who is a fitness enthusiast) which contains avidin, a substance that binds to biotin and prevents its absorption.

  • Propionyl CoA carboxylase- propionyl-CoA is carboxylated to d-methyl malonyl-CoA, which is catalyzed by propionyl-CoA carboxylase

questions.text: The following procedure was performed on the upper GI tract for acid reflux in a patient a few weeks ago. Now, the patient complains of gaseous abdominal distension and inability to vomit or belch. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with symptoms of gaseous abdominal distension and inability to vomit or belch after antireflux surgery, in this case a Nissen Fundoplication as shown in the image is suggestive of Gas Bloat Syndrome.

Gas bloat syndrome is a common complication of Fundoplication surgeries, especially Nissen’s fundoplication. It occurs due to too long or too tight a fundoplication. Symptoms include:

  • Gaseous abdominal distension
  • Passing too much flatus
  • Unable to belch or vomit

Management of tight complete fundoplication with gas bloat syndrome includes revision surgery to convert it into a partial, loose fundoplication. The most common complication of fundoplication surgeries remains short-term dysphagia for about 3 months after surgery, believed to occur due to tissue edema and inflammation.

Fundoplication is the surgical management of choice for gastroesophageal reflux surgery. It involves the creation of a “floppy valve” at the esophagogastric junction and restoration of the angle of His. The aim is to increase the tone of the lower esophageal sphincter to stop acid from entering the esophagus. 

Fundoplication may be partial, such as Anterior Dor, Watson, and posterior Toupet, or complete, such as Nissen. Partial fundoplication has fewer short-term side effects but has more long-term failure rates. Complete fundoplication has a lower failure rate but more short-term complications.

Indications for fundoplication are:

  • Incomplete symptom control with medical management
  • Intolerance/Unwillingness to comply with long-term medical management
  • PPIs are not effective at management
  • Associated large hiatus hernia
  • Complications of GERD present
  • Extraesophageal symptoms present

Option A) Gastric volvulus is not normally seen after a Nissen Fundoplication. Its symptoms encompass Borchardt’s triad: sudden severe upper abdominal pain, inability to vomit, and inability to pass NG tube. It usually occurs in the longitudinal axis (organoaxial volvulus).

Option B) Hiatus hernia is a condition in which the abdominal contents migrate through the diaphragmatic hiatus and enter the thoracic cavity. Type 2(true para esophageal hernia), where the stomach herniates into the thoracic cavity, is often associated with obstruction and can evolve into a volvulus or strangulation. Type 1( sliding hernias) are associated with herniation of the esophagogastric junction only and commonly cause GERD. Hiatus hernias are corrected during Fundoplication surgeries if present.

Option D) Perforated PUD is not a complication of Fundoplication.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes mellitus and hypertension comes to the OPD. Physical examination findings are given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate screening test?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with hypertension and diabetes, and having frontal bossing and a protruding lower jaw as shown in the image is suggestive of acromegaly. The screening test for acromegaly is serum IGF-1 levels.

Pituitary tumours are mainly classified as functioning and non-functioning tumours. Functioning tumours secrete hormones and thus lead to specific endocrine syndromes such as:

  • Acromegaly in growth hormone-secreting tumours
  • Cushing syndrome in ACTH secreting tumours
  • Galactorrhea, amenorrhea, and infertility in prolactin-secreting tumours

Non-functioning tumours produce symptoms due to mass effects. The symptoms include headaches, and visual impairment such as bitemporal hemianopia, and hypopituitarism.

The physiological actions of the growth hormone are mostly mediated through IGF-1, which is synthesized in the liver. Since the growth hormone is released in a pulsatile manner, serum IGF-1 levels are usually measured in order to assess growth hormone activity. Serum IGF-1 level is decreased in pituitary failure, defect or blockade of GH receptor. Since the low-calorie state is associated with growth hormone resistance, IGF-1 is also decreased in conditions such as cachexia, malnutrition, and sepsis. Serum IGF-1 level is increased in acromegaly.

The diagnosis of acromegaly is confirmed by demonstrating non-suppression of GH after 2 hours of an oral glucose load.

Other options:

Option A: Overnight dexamethasone suppression test is done for confirming the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome.

Option B: Since the growth hormone is released in a pulsatile manner, it is not possible to test for growth hormone levels directly in cases of acromegaly.

Option D: Short synacthen test is done to confirm the diagnosis of primary adrenal insufficiency or Addison's disease.

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man recently diagnosed with lung cancer presents with a worsening headache that is aggravated by stooping forward. On examination, he has facial and upper limb edema. His anterior abdominal wall appears as shown in the image with the arrow depicting the direction of subcutaneous venous flow. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the image showing dilated tortuous superficial abdominal veins is suggestive of superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome seen due to superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction.

Superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome is a clinical condition caused by the obstruction of the superior vena cava, which leads to impaired venous drainage from the head, neck, upper extremities, and upper torso. The most common cause is malignancy ( lung cancer, lymphomas, particularly non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and metastatic tumors). Non-malignant causes include thrombosis (caused by central venous catheters, pacemakers, or implantable defibrillators), fibrosing mediastinitis (e.g., due to tuberculosis or histoplasmosis), and aortic aneurysm or mediastinal fibrosis.

SVC syndrome is usually diagnosed clinically. Patients present with 

  • Facial puffiness and periorbital edema (worsens in the morning or when bending forward)
  • Jugular venous distension (JVD) and prominent veins on the chest wall
  • Dyspnea, cough, hoarseness, and stridor (if trachea is compressed)
  • Headache, dizziness, and confusion (due to cerebral venous congestion)
  • Edema and cyanosis of the upper limbs

The image below shows the direction of subcutaneous venous flow in various conditions.

A chest X-ray shows the superior mediastinum widening. A CT scan with contrast is the gold standard for identifying an obstruction's location, severity, and cause. Management is supportive and depends on treating the cause.

Other options:

Option A: Inferior vena cava obstruction occurs secondary to deep venous thrombosis, malignancy, pregnancy, and infection. Patients usually present with symptoms of decreased venous return such as fatigue, dizziness, weight loss, abdominal pain, night sweats, anorexia, palpitations, diaphoresis, dizziness, and shortness of breath on exertion. The direction of subcutaneous venous blood flow is from below to above. Inferior vena cava obstruction will not have facial or upper limb edema.

Option C: Cranial metastasis arises from the hematogenous spread and frequently originates from a lung primary or is associated with pulmonary metastases. Patients usually present with symptoms related to direct brain compression from the tumor or from edema. The location of the metastases will determine the focal deficits seen.

Option D: Tumor lysis syndrome is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. It is commonly associated with treating lymphomas like Burkitt's lymphoma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Patients usually present with symptoms of hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a recent Billroth II anastomosis presents with chronic bloating, watery diarrhea, and fatigue. Laboratory investigations reveal macrocytic anemia, hypoalbuminemia, and low vitamin B12 levels. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario involves a patient with a recent Billroth II anastomosis who presents with bloating, watery diarrhea, and an absorption defect (macrocytic anemia, hypoalbuminemia, and low vitamin B12 levels). This is explained by small intestinal bacterial overgrowth(SIBO). SIBO is diagnosed with a glucose-hydrogen breath test.

Billroth II anastomosis is a surgical procedure where the distal stomach is connected to the jejunum after partial gastrectomy, bypassing the duodenum. It can cause small intestinal bacterial overgrowth by creating a stasis of intestinal contents due to altered motility and loss of the gastric acid barrier, allowing excessive bacterial colonization in the small intestine.

SIBO is a condition characterized by an overgrowth of bacteria in the small bowel. It can be caused by strictures, anastomosis (Billroth II anastomosis)surgery, DM, scleroderma, and AIDS. SIBO is characterized by symptoms of malabsorption: diarrhea, flatulence, weight loss, and anemia in chronic cases—particularly megaloblastic anemia due to reduced B12 and high folate levels. Diagnosis is by endoscopy with jejunal aspirate (showing> 103 microorganisms) and glucose hydrogen breath test.

In a healthy small intestine, minimal bacterial fermentation occurs. However, in SIBO, excessive bacteria ferment ingested glucose, producing hydrogen. The procedure involves fasting for 8-12 hours before the test and collecting baseline breath samples. The patient then ingests 75g of glucose dissolved in water, and breath samples are collected every 15-30 minutes for up to 2 hours. An early rise (20ppm) in hydrogen within 90 minutes confirms SIBO.

Treatment includes a 14-day course of Rifaximin and a high-fat, low-carbohydrate diet. Surgery is often the best option for conditions like blind loops, strictures, diverticula, or afferent loops. 

Other options:

Option A: Stool culture for bacterial overgrowth is not a diagnostic test for SIBO, as it represents colonic bacteria rather than small intestinal flora.

Option C: A fecal elastase test is used to assess exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (EPI).

Option D: CT enterography is useful for identifying structural abnormalities but cannot confirm bacterial overgrowth.

questions.text: A young patient presents with resistant hypertension. CT abdomen is shown below. Which of the following conditions may also be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A history of resistant hypertension and the CT showing multiple cysts in the kidneys point to a diagnosis of adult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). One of the manifestations of ADPKD is in the form of Berry aneurysms.

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1 (chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4). The patients present with hypertension and flank pain. The cause of the pain is the infection of the renal cysts, hemorrhage, or concomitant stone formation. Gross hematuria can also occur when the cyst ruptures. The most important causes of mortality in patients with ADPKD are cardiovascular complications due to hypertension, and infections of the cyst. The patients progress to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) by late middle age.

Manifestations of ADPKD in other organs include:

  • Cysts in the liver, pancreas, spleen, and lungs
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms resulting in subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Colonic diverticulae
  • Abdominal wall hernias

The diagnosis is made using typical clinical features, family history consistent with autosomal dominant inheritance, and the presence of multiple, bilateral cysts on imaging. Ultrasound is often used as the first-line investigation. CT and T2 weighted MRI are more sensitive than ultrasound in detecting smaller-sized cysts.

Treatment includes strict control of BP using blockers of RAAS, such as ACE inhibitors and angiotensin-receptor blockers. Tolvaptan (vasopressin antagonist), sirolimus, and everolimus (mTOR pathway inhibitors) have been shown to delay the progression of renal disease. More than half of the patients with ADPKD eventually require renal replacement therapy in the form of hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis, or renal transplant.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old male patient presented to the emergency room with severe chest and back pain. Contrast-enhanced CT revealed a Stanford type B aortic dissection. Which part of the aorta is involved in this condition?
  1. Ascending aorta
  2. Arch of aorta
  3. Descending aorta
questions.solution:
The part of the aorta involved in the above clinical scenario, i.e. Stanford type B aortic dissection, is the descending aorta.

Aortic dissection most commonly occurs in middle-aged and elderly hypertensive patients.

It is initiated by an intimal tear, which allows blood to penetrate into the medial layer, producing a cleavage plane (false lumen) between the inner two-thirds and outer one-third of the media. The true lumen is separated from the false lumen by an intimomedial flap.

Classification of aortic dissection:

Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, which is based on the location of the proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system, which is based only on the location of the proximal tear. 

Site of dissection DeBakey Stanford
Both ascending and descending aorta Type I Type A
Only ascending aorta and arch of aorta Type II Type A

Descending the aorta distal to the subclavian artery

Type IIIa

Limited to the thoracic aorta

 Type B

Type IIIb

Extends to the abdominal aorta

Clinically, patients present with tearing chest/back pain associated with diaphoresis, syncope, weakness, and dyspnea or neurological manifestations.

On examination, unequal pulses or blood pressure in the extremities may be seen due to changes of flow in the true and false lumens. There can be hypertension or hypotension, loss of pulses, findings of aortic regurgitation, and pulmonary edema. 

Imaging: 

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the investigation of choice in a hemodynamically unstable patient.

In hemodynamically stable patients, the diagnosis is established with a contrast-enhanced CT scan. The characteristic diagnostic finding is a double lumen aorta.

questions.text: Which of the following passes through the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
The structure marked A is the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm. Among the given options, the hemi-azygous vein passes through the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm.

The diaphragm is a domed musculofibrous sheet that separates the thoracic and abdominopelvic cavities.

The image given below shows the inferior view of the diaphragm.

The diaphragm is supplied by the phrenic nerve whose root values are C3, C4, and C5. The phrenic nerve is responsible for the referred pain. Diaphragmatic pain is frequently felt at the tip of the shoulder due to the common root of origin of the phrenic nerve and the nerves supplying the shoulder.

Referred pain usually occurs when there is inflammation of the diaphragmatic pleura, e.g. in basal pneumonia, pleural effusions, or with irritation of the peritoneal pleura, as with a subphrenic abscess.

Note: The left phrenic nerve descends anterior to the pericardial sac of the left ventricle and terminates at the central tendon of the diaphragm. The left phrenic nerve innervates the left diaphragmatic dome, and the right phrenic nerve innervates the right diaphragmatic dome, with the majority of nerve branching occurring on the inferior aspect of the diaphragm.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is diagnosed with Tinea capitis. The hair perforation test is found to be positive. What do you expect to see in the morphology in the microscopic examination?

choices.text: Clusters of microconidia and cigar-shaped macroconidia
Abundant microconidia and thick-walled, irregular macroconidia

questions.solution:
The microscopic examination will show clusters of microconidia and cigar-shaped macroconidia.

The boy is diagnosed with Tinea capitis with hair perforation test positive, which indicates the causative organism to be Trichophyton mentagrophytes. The hair perforation test indicates surface erosion of the shaft of hair by Trichophyton mentagrophytes.

Conidia are asexual spores that have 2 types:

  • Microconidia - They are small unicellular spores
  • Macroconidia - They are large septate spores

The image given below shows the Trichophyton mentagrophytes under microscopic examination.

Trichophyton mentagrophyte on culture forms white to tan-coloured colonies with a cottony or powdery consistency. It also gives a urease positive test.

Tinea capitis refers to ringworm of the scalp where there is an invasion of the hair shafts by dermatophyte fungi (Trichophyton, Microsporum, and Epidermophyton). It presents as hair loss with inflammation, with or without itching.

Dermatophytes are of three types:

  • Trichophyton: Infection involves the skin, hair, and nails. The species include Trichophyton rubrum, Trichophyton mentagrophytes, Trichophyton tonsurans, Trichophyton schoenleinii, and Trichophyton violaceum. Microconidia is more than Macroconidia.
  • Microsporum: Infection involves skin and hair. The species include Microsporum gypseum, Microsporum canis, and Microsporum nanum. Macroconidia is more than Microconidia.
  • Epidermophyton: Infection involves skin and nails. Only Macroconidia are present. Epidermophyton floccosum is the only species in this genus.

Other options:

Option B: Long pencil-shaped macroconidia are seen in Trichophyton rubrum. 

Option C: Abundant microconidia and thick-walled, irregular macroconidia are seen in Trichophyton tonsurans.

Option D: Distorted hyphae and few conidia are seen in Trichophyton violaceum.

questions.text: A 35-year-old hypothyroid patient who attained menarche at the age of 13 years presents to the Gynae OPD with amenorrhea for 12 weeks. Lab values indicate hypergonadotropic hypogonadism with a serum prolactin value of 60 ng/ml. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of secondary amenorrhoea with hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, which implies that levels of gonadotropin hormones(FSH, LH) are elevated and levels of Estradiol are decreased. Primary ovarian insufficiency, also known as premature menopause, is the most probable diagnosis in this case.

Primary ovarian insufficiency or premature menopause is the stoppage of menstrual cycles due to ovarian failure before the age of 40 years. Clinically, it is diagnosed as :

  • Women under 40 years of age
  • Secondary amenorrhea for at least 3 months
  • Raised FSH
  • Raised FSH/LH ratio
  • Low E2                                                                                                                       

It is a cause of secondary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism is a condition where there is gonadal failure and estrogen production plummets. This low E2 state increases serum gonadotropin levels via the hypothalamic-pituitary axis stimulation. FSH ( and/or occasionally LH) are typically elevated, and E2 levels are low. It can be primary or secondary.

Causes of primary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism include gonadal dysgenesis such as that seen in Turner syndrome, Gonadotropin receptor defects such as Resistant ovary syndrome, etc

Secondary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism may occur in premature menopause either due to low ovarian reserve or after ovulation induction treatment in infertility, PCOS(where LH is elevated), autoimmune conditions affecting the ovary, ovarian infections, resistant ovary syndrome, etc

Other Options:

Option A: Simmond's disease involves the degeneration or damage of the anterior pituitary gland, leading to insufficient hormone production (hypopituitarism), not elevated FSH and LH.

Option C: Prolactinoma is suggestive when the serum prolactin level is >100 ng/ml. This patient has sufficiently elevated prolactin levels to diagnose only hyperprolactinemia. The patient has hypothyroidism, which may explain the hyperprolactinemia as elevated TSH has a stimulating effect on Prolactin. Normal serum prolactin level is up to 25 ng/ml. Levels higher than 100 ng/ml are suggestive of a tumor. Furthermore, prolactinomas are not a cause of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. They cause a fall in FSH and LH levels.

Option D: Kallmann syndrome is a cause of hypogonadotropic primary amenorrhoea where there is low or absent GnRH either due to autosomal dominant or X-linked autosomal recessive gene.

questions.text:
The maxillary artery is divided into three parts by a muscle. Which of the following correctly describes the actions of this muscle?

1. Elevation of mandible

2. Depression of mandible

3. Retraction of mandible

4. Protrusion of mandible
questions.solution:
The maxillary artery is divided into three parts by the lateral pterygoid muscle. This muscle primarily functions to depress and protrude the mandible.

The maxillary artery is a major branch of the external carotid artery. It is divided into three parts based on its relationship with the lateral pterygoid muscle:

  • First part (Mandibular part)
  • Second part (Pterygoid part) – Lies either superficial or deep to the muscle.
  • Third part (Pterygopalatine part) 

Actions of the Lateral Pterygoid Muscle:

  • Depresses the mandible (opens the mouth).
  • Protrudes the mandible forward.
  • Side-to-side movements (for grinding action).

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with visual disturbances and fatigue. He finds it difficult to see in the dark for the past few months. There is a tingling sensation in his upper limbs. On examination, there is weakness, sensory loss and dry scaly patches over both lower limbs as shown in the picture, which responds to emollients. The enzyme deficiency likely to be seen in this patient is:
questions.solution:
The enzyme deficiency likely to be seen in this patient is phytanoyl CoA α-hydroxylase.

The clinical features of this patient represent Refsum’s disease and the enzyme deficient is phytanoyl CoA α-hydroxylase, also known as phytanic acid alpha oxidase.

The given image shows ichthyosis of the shin and the patient complaints of poor vision with extremely affected dark/night vision which is suggestive of retinitis pigmentosa.

It occurs due to a defect in the enzyme phytanoyl-CoA hydroxylase (PAHX). It typically occurs in individuals between 10-15 years. Refsum disease is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of peroxisomal Phytanoyl CoA α-hydroxylase, an enzyme involved in the alpha oxidation of phytanic acid (branched-chain fatty acid). This results in the accumulation of phytanic acid in the plasma and tissues.

The manifestation of classic adult Refsum disease includes

  • Ichthyosis
  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Ataxia
  • Occasionally cardiac arrhythmias
  • cardiac conduction defects
  • elevated cerebrospinal fluid protein levels without an increase in cells.

It can be diagnosed by elevated levels of phytanic acid and decreased activity of PAHX in the fibroblasts. very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) levels are normal in this condition.

Treatment: Restriction of dietary phytanic acid (found in dairy products, fish oils, and green leafy vegetables).

Infantile Refsums disease is a distinct entity, which presents at one to six months of age with severe developmental delay but generally without the dysmorphic features.

The given image shows fundoscopic findings of retinitis pigmentosa characterized by 

  • Attenuated arteries
  • Waxy and pale optic disc
  • Bony pigmented spicules
