questions.text: A large study involving 3000 schools across a developed country with a sample of over 12 lakh girls was done by its Government to find the mean Hemoglobin value of its country’s girls. The data was plotted and formed a Gaussian distribution. Using the graph, the value of mean was determined to be 12.5  mg/dl with a standard deviation of ± 2.5 . What is the probable median and mode of this sample?
questions.solution:
The given data follows a Gaussian distribution or Normal distribution. In a normal distribution, Mean=Median=Mode.The mean is given as 12.5mg/dl. Hence, median and mode are 12.5mg/dl.

The Central Limit theorem states that as the size of the sample increases, the random sampling of means will become closer to the normal, i.e. the larger the sample, the closer it will be to a normal distribution. 

If we take any data point, such as mean hemoglobin concentration or average systolic blood pressure and plot the graph for a very large sample, such as the entire population of a country, it will follow a normal distribution. This is because normal values are more common and will tend to lie in the centre of the graph while the more abnormal a value is, the more it will lie in the periphery of the graph. The more abnormal a value is, the less common it becomes. Hence, it will form a Gaussian distribution.

In a skewed distribution, mean, median and mode are not equal. In negative skewed distribution, mean<median<mode.In a positively skewed distribution, mean>median>mode.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: Premature infants at or below what gestational age should undergo routine cranial ultrasonography screening for intraventricular hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Routine cranial ultrasonography screening is recommended for premature infants ≤30 weeks of gestation. 

Routine cranial ultrasonography (CUS) is recommended for premature infants ≤30 weeks gestation and selectively for those >30 weeks with additional risk factors. Standard screening should be performed between 7–10 days of life, with follow-ups at 4–6 weeks and term-equivalent age before discharge.

Intraventricular hemorrhage is a common complication in premature infants. It results from fragile germinal matrix blood vessels that are prone to rupture due to fluctuations in cerebral blood flow. The risk is highest in the first few days after birth. The most important risk factor for intraventricular hemorrhage is prematurity, with a high incidence in very low birth weight (VLBW) infants weighing <1500 g at birth. Hence, they are routinely evaluated with a cranial ultrasound.

Clinically, it is often silent, with no initial clinical signs. Severe cases may present with acute deterioration on days 2–3 of life, leading to hypotension, apnea, pallor, stupor, seizures, and shock. Some cases show a gradual progression with altered consciousness, abnormal tone, and respiratory distress. IVH severity is graded based on bleeding location and ventricular dilation:

  • Grade I (germinal matrix bleed)
  • Grade II (intraventricular without dilation)
  • Grade III (IVH with ventricular dilation)
  • PVHI (intraventricular + parenchymal hemorrhage).

Management is primarily supportive, including seizure control, transfusions for anemia and coagulopathy, and fluid resuscitation for shock. Progressive post-hemorrhagic hydrocephalus may require CSF diversion via a ventriculoperitoneal shunt.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with dizziness and breathing difficulty to the emergency department. Vitals are significant for a BP of 100/70mm of Hg and a pulse rate of 110 bpm. Her heart sounds are muffled. The ECG tracing is shown in the image below. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows electrical alternans with sinus tachycardia. This along with the patient's symptoms of muffled heart sounds, breathlessness, and hypotension points to a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. Pulsus paradoxus is typically associated with cardiac tamponade.

Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration. In cardiac tamponade, the ventricles are covered by an incompressible pericardial sac with increased pressure in the pericardial sac. Increased blood flows into the right ventricle during inspiration causes the interventricular septum to bulge into the left ventricle, which in turn causes a reduction in left ventricular volume, stroke volume, and arterial blood pressure. Severe cases may show weakening or disappearance of arterial pulse on palpation during inspiration.

Other causes of pulsus paradoxus include:

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Severe obstructive lung disease
  • Hemorrhagic shock

Cardiac tamponade is the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space causing raised intra-pericardial pressure. This results in poor ventricular filling and a fall in cardiac output. This may be acute following trauma or as a complication of an invasive diagnostic or therapeutic procedure. Subacute cardiac tamponade occurs over days to weeks and can be associated with neoplastic, uremic, or idiopathic pericarditis.

Symptoms of cardiac tamponade include dyspnea, chest discomfort or fullness, peripheral edema, and fatigue. Examination findings are:

  • Tachycardia and hypotension
  • Jugular venous distention with a prominent x (early systolic) descent but an absent y (early diastolic) descent
  • Pericardial rub
  • Pulsus paradoxus

ECG shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans. Electric alternans is a specific finding caused by the anteroposterior swinging of the heart with each contraction. When the heart is nearer to the chest wall, it leads to an increased amplitude deflection on the ECG, whereas, a lower amplitude deflection is seen when the heart moves away from the chest wall.

The echocardiography shows a swinging heart sign, which is characteristic of cardiac tamponade. The pericardial pressures exceed the left ventricular diastolic filling pressures, causing the collapse of heart chambers, IVC plethora, and respiratory variation in volumes and flows.

Other options:

Option A: Pulsus bisferiens also known as bifid pulse has two systolic peaks. It is seen in patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. There is a rapid upstroke to the first peak (percussion wave) and a slower rise to the second peak (tidal wave). It is also rarely appreciated in patients with severe aortic regurgitation.

Option B: Pulsus parvus et tardus refers to a weak pulse (parvus), which rises slowly to a delayed peak (tardus) seen in aortic stenosis.

Option D: Pulsus alternans is defined as beat-to-beat variability in the amplitude of the pulse. It is seen in patients with severe LV dysfunction.

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a term baby vaginally, followed by normal expulsion of the placenta. After labor, she continued to bleed profusely. USG showed retained placental tissue, and it was diagnosed as placenta succenturiata. Which of the following complications is not associated with this type of placenta?
questions.solution:
Placenta succenturiata is not associated with polyhydramnios.

Placenta succenturiata is characterized by one or more small lobes/cotyledon of the placenta located distant from the main placental margin connected by blood vessels. If it is retained following the delivery of the placenta, it may lead to postpartum hemorrhage, subinvolution, uterine sepsis, and polyp formation. If diagnosed, exploration of the uterus and removal of the missing lobe under general anesthesia should be done to avoid complications.

Placenta spuria is the condition in which separated lobes are not connected by blood vessels.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 5-month history of shortness of breath. Examination reveals a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border (second intercostal space). Additionally, S2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration. The ECG performed is as shown below. This patient’s presentation is most consistent with a complication of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This patient’s fixed, wide split S2 and systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border indicate an atrial septal defect (ASD), which can lead to atrial fibrillation (as shown in the ECG) as a late complication due to right atrial dilation.

ASD is a left-to-right shunt that causes right heart volume overload. It leads to a fixed, wide split S2 due to prolonged right ventricular systole and delayed pulmonic valve closure, independent of respiration. The systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border arises from increased pulmonary blood flow. Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations. 

Echocardiography will show characteristic right ventricular volume overload, including an increased right ventricular end-diastolic dimension and flattening and abnormal motion of the ventricular septum. ECG findings of atrial fibrillation suggest a late complication due to right atrial dilation and electrical remodeling.

Management of ASD depends on the size of the defect:

  • Small ASDs: Observation, may close spontaneously.
  • Moderate/Large ASDs: Perform percutaneous device closure (secundum ASD) or surgical closure (primum, sinus venosus).

Other options:

Option A: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a cyanotic congenital heart disease with a harsh systolic murmur due to pulmonary stenosis. A repaired TOF is associated with monomorphic ventricular tachycardia.

Option B: Ventricular septal defect presents with a loud, harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. 

Option D: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) causes a left-to-right shunt, which increases pulmonary blood flow and leads to symptoms like dyspnea, poor feeding, and fatigue. A characteristic continuous machine-like murmur is heard at the left infraclavicular area.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, enucleation is not the preferred surgical intervention?
questions.solution:
Enucleation is not the preferred surgical intervention for panophthalmitis. Instead, evisceration of the eye is the preferred surgical intervention for panophthalmitis.

Enucleation is the removal of the eyeball but surrounding structures like eyelid and orbit remain. Enucleation is usually done for:

  • Intraocular tumors - Malignant melanoma, Retinoblastoma
  • Eye Donation

Evisceration is the removal of internal contents of the eye, like lens iris vitreous, but sclera and EOM are left as such. Indications for evisceration are:

  • Panophthalmitis 
  • Expulsive choroidal hemorrhage
  • Bleeding anterior staphyloma

questions.text: Anaplerosis is the process of refilling the catalytic intermediates of the citric acid cycle that carry acetyl CoA as it gets oxidized. All of the following are anaplerotic reactions, except _____.

choices.text: Conversion of succinyl CoA to heme
Conversion of propionyl CoA to succinyl CoA

questions.solution:
Conversion of succinyl CoA to heme is not an anaplerotic reaction. It is an example of a cataplerotic reaction.

The anaplerotic process is the replenishment of the intermediates of the citric acid (Krebs) cycle to replace the catalytic processes and to ensure the continuation of the cycle.

The most important anaplerotic reaction is the carboxylation of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, which is catalyzed by pyruvate carboxylase. This reaction is important to maintain an adequate concentration of oxaloacetate for the condensation reaction with acetyl-CoA. On accumulation, acetyl-CoA acts as an allosteric activator of pyruvate carboxylase and an inhibitor of pyruvate dehydrogenase, thereby providing an adequate supply of oxaloacetate.

Other anaplerotic reactions:

  • Glutamate and glutamine to α-ketoglutarate, a reaction catalyzed by glutamate dehydrogenase and glutaminase, respectively
  • Compounds that produce propionyl CoA can be then carboxylated and isomerized to succinyl CoA.
  • Transamination of aspartate to form oxaloacetate.
  • Pyruvate can be carboxylated to malate.

The cataplerotic process is the metabolism of the citric acid cycle intermediates that leave the cycle and participate in the biosynthesis of other compounds. These processes are required to redirect citrate toward fatty acid synthesis; succinyl CoA to heme synthesis, malate to gluconeogenesis; and α-ketoglutarate to amino acid synthesis, purine synthesis, and neurotransmitter synthesis.

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Release: FADH2

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of vomiting, abdominal distention, and postprandial epigastric pain. She provides a history of recent profound weight loss. A barium meal follow-through of the patient is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium follow-through demonstrating dilation of the duodenum with an abrupt cut-off at its third part, coinciding with the line of the superior mesenteric artery is suggestive of superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome/Wilkie syndrome.

Wilkie syndrome is usually seen in young women. It is a rare condition in which the SMA compresses the third portion of the duodenum. The normal aortomesenteric angle is between 25-60 degrees. This is reduced in SMA syndrome. The SMA obstructs the third part of the duodenum by compressing it against fixed retroperitoneal structures.

SMA syndrome is associated with supine immobilization, profound weight loss, scoliosis, and body cast, hence also called cast syndrome. Clinical features include profound nausea and vomiting, abdominal distention, weight loss, and postprandial epigastric pain. Upper gastrointestinal barium studies are used for diagnosis. CT is also useful in some cases.

Management includes:

  • Duodenojejunostomy with the division of the ligament of Treitz is the most common and most successful procedure done.
  • Strong's operation -the division of ligament of Treitz and transposition of the SMA.
  • Anterior transposition of the 3rd part of the duodenum.

The given image shows a compressed angle between SMA and the abdominal aorta in CT angiography.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presented to OPD  with multiple pigmented papular lesions on her face, neck, and forearm and corneal injection following exposure to the sun. Which DNA repair mechanism is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and the history are suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum. The DNA repair mechanism that is defective in this condition is nucleotide excision repair (NER). The given image shows hyperkeratotic lesions with some induration suspicious of actinic keratosis and early squamous cell carcinoma. Also, numerous hyper-pigmented lentigos and xerosis are seen on the entire front of the face.

 Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and other carcinogenic agents.

Skin changes begin in infancy or early childhood, mainly in sun-exposed areas. The skin lesions include erythema, scaling, bullae, freckles, telangiectasia, keratoses, basal and squamous cell carcinomas, and malignant melanomas. Eye manifestations include photophobia, blepharitis, keratitis, corneal opacities, eyelid tumors, and possible blindness. Neurologic abnormalities occur rarely in the form of cognitive deterioration and sensorineural deafness.

UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase. The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA. In XP, there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure, and hence the accumulation of mutations that cause cancers.

questions.text: A cloth stained with a dark stain, suspected to be bloodstain was recovered from a crime scene. Which of the following statements regarding the examination of this evidence is true.

choices.text: A precipitin test is done to differentiate between human and animal blood
The sex of the individual can be determined using RBCs from the sample
A positive hemochromogen test rules out the identity of the stain as blood
A positive benzidine test is confirmatory of bloodstain

questions.solution:
A precipitin test is done to differentiate between human and animal blood.

Blood stains can be subjected to a precipitin test where the blood sample is taken and anti-human antibodies are added to the sample. Flocculation occurs if the sample has human blood. Positive tests are obtained at even 1/1000 dilution of human serum.

Other ways to differentiate human and animal blood include RBC examination under the microscope as animal RBCs are usually nucleated. Human RBCs are anucleate. Species-specific tests like precipitin electrophoresis and anti-globin consumption tests also exist.

Other Options:

Option B: The sex of the individual can be determined by leucocytes in human blood as they are nucleated and the nucleus contains Barr body or Sex Chromatin.RBC is an anucleate cell. Usually, if there is no Barr body, they are male, and if one Barr body is present, they are female. Exceptions to the rule exist, like Turner/Klinefelter syndrome.

Note: Number of Barr body=Number of X chromosome - 1

Option C: Hemochromogen/Takayama Test is a microchemical test that acts as a confirmatory test for Blood stains. In this test, Takayama reagent(NaOH, Pyridine, Glucose) is added to the stain. If bloodstain is present, pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen appear in a few minutes. The test is negative if the crystals are not formed in 30 minutes.

The Teichmann test (hemin crystal test) is another microchemical confirmatory test used to detect bloodstains. When Teichmann reagent is added, if bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of hemin/ hematin chloride appear. When hydrogen peroxide is added, the hematin crystals give bubbles of gas.

Option D: The benzidine test is a screening test, and a negative test rules out the possibility of the stain being blood. However, it can also give false positive results with various compounds such as pus, saliva, milk, rust, vegetable stain, etc.

Note: Confirmatory tests for blood include the Teichmann test, Takayama test and the Spectroscopic test. Spectroscopic test is more reliable than other tests.

questions.text: A girl with a known epilepsy disorder and intellectual disability is being evaluated for a genetic condition. On examination, the following lesions are observed on her face. Which of the following is the most common renal manifestation observed in this disorder?
questions.solution:
Renal Angiomyolipoma is the most common renal manifestation that can be seen in this patient with clinical features suggestive of Tuberous Sclerosis.

The given image shows the adenoma sebaceum, also known as multiple angiofibromas of the face, located on central cheeks, seen in Tuberous sclerosis.

The given scenario describes the classic epiloia triad (Epilepsy, Low intelligence, and Adenoma sebaceum) of Tuberous sclerosis, which is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder characterised by the presence of benign congenital tumors in multiple organs. The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16. Loss-of-function mutations of these tumor suppressor genes (TSC1&2) are present.

Angiomyolipomas are benign tumors that occur sporadically or in association with tuberous sclerosis. They are often benign, bilateral and multiple. They can present as flank pain, palpable mass, hematuria, urinary tract infections, hypertension, or renal failure. Rarely, they may result in massive retroperitoneal hemorrhage (Wunderlich syndrome) and present as a triad of Renal mass, flank pain, and Hypotension (Lenk’s triad). 

Ultrasound typically shows a bright echogenic mass due to the high fat content.

On imaging, they look very similar to the cysts in ADPKD but there is a clear increase in risk of progression to renal cell carcinoma in these cases. Hence regular imaging surveillance is necessary in cases of tuberous sclerosis. They may rarely develop chronic kidney disease and further detoriate to End stage renal disease if left untreated.

Microscopically, they arise from the perivascular epitheloid cells and are composed of varying proportions of vascular, immature smooth muscle cells, and fat cells.

Asymptomatic cases with >4cm in dimension are recommended to undergo prophylactic partial nephrectomy, while those presenting with bleeding can be treated with renal artery embolization. Recently, mTOR inhibitors like everolimus have been approved by US-FDA to treat renal as well as non-renal manifestations of tuberous sclerosis. 

 Other Non-renal manifestations of Tuberous sclerosis include: 

  • Neurological - subependymal nodules, cortical tubers, subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGAs).
  • Skin lesions - Hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules
  • Periungual fibromas or Koenen tumors (small fibromas or nodules of skin around fingernails or toenails)
  • Shagreen patch- roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, primarily in the lumbosacral region
  • Facial angiofibromas
  • Confetti skin lesions
  • Other solid tumours - Cardiac rhabdomyoma

Other options: 

Option A: Clear cell renal carcinoma is associated with Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome.

Option C: Renal oncocytoma is the most common benign renal tumour overall. It is associated with Birt-hogg dube syndrome.

Option D: Papillary renal carcinoma is occurs due to mutations in MET gene.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency room of a hospital after he consumed 12-14 tablets of acetaminophen 650 mg . He complains of nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain. The false statement regarding this condition is:

choices.text: Plasma transaminases are elevated within 6 hours after ingestion
Centrilobular necrosis can be seen in this condition
N-acetyl cysteine helps replenish glutathione stores

questions.solution:
The given scenario indicates acetaminophen poisoning. Plasma transaminases become elevated about 12–36 hours after ingestion, not within 6 hours.

Acetaminophen is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), which appears to inhibit cyclooxygenase (COX) in the brain selectively and has both analgesic and antipyretic effects. Even though acetaminophen has a good safety profile at therapeutic levels, it can cause severe liver toxicity if taken in large amounts.

Acetaminophen poisoning can cause necrosis in the Centrilobular zone of the portal triad. Hepatic injury with acetaminophen involves its conversion to the toxic metabolite N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI). Generally, it is eliminated rapidly by conjugation with glutathione and then metabolized to a mercapturic acid before being excreted into the urine. 

However, in an acetaminophen overdose, hepatocellular levels of glutathione become depleted as a result of which the NAPQI metabolite binds covalently to cell macromolecules, leading to cellular dysfunction. Furthermore, depletion of intracellular glutathione renders the hepatocytes highly susceptible to oxidative stress and apoptosis. Renal tubular necrosis and hypoglycemic coma also may occur.

N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI) is a toxic metabolite of acetaminophen which causes hepatotoxicity. In adults, hepatotoxicity may occur after ingestion of a single dose of 10–15 g (150–250 mg/kg) of acetaminophen; doses of 20–25 g or more are potentially fatal.

Plasma transaminases become elevated, beginning about 12–36 hours after ingestion. Symptoms that occur during the first 2 days include nausea, abdominal pain, anorexia ; indications of hepatic damage manifest within 2–4 days of ingestion and present as right subcostal pain, tender hepatomegaly, jaundice, and coagulopathy. Renal impairment or frank renal failure may occur. Liver enzyme abnormalities typically peak 72–96 h after ingestion. Biopsy of the liver would show centrilobular necrosis with periportal sparing.

Activated charcoal, if given within 4 h of ingestion, decreases acetaminophen absorption considerably and should be administered if the ingested dose is suspected to exceed 7.5 g. N-acetyl cysteine is indicated for those at risk of hepatic injury and functions by detoxifying NAPQI and replenishing glutathione stores. 

Hypoglycemia may result from liver failure, therefore plasma glucose should be monitored closely. Fulminant hepatic failure is an indication for liver transplantation.

questions.text: A family went camping in the woods and lit a fire using some vegetative material, shown below, that they found near them. The father roasted the plant over the fire and ate it. After some time, he complained of abdominal pain, profuse salivation, diarrhea, and palpitations and was rushed to the ER. His pulse was rapid and faint, his blood pressure was 90/60 mm Hg, hyperkalemia was noted, and his ECG showed AV Block. What is the plant and its antidote?
questions.solution:
The plant is Nerium odorum identified by the image and the characteristic clinical features of profuse salivation, AV block, and hyperkalemia. The antidote administered is Digibind.

Nerium odorum/Oleander/Kaner is a tall shrub with lanceolate(pointy) leaves and pink/white/ red/yellow flowers that are found on the Indian Subcontinent. All parts of the plant contain cardiac glycosides which cause gastrointestinal and cardiac symptoms. Nerium poisoning is known to occur by burning vegetative matter of the plant and inhaling fumes or consuming food over the fumes.

Features of Oleander poisoning:

  • Copious salivation, Nausea, vomiting
  • Abdominal pain and diarrhea
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Fatal tachy/brady arrhythmias, AV blocks
  • Death by cardiac failure
    Treatment involves gastric lavage with activated charcoal and administration of a specific antidote, a digoxin-specific FAB fragment known as Digibind. This fragment binds to the cardiac glycosides, which can then be safely excreted from the body. Hyperkalemia correction is also done.

Plant Poisons and their antidotes:

PLANT ANTIDOTE
Datura stramonium Physostigmine
Atropa belladonna Physostygmine
Nerium odorum Digibind
Cerebra thevetia Digibind
Digitalis purpurea Digibind
Nicotiana tabacum Inversine/Mecamylamine

Other Options:

Option B: Atropa belladonna poisoning usually presents with antimuscarinic symptoms such as dry mouth, delirium, fever, dilated pupils, etc. Antidote is Physostigmine.

Option C: Cerbera thevetia also contains toxic cardiac glycosides, and the specific antidote is Digibind, just like Nerium odorum. However, the image given in the question shows the Nerium plant.

Option D: Aconitum napellus poisoning typically occurs through roots and seeds. Leaves or roots, if touched, cause numbness and tingling of hands. There is a burning sensation and numbness in the upper GI tract. Later, there is numbness and paresis of all limbs, hippus, diplopia, and eventually respiratory/cardiac paralysis. There is no specific antidote.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child has been brought up with a high fever and noisy breathing, cough, and dysphagia for the past few days. The radiograph showed the following finding. Which type of stridor is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and radiograph of the patient showing the widening of the prevertebral shadow suggest acute retropharyngeal abscess, which is characterised by an inspiratory stridor.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through the narrowed air passages. Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, like in retropharyngeal abscess and laryngomalacia. 

An acute retropharyngeal abscess occurs in children below 3 years of age. The infections of adenoids or tonsils cause suppuration in the retropharyngeal lymph nodes, which leads to abscess formation. In adults, retropharyngeal abscess is usually secondary to trauma like penetrating injury of the posterior pharyngeal wall or cervical esophagus.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Inspiratory stridor leading to difficult breathing
  • Croupy cough
  • Torticollis
  • A bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall

The features that are seen in the x-ray include :

  • Widening of the prevertebral soft tissue shadow
  • In an acute abscess, the gas formation can be seen.

Treatment is usually by incision and drainage of the abscess and antibiotics. Tracheostomy is required in cases of large abscesses causing obstruction to the airway or leading to laryngeal edema. 

Other options:

Option B: Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, like in bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis. 

Option C: Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of glottis, subglottis and cervical trachea, like in laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis and subglottis stenosis.

questions.text:
A young man with a history of blunt abdominal trauma was brought to the emergency department. He was hemodynamically unstable, and a FAST examination revealed free fluid. An immediate laparotomy was done. The maneuver shown in the image below was performed due to severe bleeding near the liver. However, the bleeding continued. What could be the probable source of the bleeding in this case?

FAST - Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma

choices.text: Both hepatic arterial and Portal venous bleeding

questions.solution:
The image shows clamping of the hepatoduodenal ligament, which is done in the Pringle maneuver. Bleeding that is not controlled by this maneuver suggests that the source of the bleeding is the hepatic vein. 

The Pringle manoeuvre is performed in surgery when there is excessive bleeding from the liver to temporarily arrest the bleeding and identify the source of the bleed, and is especially helpful in traumatic liver injury. With the occlusion of the portal triad, the inflow from the hepatic artery and portal vein are controlled, but backflow from the IVC and hepatic vein persists. After performing this maneuver, the liver laceration can be explored, and further bleeding can be controlled.

It is one of the 4 Ps in the management of liver injuries, which include: 

  • Push- Compression of the edges of the laceration
  • Pringle- Applying pressure on the portal triad
  • Plug- The defects are plugged with silicon tubes
  • Pack- Apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleeding

Ischemia and portal hypertension are complications that result from either prolonged clamping time during the Pringle maneuver or normal clamping time in patients with compromised liver function (eg, from cirrhosis).

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not encountered along the anatomical plane of the L1 vertebra?
questions.solution:
The inferior vena cava  is not typically encountered along the plane of the L1 vertebra.

The transpyloric plane is a horizontal plane that passes through the level of the L1 vertebra. Its relationship with key abdominal structures makes it an important reference point in normal and pathological conditions. The anatomical plane at the L1 level typically intersects:

  • Pylorus of the stomach
  • Duodenal bulb 
  • Neck of pancreas
  • Origin of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), portal vein, and renal arteries
  • Hepatic flexure of the colon
  • Hilum of the left kidney
  • Fundus of gallbladder 

The inferior vena cava (IVC) typically forms at the level of the L5 vertebra, which corresponds to the intertubercular plane (also known as the transumbilical plane). 

Related Pearl: Abdominal planes and their landmarks

Planes that divide the abdomen into 9 regions are:

  • Horizontal planes 
    • At the level of L3 - Subcostal plane (between 10th costal cartilages). It corresponds to the 3rd part of the duodenum
    • At the level of L5 - Transtubercular plane (between tubercles of iliac crests). It corresponds to the origin of inferior vena cava. 
  • Vertical planes (paramedian or lateral planes)
    • From mid-clavicular point to mid-inguinal point on both sides 

The nine regions of the abdomen include:

  • Right hypochondriac, epigastric, left hypochondriac
  • Right lumbar, umbilical (central), left lumbar
  • Right iliac, hypogastric (suprapubic), left iliac

Other planes and angles in the abdomen are:

  • Transpyloric (Addison's) plane - passes midway between the suprasternal notch and the upper border of the pubic symphysis.
  • Supracristal plane - passes through the highest point of the iliac crest on both sides. It corresponds to the level of the L4 body or L4/5 disc and its spinous process. It is an important landmark when performing a lumbar puncture or spinal injection. The bifurcation of the abdominal aorta lies approximately in this plane.
  • The plane of the pubic crest - passes through the upper border of the pubic symphysis. In supine, this plane intersects the tip of the coccyx and the femoral head.
  • Renal angle - between the 12th rib and the outer border of erector spinae muscle. The lower border of normal kidneys may occasionally be felt here. 
  • Lumbar triangle of Petit - formed below by the iliac crest, anteriorly by external oblique, and posteriorly by latissimus dorsi. Lumbar hernia can occur here.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the hospital with complaints of blood-stained sputum. He has smoked around 1.5 packs per day for the last 20 years. Bronchoscopy was suggestive of lung carcinoma. A biopsy was obtained and is shown below. The cells were positive for thyroid transcription factor-1, napsin A and were negative for p63 and p40. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of adenocarcinoma lung. The microscopic image of the tissue shows an increased mucinous type of cells and their characteristics growth along the pre-existing alveolar septa.

Smoking is a major risk factor for developing lung cancer. Other risk factors that can contribute are industrial chemical exposure, air pollution, etc.

They are broadly divided into

  1. Small cell lung cancer
  2. Non-small cell lung cancer
    1. Adenocarcinoma
    2. Squamous cell carcinoma
    3. Large cell carcinoma

Though adenocarcinoma is the most common tumor of the lung in non-smokers, it can be seen in smokers as well. It is also more common in women. Adenocarcinoma of the lung occurs in the periphery of the lung, frequently in areas of chronic scarring caused by chronic inflammatory changes. 

Clinical features include cough, chest pain, hemoptysis, and symptoms due to metastasis. Some lung cancers are responsible for paraneoplastic syndromes.

Lung adenocarcinomas are now classified by their predominant pattern:

  • Lepidic pattern (At the periphery of the tumor, the tumor cells crawl along the surrounding normal alveoli)
  • Acinar pattern
  • Papillary pattern
  • Solid patterns (poor prognosis)

Lung nodules should always be compared with previous films. CT scan is done for further evaluation and biopsy is done to confirm the diagnosis.

In the image below glandular differentiation can be noted which is seen in adenocarcinoma of the lung.

Other options:

Option B: Small cell carcinomas:

They have the strongest association with smoking. They include loss-of-function mutations involving TP53, RB, and chromosome 3p deletions. Small cell carcinomas arise in the bronchi or in the periphery of the lungs. Extensive necrosis leads to the coating of the surrounding walls by DNA. This appears as basophilic staining of the vascular walls and is called the Azzopardi effect. They express chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56.

Below image- Small cell carcinoma:

Option D: Large cell carcinoma 

It is an undifferentiated malignant epithelial tumor that lacks the cytologic features of other forms of lung cancer. They do not express markers of adenocarcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma.

Option A: Squamous cell carcinomas

They are commonly found in men and are strongly associated with smoking. They are located in the central or perihilar region. It can grow as an exophytic mass in the bronchial lumen leading to bronchial obstruction. They are positive for p63 and p40.

Below image- Squamous cell carcinoma:

questions.text:
A 53-year-old female patient presents with complaints of weakness for the last 2 months. Additionally, she is facing difficulty rising from a chair, and combing her hair every morning. A physical exam reveals decreased strength in the shoulders and hip. Skin findings are as shown in the image. Which of the following is seen in this patient's condition?
  1. Perimyseal infiltrates
  2. Perivascular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles
  3. CD4+ cellular infiltrates
  4. Predominant distal muscle weakness
  5. Underlying malignancy
questions.solution:
In the given clinical vignette, this patient's symptoms along with the image findings showing heliotrope rash are highly suggestive of dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis involves CD 4+ cells, perimyseal infiltrates, and is associated with underlying malignancy. Hence, the correct findings are 1, 3, and 5.

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness, muscle inflammation, and a variety of characteristic skin manifestations. The pattern of muscle involvement helps distinguish a myopathy from a cerebral, spinal cord, neuronal or neuromuscular junction cause. It is commonly associated with an underlying malignancy.

Classic signs-

  • Heliotrope rash/ eyelid erythema- Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids
  • V sign- Confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest
  • Shawl sign- Confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms
  • Gottron’s papules- Erythematous papules and plaques over extensor surface of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints
  • Gottron's sign- Erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles. 
  • Mechanic’s hands- Rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmer areas of the fingers
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Facial rash- Confluent erythema in the malar distribution involving the cheeks, nasal bridge, and nasolabial folds
  • Nail fold changes
  • Flagellate erythema- Linear erythema on the upper back with pruritus
  • Poikiloderma- Mottled pattern of hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules with telangiectasias
  • Cutaneous calcinosis- Accumulation of calcium deposits in the skin.

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies. Electromyography will reveal features of myopathy. Histology will show perifascicular atrophy and immunohistochemical staining will reveal myxovirus resistance protein A, a sensitive and specific marker. 

Treatment of dermatomyositis is immunotherapy with high-dose glucocorticoids being the first line. Methotrexate can be started as the second line if the patient presents with severe weakness, other organ system involvement, or those with risk of steroid complications like patients with diabetes, osteoporosis, or postmenopausal women. Otherwise, second-line agents are only started in patients who do not show improvement after 2-4 months of treatment with prednisone or those who cannot be maintained on a low dose. Triple therapy with intravenous immunoglobulin or rituximab may be required. 

Note: Inclusion Body myositis is resistant to immunosuppressive medication 

Muscle biopsy findings in various inflammatory myositis are as follows-

Dermatomyositis Polymyositis Inclusion body myositis

Perivascular infiltrates and perifascicular atrophy. Perivascular infiltrates    Perivascular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with chronic heart failure presents with a particular breathing pattern. His depth and rate of respiration are plotted as given below. The type of breathing abnormality seen here is?
questions.solution:
The type of breathing abnormality shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes breathing. 

Cheyne-Stokes breathing is characterized by periods of waxing and waning hyperventilation separated by periods of apnea, as seen in the image. This pattern is seen at high altitudes and in patients with severe heart disease or brain injury.

 
In Cheyne-Stokes respiration, the person ventilates excessively, leading to an excessive loss of CO2 and an increased concentration of O2 in the blood. These changes in the blood are detected only after a few seconds after the pulmonary blood reaches the brain. Thus ventilation does not get inhibited immediately.
 
When the overventilated blood finally reaches the respiratory center in the brain, the center gets excessively depressed, and ventilation is inhibited. This leads to increased CO2 and decreased O2 in the alveoli. It takes the center a few more seconds to respond to these reversed changes, leading to excessive ventilation. The cycle then repeats.
 
 
In severe chronic cardiac failure, blood flow from the lungs to the brain is slow. This leads to alveolar changes in the CO2 and O2 occurring for longer than usual and excessive storage of these gases within the alveoli and pulmonary blood. After a few seconds, the periodic respiratory drive becomes extreme and Cheyne-Stokes breathing begins. 
 
Other options:
Option A: Kussmaul's breathing is a form of hyperventilation. It occurs due to an increased tidal volume with or without an increase in respiratory rate. It is seen in association with any condition that leads to acidosis.
 
Option B: Biot's breathing is characterized by regular deep respirations with periods of apnea. It occurs due to pontine damage by stroke, trauma, or uncal herniation. 
 
Option D: Hyperpnea refers to an increased volume of respiration with or without an increased rate of breathing. Blood gas concentrations are normal.
 
The different patterns of respiration are shown below.

questions.text: A patient with Hansen's Disease, 6 weeks after initiating treatment with an MDT regimen, presents with fever, lymphadenopathy, and an exfoliative rash. On examination, he is deeply icteric and hepatosplenomegaly is noted. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate high dose clofazimine and add thalidomide
Initiate high dose dapsone and add systemic corticosteroids
Continue the same MDT.Supportive care only

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Dapsone Hypersensitivity Syndrome/Sulfone hypersensitivity syndrome, which is a complication of Dapsone treatment. Dapsone must be immediately discontinued, and systemic steroids and supportive care must be given.

Dapsone Hypersensitivity syndrome is a DRESS(Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms), which occurs typically 4-6 weeks after initiating treatment with dapsone and presents with:

  • Fever
  • Exfoliative dermatitis
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Hepatitis and hepatosplenomegaly

It is more common in HLA B* 13:01. Management includes immediate cessation of Dapsone starting systemic corticosteroids and providing supportive care. Despite identification and prompt treatment, it can be fatal.

Other Options:

Option A) High-dose clofazimine(300 mg/day), due to its anti-inflammatory action, and/or thalidomide(400 mg/day) are used in the treatment of erythema nodosum leprosum which presents with erythematous nodules over face and extensor surfaces of limbs associated with systemic signs and symptoms such as iritis, uveitis, dactylitis, arthritis, myositis, orchitis, lymphadenitis, neuritis, etc. Thalidomide must always be used under cover of contraceptives due to its teratogenic nature.

Option C) and D) Dapsone must be withdrawn in Dapsone hypersensitivity syndrome.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old female patient with a history of streptococcal upper respiratory tract infection one week back presents with acute tender, red dermal plaques and nodules over the arms and face since one day. Histopathology of the lesion shows a striking band of dermal edema overlying a dense neutrophilic infiltrate. The peripheral smear shows neutrophilia.
What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario where an individual presents with acute, tender, red dermal plaques and nodules along with an HPE and peripheral smear showing neutrophils is suggestive of Sweet syndrome, an acute febrile inflammatory neutrophilic dermatosis.

Sweet syndrome is of three types:

  • Classic Sweet Syndrome: CSS: Triggers include Streptococcal pharyngitis, Yersinia, Mycobacterium infections, Salmonella, IBD, Sarcoidosis, Rheumatoid Arthritis, Behcet, etc.
  • Malignancy-associated Sweet Syndrome: Typically associated with hematological malignancies like AML and Promyelocytic Leukemia
  • Drug-Induced Sweet Syndrome: Drugs like ATRA, G-CSF, Azathioprine

The lesions can be described as tender, tumid, red dermal plaques and nodules affecting arms, upper body, and face. They often arise in CSS after a nonspecific GI or Upper respiratory tract infection. Histopathology shows dense dermal neutrophilic infiltrate, and peripheral smear shows neutrophilia. Several differential diagnoses exist for the condition, such as erythema nodosum, metastases, leukemia cutis, erysipelas, etc

First-line drugs for treatment are oral and systemic corticosteroids depending on disease severity. Second-line drugs include Dapsone, Colchicine, and Potassium Iodide.

The image below shows Sweet Syndrome lesions on the arm:

Other Options:

Option A: Erythema marginatum is an evanescent non-pruritic rash with a serpiginous spreading edge and central clearing seen over the trunk and extremities and part of the Jones Criteria for Rheumatic Fever.

Option B: Erythema gyratum repens is an annular erythematous rash with a peripheral collarette seen as a paraneoplastic manifestation of malignancies like lung cancer.

Option C: Erythema migrans is a characteristic lesion that appears over the Ixodid tick’s bite site around 7-14 days after onset of Lyme Disease and is a target/bull’s eye-like lesion with central clearing that spreads uniformly.

questions.text: A child with congenital thrombocytopenia presents with eczema and recurrent infections. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the WASP gene. Which of the following statements about this condition is false?

choices.text: It is an X-linked recessive disorder
High levels of IgM are found in the serum
The definitive treatment is stem cell transplantation
There is an increased risk of lymphoreticular malignancies

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests Wiskott Aldrich syndrome. Here, serum IgM levels are low, but IgG levels are usually normal, and these are associated with increased levels of IgA and IgE.

Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is a rare X-linked recessive immunodeficiency. The WASP gene on Xp11.23 encodes the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein, which plays a crucial role in cytoskeletal organization in lymphocytes and platelets. This primarily affects platelets, lymphocytes, and the immune system, leading to:

  • Thrombocytopenia (low platelet count with small-sized platelets).
  • Eczema, often resembling atopic dermatitis.
  • Recurrent infections due to both B-cell and T-cell dysfunction.

Immunoglobulin abnormalities in WAS (due to T-cell dysfunction leading to defective B-cell activation and class switching, impairing IgM production while allowing IgA and IgE to be upregulated) include:

  • Low IgM results from defective B-cell signaling and impaired class switching.
  • Normal IgG levels.
  • Elevated IgA and IgE levels contribute to the eczema and allergic diathesis seen in these patients.

These abnormalities increase the patient's susceptibility to encapsulated bacterial infections, such as S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and N. meningitidis. They also increase the risk of lymphoreticular malignancies. 

Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the only definitive management of this condition. Supportive care includes IVIG therapy, prophylactic antibiotics, and platelet transfusions in severe thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: Which of the following biochemical processes occur either in the cytoplasm or in the lysosome?
questions.solution:
Glycogenolysis occurs either in the cytoplasm or in the lysosome.

Glycogenolysis is a catabolic pathway involving the degradation of glycogen. In early fasting, which is 4-18 hours after the well-fed state, the blood glucose level is maintained by hepatic glycogenolysis. The glycogen stores are sufficient for around 18 hours after a meal, following which they start to deplete. Therefore, the source of blood glucose in a person fasting for 11 hours will be liver glycogenolysis.

Glycogen phosphorylase is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycogenolysis and is decreased in the fed state.

  • Negative regulators of Glycogen phosphorylase include:
    • Glucose-6-phosphate
    • Insulin
    • ATP
  • Positive regulators of Glycogen phosphorylase include:
    • Epinephrine
    • Glucagon
    • AMP

Option A: FA (fatty acid) oxidation occurs in the mitochondria (via beta-oxidation), not the cytoplasm.

Option B: Ketone body synthesis takes place in the mitochondria of liver cells.

Option C: Gluconeogenesis involves steps in both the mitochondria and the cytoplasm, so it is not exclusive to the cytoplasm.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of cholecystectomy presents with fever, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain. Imaging reveals a 2 cm stone in the distal CBD, and ERCP fails to retrieve it. He undergoes open CBD exploration for stone removal. Which of the following instrument is used for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The instrument used in this case is shown in image 1: Desjardins forceps. 

Desjardins forceps are designed for exploring the open common bile duct (CBD). They are primarily used to grasp and extract large or impacted bile duct stones that cannot be retrieved via ERCP or balloon techniques.

Features of Desjardin Forceps:

  • Fenestra at the tip has curved jaws – Designed to securely hold the stone without slippage.
  • Long shaft – Allows deep reach into the CBD.
  • Strong grip – Facilitates manual extraction of large, impacted stones.

It does not have a lock; hence, accidental damage to CBD mucosa or crushing of the CBD stone is avoided.

Other Options:

Option B: Babcock forceps are used for handling delicate tissues like part of the bowel, fallopian tubes, appendix, ureter, cord, etc

Option C: Tilley’s forceps are used for anterior nasal packing in epistaxis. 

Option D: Pile holding forceps are used in proctology for hemorrhoids, not in biliary surgery.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient is undergoing surgery for intestinal obstruction under isoflurane. Suddenly the patient develops tachypnea, tachycardia, and hyperpyrexia. His capnograph is given below. Investigations reveal hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis. What is the next best step in the management?

choices.text: Administer bicarbonate to correct metabolic acidosis
IV Paracetamol and cold tepid sponging to tackle the hyperpyrexia
Discontinue Isoflurane followed by IV dantrolene sodium

questions.solution:
Capnograph shows a sudden and progressive increase in ETCO2 which is typical of malignant hyperthermia. The next best step is to discontinue isoflurane followed by the administration of dantrolene sodium.

Protocol for immediate treatment of malignant hyperthermia

  1. Discontinue volatile anesthetic and succinylcholine. Notify the surgeon. Call for help.
  2. Mix dantrolene sodium with sterile distilled water, and administer 2.5 mg/kg intravenously as soon as possible.
  3. Administer bicarbonate for metabolic acidosis.
  4. Institute cooling measures (lavage, cooling blanket, cold intravenous solutions).
  5. Treat severe hyperkalemia with dextrose, 25–50 g intravenously, and regular insulin, 10–20 units intravenously (adult dose).
  6. Administer antiarrhythmic agents if needed despite correction of hyperkalemia and acidosis.
  7. Monitor end-tidal CO2 tension, electrolytes, blood gases, creatine kinase, serum myoglobin, core temperature, urinary output and color,and coagulation status.

Malignant hyperthermia is a condition in which the patient develops sustained muscle contraction and hyperthermia. It occurs following the administration of succinylcholine and other inhaled anesthetics like halothane, isoflurane, sevoflurane, desflurane, etc. It is due to the mutation of the gene for the ryanodine receptor (Ryr 1), located on chromosome 19.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia include inhaled general anesthetics (Ether, Halothane, Methoxyflurane, Enflurane, Isoflurane, Desflurane, Sevoflurane) and succinylcholine.

Clinical features include muscle rigidity, tachycardia, unexplained hypercarbia, and increased temperature. Hypertension may be rapidly followed by hypotension and cardiac depression. Dark-colored urine typically identifies myoglobinuria.

Laboratory testing typically reveals mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis with a marked base deficit, hyperkalemia, hypermagnesemia, and reduced mixed-venous oxygen saturation.

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has a therapeutic role in cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Amiloride can be administered to patients with cystic fibrosis to enhance mucus clearance through the action of cilia and coughing, thereby slowing down the deterioration of lung function.

When delivered as an aerosol, it improves the symptoms of cystic fibrosis by increasing the fluidity of respiratory secretions. The administration of amiloride reduces the abnormal absorption of sodium and water that is commonly observed in the airway epithelium of individuals with cystic fibrosis. This, in turn, is believed to enhance the flow properties of mucus in the airways, facilitating its clearance and promoting better mucus movement.

Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks epithelial sodium channels in collecting tubules. Therefore, it reduces sodium retention and potassium wasting. 

It is used to treat Liddle's syndrome, combined with loop or thiazide diuretics to prevent hypokalemia, lithium-induced polyuria, and edema associated with congestive heart failure, liver cirrhosis, and chronic kidney disease. Its toxicity can cause hyperkalemic metabolic acidosis.

Other options:

Option A- Furosemide is a loop diuretic and acts by inhibiting the Na-K-2Cl- transporter in the ascending loop of Henle. Used in cases of acute pulmonary edema, hyponatremia, hypercalcemia, and hypertension.

Option C- Spironolactone is an aldosterone antagonist. Used in cases of hypertension, primary hyperaldosteronism, and polycystic ovary disease

Option D- Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic and acts by the inhibition of the Na+/Cl- transporter in the distal convoluted tubule. Used in cases of hypertension, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, and kidney stones caused by calcium crystals.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with bone pain. He is found to have  diabetes insipidus and lytic lesions  are seen in the skull X ray. Electron microscopy reveals tennis racket-shaped structures. What is the gene and the signaling pathway involved in this disease?
questions.solution:
Bone pain, diabetes insipidus, and lytic lesions in the skull with tennis racket-shaped structures (Birbeck granules) is suggestive of Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH). Mutation in the BRAF gene leading to activation of the MAPK signaling pathway is the most likely cause of the abnormal proliferation of these cells.

LCH is driven by the abnormal proliferation of Langerhans-like cells, which are part of the immune system. Men are more affected than women. This mutation causes the uncontrolled growth and expansion of Langerhans cells, which infiltrate various organs, including bones, skin, and endocrine glands.

Patients present with pain and swelling over the affected areas. Commonly affected sites are the skull, pelvis, femur, and mandible. Radiographs usually show lytic lesions. In the skull, lesions appear as a hole within a hole, and in the vertebra, vertebra plana (flattening of the vertebral body) can be seen. 

Histopathologically, it is characterized by the presence of Langerhans cells. The tumor cells contain abundant cytoplasm with folded or grooved nuclei. Ultrastructurally, they contain tennis-racket-shaped intracytoplasmic inclusions called Birbeck granules. The tumor cells specifically express HLA-DR, S-100, CD1a, and langerin (CD207) markers.

Irregular radiolucent areas mostly involving superficial alveolar bone.

  • Permeative and aggressive appearing lesions occur
  • Mainly involves diaphysis or meta diaphysis
  • Endosteal scalloping, Periosteal reaction(in healing phase),cortical thinning,intracortical tunneling and associated soft tissue mass can be seen.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came with complaints of headache, impaired memory, and visual disturbances. He has a history of genital ulcers from many years ago for which he did not seek appropriate treatment. Further evaluation reveals CSF analysis positive for VDRL screening. Which of the following findings is observed in the pupils in response to light?

choices.text: Pupils react but do not accommodate.
Pupils accommodate but do not react.

questions.solution:
Pupils accommodate but do not react to light.

The clinical features of the patient are suggestive of neurosyphilis. The type of pupillary response seen in reaction to light is known as the Argyll Robertson pupil.

Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) is a feature of neurosyphilis that includes general paresis and tabes dorsalis. Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) results from damage to the relay paths in the tectum between the afferent and efferent tracts that interrupt pupillary light reflex. But the ventral pathway of the pupillary near reflex is spared, resulting in an intact accommodation reflex. 

Clinical features in the eyes include an intact accommodation reflex, i.e eyes converge and constrict on seeing a near object. Light reflexes are absent, which means they do not constrict when exposed to bright light (i.e., they do not react to light). This is also known as light-near dissociation. These patients also have bilateral small irregular pupils. Optic atrophy is another common feature of tabes. 

Treatment of neurosyphilis is with aqueous crystalline penicillin G for 10–14 days or aqueous procaine penicillin G plus oral probenecid, both for 10–14 days. Patients who have penicillin allergy are desensitised and then treated with penicillin.

Related Pearl: Sympathetic and parasympathetic nerve supply to iris muscles

  • Dilator pupillae/radial muscle of iris: Sympathetic postganglionic nerves from cervical ganglion.
  • Constrictor pupillae/circular muscle of iris: Parasympathetic postganglionic nerves from ciliary ganglion (Edinger Westphal nucleus).

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant is brought to you for a routine check-up. On examination, the posterior fontanelle appears closed while the anterior fontanelle remains open and palpable. Which of the following is the most appropriate explanation for the current state of the fontanelles?

choices.text: Posterior fontanelle closes by 2-3 months of age and anterior fontanelle usually closes by 18-24 months of age
Both anterior and posterior fontanelles should have closed by 4 months, and delay in closure may indicate raised intracranial pressure
Anterior fontanelle should be closed by 4 months, while posterior fontanelle may remain open for up to 6 months
Closure of posterior fontanelle before 4 months is abnormal, and the infant may have craniosynostosis

questions.solution:
In a normally developing child, The posterior fontanelle closes by 2-3 months of age and the anterior fontanelle usually closes by 18-24 months of age.

Fontanelles, often referred to as “soft spots,” are key features of a newborn’s skull. There are six fontanelles present during infancy, with the anterior and posterior fontanelles being the most prominent. 

The anterior fontanelle is the largest, typically diamond-shaped with an average size of 2.1 cm, and closes by 18-24 months after birth. The posterior fontanelle is triangular and usually closes within 2-3 months after birth. 

Fontanelles offer valuable insight regarding the hydration status and intracranial pressure of the child. Common conditions associated with a larger anterior fontanelle or a delay in its closure include

  • Down syndrome
  • Achondroplasia
  • Congenital hypothyroidism
  • Rickets
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Trisomy 13 and 18

questions.text: The structure marked "?" in the image is composed of _____ cartilage.
questions.solution:
The structure marked "?" in the image is the thyroid cartilage, and it is composed of hyaline cartilage.

Thyroid cartilage is identified by the presence of superior and inferior horns, and its relation with the epiglottis and larynx. The given image shows a cut-open view of the larynx from the back, and here, the thyroid cartilage encases the larynx anteriorly. The stalk of the epiglottis is also seen attached to the inner surface of the thyroid cartilage.

Hyaline cartilage is made up of chondrocytes and matrix:

  • The chondrocytes in the deeper matrix are rounded in shape and may appear in groups of eight that originate from the mitotic divisions of a single chondroblast. These groups of cells are called isogenous cell aggregates or cell nests.
  • The important components of the matrix are type II collagen, aggrecan (proteoglycan), and chondronectin (glycoprotein).
  • The matrix that immediately surrounds the chondrocytes is basophilic and is known as the territorial matrix, whereas the matrix that is more distant from the cells appears pale and is known as the interterritorial matrix.

Hyaline cartilage is found at various sites:

  • Larger respiratory passages (nose, larynx, trachea, and bronchi)
  • Thyroid cartilage
  • Cricoid cartilage
  • Base of the arytenoid cartilage
  • Ventral end of ribs, where they articulate with the sternum
  • Epiphyseal plate of long bones
  • Articular cartilage of synovial joints 
  • Temporary skeleton in embryo

On microscopy, hyaline cartilage can be identified by the following characteristics:

  • Presence of chondrocytes within lacunae.
  • Group of two or more chondrocytes, which are known as isogenous cell aggregates or cell nests
  • Basophilic territorial matrix and pale interterritorial matrix
  • Presence of perichondrium with outer fibrous and the inner cellular layer

questions.text: A randomized control study was conducted on 100 people to determine the causes and effects of different hormones that increase insulin secretion. All of the following factors increase insulin secretion except?
questions.solution:
Somatostatin decreases insulin secretion. Acetylcholine, gastric inhibitory polypeptide (GIP), and arginine stimulate its release.

Somatostatin, also known as growth hormone-inhibitory hormone, is secreted by the delta cells of the islets of Langerhans. It acts locally to inhibit insulin and glucagon secretion, reducing tissue utilization of absorbed nutrients. The primary function of somatostatin is to prevent the rapid depletion of nutrients, ensuring their availability over an extended period.

Insulin, secreted by the pancreatic beta cells, responds to increased blood glucose levels by promoting glucose uptake, storage, and utilization. When blood glucose levels rise, insulin:

  • Enhances hepatic uptake of glucose, storing it as glycogen
  • Facilitates the conversion of excess glucose into fatty acids
  • Suppresses glycogen breakdown to maintain glucose homeostasis

Conversely, when blood glucose levels fall, insulin secretion decreases, activating phosphorylase to break down glycogen and release stored glucose into circulation.

Mechanism of Insulin Secretion

  1. Glucose Entry: Glucose enters pancreatic beta cells via GLUT-2 receptors.
  2. Phosphorylation: Inside the cell, glucokinase (rate-limiting enzyme) phosphorylates glucose to glucose-6-phosphate, which is then oxidized to generate ATP.
  3. Potassium Channel Closure: Increased ATP levels close ATP-sensitive potassium channels, leading to cell depolarization.
  4. Calcium Influx: Depolarization triggers the opening of voltage-gated calcium channels, causing Ca²⁺ influx.
  5. Insulin Release: Elevated intracellular Ca²⁺ levels stimulate the exocytosis of insulin-containing vesicles, releasing insulin into the bloodstream.

Other Options:

Option B: Acetylcholine stimulates M3 receptors, which increases Ca²⁺ , which leads to increased insulin. Hence, Acetylcholine promotes insulin secretion during the cephalic phase of digestion (before food intake).

Option C: GIP is an incretin hormone K-cells release in the small intestine in response to oral glucose intake. It binds to β-cell receptors and increases cAMP, which enhances insulin secretion.

Option D: Arginine is an amino acid that stimulates β-cells directly.

questions.text:
The graph below shows changes in the percentage of the filtered amount of substances remaining in the tubular fluid along the length of the nephron in the presence of vasopressin. Which of the following correctly identifies 1, 2, 3 and 4?
Curve 1 A- Glucose
Curve 2 B- Water
Curve 3 C- Urea
Curve 4 D- Creatinine
questions.solution:
The correctly matched order of graph lines is 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D.

The concentration of a filtered solute changes as it passes through the tubules. The tubular cells may remove the solute from the filtrate (tubular reabsorption), add more substance to the filtrate (tubular secretion), or do both. 

Curve 1 represents Glucose. Glucose is actively reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule via sodium-glucose transporters. Essentially, 100% of glucose is reabsorbed in a healthy kidney, so very little or no glucose should appear in the urine.

Curve 2 represents Water. Vasopressin increases the permeability of the collecting ducts to water by promoting the insertion of aquaporins. In the presence of vasopressin, more water will be reabsorbed, and its concentration will decrease as it moves through the nephron, particularly in the proximal tubule and descending limb of the loop of Henle. The curve representing water will gradually decrease as it moves along the nephron.

Curve 3 represents Urea, which is reabsorbed passively and increases in concentration as it passes through the nephron. Initially, urea concentration remains relatively low in the proximal convoluted tubule. As the filtrate moves through the loop of Henle and the distal tubule, the urea concentration gradually increases because of continued water reabsorption by vasopressin. In the collecting ducts, vasopressin stimulates urea transporters (UT-A1 and UT-A3), which enhance urea reabsorption. 

Curve 4 represents Creatinine, which does not undergo reabsorption or secretion, so its concentration remains unchanged throughout the nephron.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is responsible for the citrullination of histones, during the formation of neutrophil extracellular traps?
questions.solution:
Arginine deaminase is responsible for the citrullination of histones, during the formation of neutrophil extracellular traps.

The initiation of neutrophil extracellular trap (NET) formation involves the activation of an arginine deaminase through reactive oxygen species (ROS), which converts arginine into citrulline, resulting in the decondensation of chromatin structure. Subsequently, additional enzymes produced in activated neutrophils, like myeloperoxidase (MPO) and elastase, penetrate the nucleus and induce further chromatin relaxation. This process eventually leads to the disruption of the nuclear membrane and the release of chromatin.

NETs are networks of extracellular fibers that consist of a viscous meshwork of nuclear chromatin. They trap microbes at sites of infection, preventing their further spread. They also contain a high concentration of antimicrobial proteins like neutrophil elastase, cathepsin G, and histones that have a high affinity for DNA.

They are produced by neutrophils in response to the following triggers:

  • Pathogens - Mainly bacteria and fungi
  • Inflammatory mediators -
    • Chemokines
    • Cytokines (mainly interferons)
    • Complement proteins
    • Reactive oxygen species

NETs have also been detected in the blood during sepsis. In this condition, platelet activation is involved in the NET formation. The nuclear chromatin in the NETs is a source of nuclear antigens (histones and associated DNA) in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This triggers autoantibody production and further clinical manifestations.

Other options:

Option A: Superoxide dismutases (SODs) are present in various cell types and play a role in converting oxygen (O2) into hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). This group of enzymes consists of manganese-SOD, which is predominantly found in mitochondria, and copper-zinc-SOD, which is primarily located in the cytoplasm. Their function is to assist in the elimination of free radicals.

Option B: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are generated through the swift assembly and activation of a complex oxidase known as NADPH oxidase, or phagocyte oxidase. This oxidase facilitates the conversion of oxygen into superoxide anions.

Option C: Nuclear alterations in necrosis occur due to the degradation of DNA. One pattern involves the fading of chromatin basophilia, known as karyolysis, which likely occurs due to the enzymatic breakdown of DNA by endonucleases.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presented with complaints of fever and multiple joint pains with swelling for the past 10 days. He had a history of sore throat 4 weeks back. Cardiac murmur was heard on auscultation. The physician orders a blood test for titers of a particular antibody that is implicated in this condition. Which of the following tests is employed for this antibody assay?
questions.solution:
A latex agglutination test is employed for this antibody assay.

The clinical scenario is highly suggestive of a diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic fever. According to Modified Jones criteria for the diagnosis of Rheumatic fever, establishing evidence of antecedent streptococcal infection is needed whenever possible. Hence, an anti-Streptolysin O antibody titer (ASO) is ordered by the physician. ASO levels are best estimated by a Latex agglutination test. Antistreptolysin O antibody was detected before by neutralisation method but is now replaced by latex agglutination test.

Latex agglutination test uses polystyrene latex, which can be manufactured as uniform spherical particles 0.8-1.0 µm in diameter and can adsorb several types of antigens. Latex agglutination tests are used in the clinical laboratory to detect anti-streptolysin O (ASO), C-reactive protein (CRP), RA factor, human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), and many other antigens. 

Other options :

Option A: Slide flocculation test - It is a type of precipitation reaction between antigens & antibodies. In clinical practice, it is the principle behind VDRL and RPR tests for Syphilis.

Option C: Hemagglutination inhibition test -  It is a type of neutralisation test used in the diagnosis of viral infections like Influenza.

Option D: Complement fixation test - it is a type of antigen-antibody reaction that uses complements to interact with antibodies in the test serum. It is used in the diagnosis of Rickettsial infections.

questions.text: Which of the following formula would you use for measuring the estimated fetal weight in a pregnant woman with fetal head at station +2?

questions.solution:
The fetal weight can be measured by Johnson's formula which is [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-11] x 155 in grams for a fetus which is at station +2 (below the level of ischial spine).
