questions.text:
Lewy body dementia is the second most common neurodegenerative dementia after Alzheimer's disease. MIBG myocardial scintigraphy in Lewy body dementia shows?

MIBG - Iodine-123-meta-iodobenzylguanidine
questions.solution:
Iodine-123-meta-iodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) cardiac scintigraphy shows postganglionic sympathetic denervation in Lewy body dementia.

Biomarkers of Lewy body dementia are:

  • Polysomnogram shows REM sleep behaviour disorder with atonia
  • CSF shows decreased α-synuclein by RT-QuIC
  • MRI shows atrophy of the amygdala
  • 18- Fluoro deoxyglucose PET Scan shows hypometabolism in the occipital lobe and increase in posterior cingulate (cingulate island sign)
  • MIBG myocardial scintigraphy shows post-ganglionic sympathetic denervation
  • PET dopamine scan shows reduced dopamine transporter in the basal ganglia, particularly putamen

Lewy body dementia is the second most common type of dementia after Alzheimer's disease and vascular dementia. It is characterised by the protein deposition of Lewy bodies in the substantia nigra, limbic system, and cerebral cortex, comprising α-synuclein and ubiquitin. Thus, they are classified under synucleinopathies.

The image given below shows immunohistochemistry showing positive staining (brown) for alpha-synuclein of an intraneural Lewy body:

The core clinical features are:

  • Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.
  • Recurrent visual hallucinations are typically well-formed and detailed.
  • REM sleep behaviour disorder may precede cognitive decline.
  • One or more spontaneous cardinal features of Parkinsonism (bradykinesia, rest tremor, rigidity).
  • Sensitivity to neuroleptics - severe adverse reactions if treated with antipsychotics

Other features are mood disorders like depression, anxiety and autonomic disturbances like orthostatic hypotension and constipation.

The mainstay of treatment here is symptomatic management, which includes cholinesterase inhibitors (rivastigmine, galantamine, or donepezil), atypical antipsychotics, and SSRIs. Highly potent typical antipsychotics like haloperidol are contraindicated in this condition due to extreme neuroleptic sensitivity.

questions.text: Given below are the entry inhibitors that are used in antiretroviral therapy. Which of the following is active against only the CCR-5 tropic virus?
questions.solution:
Maraviroc is an entry inhibitor that is active against only CCR-5 tropic strains. 

Maraviroc is approved for use in HIV-infected adults who have baseline evidence of predominantly CCR5-tropic virus. The drug has no activity against viruses that are CXCR4-tropic or dual-tropic.

The entry of HIV into target cells involves sequential binding of the virus to both a main receptor (CD4) and a chemokine co-receptor (CCR5 or CXCR4), followed by membrane fusion and release of virion contents into the cytoplasm.

Entry inhibitors: The four drugs available in this class have different mechanisms of action. 

  • Fostemsavir binds to the virus envelope protein gp120 and prevents binding to CD4.
  • Ibalizumab, a monoclonal antibody, binds to host CD4 and thus prevents viruses from entering target cells.
  • Maraviroc is a chemokine receptor antagonist and binds to the host cell CCR5 receptor to block the binding of viral gp120.
  • Enfuvirtide inhibits the fusion of the viral and cell membranes mediated by gp41 and CD4 interactions. Not active against HIV-2

Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors Inhibits reverse transcriptase by binding to an allosteric site of the enzyme
Protease inhibitors Inhibits the viral protease enzyme necessary to produce mature virions upon budding from the host membrane.

Interferes with binding, fusion, and entry of HIV -1 into the cell by blocking a target.

questions.text:
An adolescent presents with severe pain in the left upper abdomen with radiation to the left shoulder for the past few hours. Vitals are given below. His recent medical records reveal that the Monospot test was positive. What is the treatment of choice?

BP: 90/60 mmHg
PR: 120 bpm
RR: 24/min
Temp: 99 degrees F
SpO2: 92%
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points towards splenic rupture in a case of infectious mononucleosis and the treatment of choice is immediate splenectomy.

Left upper quadrant pain that radiates to the left shoulder points towards a splenic pathology and with unstable vitals, splenic rupture is the likely diagnosis. Monospot test (Paul-Bunnell test) detects heterophile antibodies in the blood that are produced in response to the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

Infectious mononucleosis due to either EBV or cytomegalovirus infection imparts a risk of spontaneous rupture of the spleen in both adults and children. The pathophysiological mechanism is infiltration of the splenic parenchyma with inflammatory cells, which distorts the architecture and fibrous support system of the spleen and thins the splenic capsule. Splenic rupture can occur spontaneously or after a minor trauma or even a Valsalva maneuver. 

A splenic abscess not on the verge of rupture is managed with broad-spectrum antibiotics for 2 weeks empirically which can later be modified based on the culture reports. Splenic abscess presents with fever, left upper quadrant pain, leucocytosis, and splenomegaly. Presentation is usually delayed by around 2 weeks. USG/CT aid in making the diagnosis. Splenectomy is the operation of choice, but percutaneous and open drainage are options for patients who cannot tolerate splenectomy.

questions.text: The method of asphyxia shown in the given image is ______
questions.solution:
The given image is characteristic of mugging where strangulation is caused by holding the neck of the victim in the bend of the elbow.

In this case, the pressure is put upon the neck by the arm held around the throat. The attack is usually made from behind, with the neck being trapped in the crook of the elbow and pressure exerted when the front and sides of the larynx. 

A diffuse abrasion is seen along the margin of the jaw due to the friction of the forearm. Death can occur due to asphyxia or reflex cardiac arrest

Other options:

Option A: Garrotting involves attacking the victim from behind using a ligature. The ligature is thrown around the unaware victim’s neck and then tightened with the help of two sticks tied at the free ends of the string. Earlier in Spain, garroting was also an official method of execution of criminals.

An image of the execution of a prisoner by garroting is shown below

Option B: Throttling or manual strangulation is defined as compression and strangulation with bare hands. 

Effects of pressure on the neck due to manual strangulation are:

  • Carotid artery blockage resulting in loss of consciousness
  • Carotid sinus pressure causing vagus nerve stimulation and cardiac arrest
  • Airway blockages causing hypoxemia 

The given autopsy images showing carotid intimal tear and muscle hematoma with nail marks on the neck and absence of ligature mark point towards a diagnosis of throttling.

Option D: Smothering is defined as a form of asphyxia where the external respiratory orifices are closed either by the hand or by other means or blocking up the cavities of the nose and mouth by the introduction of a foreign substance.

The image shows smothering, which involves the blockage of the external air passages, usually by a hand or soft fabric/pillow.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of new-onset left-sided chest pain. He had a recent history of a viral infection. ECG showed diffuse ST elevation with upward concavity and echocardiography detected a pericardial effusion. What is the finding that can be seen on the chest radiograph of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of pericardial effusion as a result of acute pericarditis. The chest radiograph may show a water-bottle configuration due to enlargement of the cardiac silhouette because of the pericardial effusion.

Pericardial effusion is usually associated with chest pain and/or the ECG changes of pericarditis (widespread ST elevation, often with upward concavity). If the effusion is large, the ECG may show electrical alternans. Heart sounds may be faint, friction rub, and the apical impulse may not be audible.

Echocardiography is a widely used imaging technique that allows localization and estimation of the quantity of pericardial fluid.

The chest X-ray shows an enlargement of the cardiac silhouette- water-bottle configuration. It may be normal in small effusions. The lateral radiograph may show the oreo cookie sign. It is a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line (paracardial fat) directly behind the sternum anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical line (epicardial fat) posteriorly. 

CT and MRI are indicated when echocardiography is inconclusive, when the effusion is loculated or hemorrhagic or if there is pericardial thickening.

A water bottle configuration on a chest X-ray is shown below.

Other options:

Option B: A boot-shaped heart is seen in patients with Tetrology of Fallot. It refers to the appearance of an upturned cardiac apex due to right ventricular hypertrophy. 

Option C: Batwing appearance is seen in pulmonary edema. It refers to the appearance of perihilar consolidation.

Option D: The figure 3 sign is seen in the aortic coarctation. It is formed by pre-stenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and indentation of the left subclavian artery at the coarctation site and post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought by his parents with complaints of marked regression of developmental milestones, which occurred particularly after 2 years of age. They also complain about his poor social skills, restricted activity, and poor language development. Based on your diagnosis, identify the wrong statement.

choices.text: Microcephaly is present in the child

questions.solution:
Poor social skills, restricted activity, poor language development, and regression of milestones point toward Heller syndrome. Microcephaly is not seen in Heller Syndrome. It is seen in Rett syndrome.

Heller syndrome is also known as Childhood disintegrative disorder. Key features include:

  • Presents at 3–5 years of age
  • Seen in boys
  • Regression of developmental milestones after two years of age
  • Loss of language and social skills
  • Stereotyped movements and compulsive behavior.
  • Intellectual disability
  • Poor bowel and bladder control
  • Associated with seizures

Rett’s syndrome is an X-linked disease that occurs predominantly in females and is characterized by stereotypic motions (hand wringing), developmental regression, and microcephaly. In Rett Syndrome, regression starts later than 5 months. Clinically, development may proceed normally until 1 year of age, when regression of milestones and acquired microcephaly become apparent.

questions.text: A patient presents with left head tilt. On examination, he was having right hypertropia, and the deviation increased on looking towards the left side. Which of the following extraocular muscles is most likely to be paralysed?
questions.solution:
The most likely paralysed muscle in the given clinical scenario is Right Superior Oblique.

This concept is based on the Park-Bielschowsky three-step test, which is used to diagnose the muscle paralysis responsible for vertical eye deviation.

Step 1: Identify the hypertropic eye

  • Firstly, identify the hypertropic eye in the primary position. In this case, the right eye is hypertropic.
  • This implies that either one of the two depressors of the right eye or one of the two elevators of the left (hypotropic) eye is weak. 
  • So the weak muscles could be left superior rectus, left inferior oblique, right superior oblique or right inferior rectus. Hence, Option B and C are ruled out.

Step 2: Observe if deviation worsens in specific gazes

  • Ask the patient to look horizontally right and then left and see in which position the deviation is more.
  • Remembering that the deviation increases in the direction of action of the paralysed muscle, identify which two of the four muscles are likely to be affected.
  • In this case, the deviation increases on looking towards the left side, which means that either the right superior oblique (that helps in abduction) or the left superior rectus (that helps in adduction) is paralysed.

Step 3: Determine the worsening of deviation in head tilts

  • With the left head tilt, the right eye will extort while the left eye will intort. 
  • Right superior oblique palsy will present as right eye extorsion
  • Left superior rectus palsy will present as left eye extorsion

Hence, in this case, the patient will have Right superior oblique muscle palsy.

Other options:

Option B: Paralysis of the left inferior rectus would result in left hypertropia.

Option C: Paralysis of the left superior oblique would cause left hypertropia.

Option D: Paralysis of the right inferior rectus would lead to a right hypertropia that worsens in the right gaze (due to impaired downward movement of the right eye) and will present as right eye intorsion.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old woman is diagnosed with a grade 2 invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast. Her biopsy report reveals the findings below. She has no lymph node involvement or distant metastases. The oncologist is considering adjuvant systemic therapy. How does the Ki-67 index influence the treatment plan for this patient?

ER/PR: Positive
HER2: Negative (IHC 1+)
Ki-67 index: 35%

choices.text: Indicates the need for chemotherapy due to high proliferation
Suggests that the tumor is HER2-positive despite IHC results
Rules out the need for hormonal therapy
Determines the need for breast conservative therapy

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a woman with invasive ductal carcinoma and a Ki-67 index of 35% indicates the need for chemotherapy due to high proliferation.

Ki-67 is a protein expressed during the active phases of the cell cycle (G1, S, G2, and M phases) but absent during the resting phase (G0 phase). Therefore, its presence in a tumor sample indicates that the tumor cells are actively proliferating. The Ki-67 index is calculated by determining the percentage of tumor cells that express Ki-67, which correlates with the tumor's growth rate.

  • High Ki-67 Index (above 30%): Indicates high proliferation and aggressive tumor behavior. High Ki-67 tumors are often more responsive to chemotherapy but may also have a worse prognosis.
  • Low Ki-67 Index (below 5%): This index indicates low proliferation, meaning the tumor is growing slowly. A lower Ki-67 index is usually associated with a better prognosis.

Ki-67 plays a crucial role in predicting and monitoring the response to chemotherapy.

Other options:

Option B: HER2-Status: Ki-67 does not correlate with HER2 positivity; HER2 status is determined independently by IHC or FISH.

Option C: Hormonal Therapy: High Ki-67 does not negate the benefit of hormonal therapy; it complements it in cases requiring combination therapy.

Option D: Determines the need for breast conservative therapy: Surgical decisions (breast conservative therapy vs modified radical mastectomy) are based on tumor size, location, and breast anatomy, not on Ki-67.

questions.text: A patient undergoes infertility evaluation and is diagnosed to have a Mullerian duct anomaly, namely Uterus Didelphys. What is the most probable per-vaginal examination finding?
questions.solution:
On per-vaginal examination, Uterus Didelphys presents with a longitudinal vaginal septum and two cervices each leading into separate uterine cavities.

On PV examination longitudinal vaginal septum of varying length and duplicated cervices may be felt.TVS/HSG act as diagnostic tools, and in case of any confusion, MRI can help confirm the diagnosis of uterus didelphys. The uteri are separate, and each has its endocervical canal and fallopian tube with no communication. A longitudinal septum may also be felt in the bicornuate uterus.

Uterus didelphys can be diagnosed antenatally by the presence of hydrometrocolpos, which is seen as renal agenesis and cystic pelvic mass on an AN scan.

Complications of pregnancy in a female with didelphys uterus include miscarriages, malpresentation, and preterm birth. Treatment is surgical in the form of metroplasty where fundal recombination is attempted.

Other options:

Option A: Transverse vaginal septum is not associated with uterus Didelphys. If not perforate, it can obstruct labor.

Option C: Circumferential ridge and transverse septum in vagina/cervix and cervical collar are all associated with Diethylstilbestrol associated Mullerian anomalies.

Option D: Upper vaginal agenesis is associated with Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser Syndrome, where concomitant uterine hypoplasia or agenesis is also seen.

questions.text: A patient with fever, subcutaneous nodules over the extensor surfaces, migratory polyarthritis, and chest pain had a throat infection 2-3 weeks back.  A biospy of the heart showed the below lesion. What is the lesion composed of?

choices.text: T lymphocytes, B lymphocytes, and plasma cells
T lymphocytes, plasma cells, and activated macrophages
Streptococci, T lymphocytes, and activated macrophages
Streptococci, T lymphocytes, and B lymphocytes

questions.solution:
The clinical features in this patient are suggestive of acute rheumatic fever. The most likely lesion shown in the biopsy specimen of acute rheumatic carditis is Aschoff's body, which are composed of T lymphocytes, plasma cells, and activated macrophages.

Aschoff's bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, occasional plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence, they are also called caterpillar cells.

This condition classically occurs a few weeks after an episode of group A streptococcal pharyngitis or, less commonly, skin infections. The antibodies to streptococcal cell-wall antigen cross-react with myocardial antigen, resulting in complement activation and recruitment of neutrophils and macrophages. Cytokine production by the stimulated T cells leads to macrophage activation.

questions.text: In which of the following types of diarrhoea would a patient's symptoms be likely to improve with fasting?
questions.solution:
Osmotic diarrhoea ceases with fasting.

Based on the mechanism by which it occurs, diarrhoea is classified broadly as secretory or osmotic.

Osmotic diarrhoea occurs when the contents in the gut contain osmotically active substances that draw fluid into the lumen resulting in loose stools. The presence of these contents may be due to ingestion of certain types of food, such as dairy products in the case of lactose intolerance, or abuse of drugs like osmotic laxatives. The patient's symptoms tend to subside once the inciting osmotic solute is removed. Osmotic diarrhoea is associated with a high stool osmotic gap.

Secretory diarrhoea (Option A) occurs due to an abnormality in fluid and electrolyte transport across the enteric mucosa. Clinically, it is differentiated from osmotic diarrhoea by the persistence of diarrhoea even after fasting and lack of stool osmotic gap. Secretory diarrhoea is typically watery, with large volume, and commonly occurs due to infective pathology, such as seen in cholera.

Although there may be some overlap in the mechanism, diarrhoea is also categorised as follows:

  • Inflammatory (Option B) - characterized by pain, fever and bleeding along with diarrhoea. eg - inflammatory bowel disease
  • Steatorrheal - loose stools which are foul-smelling, greasy and difficult to flush, occurring to various causes of fat malabsorption. eg -  pancreatitis, abetalipoproteinemia
  • Iatrogenic - following surgery such as vagotomy, bariatric surgery, or terminal ileal resection.
  • Factitious (Option D)  - in the case of eating disorders or psychiatric illness where the patient abuses laxatives or intentional contamination of stool with water
  • Motility disorders - such as autonomic neuropathy in diabetic adults

questions.text: According to the Maternity Benefits (Amendment) Act 2017, expectant mothers are given maternity leave for how many weeks?
questions.solution:
According to the Maternity Benefits (Amendment) Act, 2017, expectant mothers are given maternity leave for 26 weeks.

The Maternity Benefits (Amendment) Act, 2017, governs maternity leave entitlements in India. The act enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave and introduced new provisions for different scenarios.

Category of Leave Entitlement
Regular maternity leave (1st or 2nd child) 26 weeks (up to 8 weeks before delivery)
Maternity leave (3rd child or beyond) 12 weeks
Adoptive or commissioning mothers 12 weeks from the date of child handover
Miscarriage or Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) 6 weeks
Tubectomy operation 2 weeks

 

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: The inhibition of xanthine oxidase by allopurinol is also observed in the mineral deficiency of?
questions.solution:
Molybdenum deficiency leads to the reduced function of the enzyme xanthine oxidase. 

Xanthine oxidase is a molybdenum-containing enzyme that oxidizes hypoxanthine to xanthine and then to uric acid. Molybdenum is a crucial cofactor for this enzyme, and its deficiency can impair its function. Allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, mimics this effect by reducing uric acid production. A deficiency of molybdenum can similarly reduce xanthine oxidase activity, leading to an accumulation of hypoxanthine and xanthine.

The average daily dietary intake of molybdenum is 100 mg. The majority of the molybdenum absorbed is eliminated in the urine. Higher protein and cysteine intake will result in increased molybdenum excretion. Molybdenum is found in cereals. The liver has the highest concentration of Mo in the body. 

Excessive molybdenum consumption can lead to the development of molybdenosis, a condition distinguished by stunted growth, hematological deficiencies, and gastrointestinal disturbances. Copper and cysteine have been found to effectively remove molybdenum from the human body, lowering its toxicity. Elevated concentrations of molybdenum in dietary sources can hinder the assimilation of copper. A molybdenum deficiency has been found to correlate with a higher occurrence rate of esophageal cancer.

Other examples of minerals as cofactors :

  • The cofactor of glutathione peroxidase is selenium. (Option A)
  • The cofactor of carbonic anhydrase is zinc. (Option B)
  • The cofactor of glycosyltransferases is manganese. (Option D)
  • The cofactor of lysyl oxidase is copper.

questions.text: How does the dependency ratio of a country with the given population pyramid compare to that of India at present?
questions.solution:
The given population is that of a developed country with a bulge in the middle. This country will have a more economically productive age group (15-64) and a less dependent population (people above 65 and children below 15), so the dependency ratio will be lower than India's.

Dependency ratio: In any given population, persons over 65 and children under 15 are considered dependents. The total dependency ratio is the ratio of the combined dependent population to all individuals in the 15 – 65 age group, calculated using the formula below. It is also called the societal dependency ratio.

The total dependency ratio can also be divided into the young-age dependency ratio and the old-age dependency ratio. 

The demographic bonus denotes the decline in the dependency ratio due to declining fertility. The demographic burden is used to denote the increase in the total dependency ratio over any period of time, which is mostly caused by an increased old-age dependency ratio.

Related Pearl: Population Pyramid

  • The age or population pyramid is used to represent the age/sex structure of a population.
  • Below is the age pyramid of India (2017).
  • The age pyramid of India has a broad base and a tapering top, as it is with most developing countries.
  • As a nation develops the lower portion of the pyramid will start constricting and the upper portion will start increasing. 
  • Developed countries usually will have a bulge in the middle with a narrow base, as shown below in the age pyramid of Switzerland.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with episodes of sudden-onset vertigo accompanied by hearing loss in the right ear. Upon further inquiry, the patient also reports occasional ringing sound in the ear. What are the anticipated findings in pure tone audiometry and tuning fork test?

choices.text: Downsloping Audiogram and Weber’s test lateralized to Left ear
Upsloping Audiogram and Weber’s test lateralized to Right ear
Downsloping Audiogram and Weber’s test lateralized to Right ear
Upsloping Audiogram and Weber’s test lateralized to Left ear

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Meniere’s disease or Endolymphatic hydrops. In Meniere’s disease, an upsloping curve is seen in pure tone audiometry, and Weber’s test is lateralised to a better ear (in this case, the left ear).

Pure tone audiometry seen in Meniere’s disease is shown below:

Meniere's disease occurs due to increased production or decreased drainage of endolymph, leading to increased volume and distension of the endolymphatic system. Clinical features include episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and fullness of the ear. 

Rinne's test is positive, and Weber's test shows lateralization to the better ear, suggestive of sensorineural hearing loss. Pure tone audiometry (PTA) will reveal sensorineural hearing loss. Initially, the lower frequencies are affected, resulting in a 'rising' curve. Later in disease progression, higher frequencies are affected, leading to a 'flat' or 'falling' curve.

Special audiometry tests will help confirm that the pathology is in the cochlea and differentiate it from retro cochlear lesions. The recruitment test will be positive, the short increment sensitivity test (SISI) will be better than 70% in two-thirds of the patients (normal is 15%), and the tone decay test will be abnormal (normally less than 20 dB decay). 

Acute attacks can be treated with bed rest and vestibular sedatives like dimenhydrinate, promethazine, theoclate, or prochlorperazine. 

Chronic management involves vasodilators (betahistine) and diuretics. Treatment of Meniere's disease includes reassurance, smoking cessation, dietary salt not exceeding 1.5-2.0 g/day, and avoiding excessive water, coffee, tea, and alcohol intake. 

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

A few hours later, she complains of headache, difficulty in breathing, and palpitations. Her vitals and chest x-ray are given below. Which tocolytic agent was most likely administered?

Pulse rate - 122/minute

Preterm labor and delivery (labor starts before the 37th completed week, counting from the first day of the last menstrual period) can be delayed by drugs in order to improve the perinatal outcome. A short-term delay of 48 hours allows the use of corticosteroids that can reduce perinatal mortality and serious morbidity significantly.

questions.text: A patient presents with chest pain and breathlessness. Examination reveals a systolic murmur and a low ejection fraction on echocardiography. A cardiac histological image is provided below. Which gene is most commonly mutated in familial cases of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology image showing ninja stars-like nuclei is suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), and familial DCM is most commonly associated with truncation mutation of the TTN gene, which codes for the intra-sarcomeric protein titin.

The genetic forms follow the autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance with variable penetrance.

Dilated cardiomyopathy is the morphological and functional progressive cardiac dilatation and systolic dysfunction. To be considered DCM, the heart should not have any primary valvular abnormalities.

Causes of DCM include:

  • Genetic factors (familial in 50% of cases)
  • Direct toxic effects of alcohol and its metabolites (acetaldehyde)
  • Previous history of viral myocarditis
  • Exposure to cardiotoxic drugs such as cobalt
  • Iron overload  (hemochromatosis)
  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy
  • Catecholamine effect causing Takotsubo cardiomyopathy 

Clinical features include the slow progression to congestive heart failure and symptoms and signs related to it. Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmias or progressive cardiac failures can occur. 

Histopathologically, myocytes will show hyperchromatic and highly distorted ninja star-like nuclei (non-specific finding).

Image showing histological findings in dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM)

Option A: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy shows mutation in myosin-binding protein C (MYBP-C) or β-myosin heavy chain (β-MHC/MYH7).

Option C: LMNA (Lamin A/C) is a gene that encodes for nuclear envelope. It is less commonly seen in dilated cardiomyopathy. 

Option D: TNNT2 (Troponin T2) codes for cardiac Troponin.

questions.text:
An HIV-positive patient who is currently not on ART presents with headache and neck stiffness with a CD4+ T cell count of 90/μL. CSF examination reveals encapsulated yeast cells. Which amongst the following antifungal drugs is not useful in this patient?

ART- Anti-Retroviral Therapy
questions.solution:
Signs of meningitis such as headache & neck stiffness, and CD4 count of 90/μL in an HIV patient who is not on ART are suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis. Caspofungin has no role in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis.

Caspofungin acts by inhibiting the synthesis of β(1,3)-d-glucan by inhibiting the enzyme β(1,3)-d-glucan synthase. β(1,3)-d-glucan is a component of the fungal cell wall. The cell wall of Cryptococcus neoformans has more chitin and less β-1,3-glucan. So, caspofungin is not effective in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis.

Caspofungin is used for the treatment of candida infection and invasive aspergillosis. 

Cryptococcal meningitis is an AIDS-defining opportunistic fungal CNS infection that generally occurs in untreated patients with CD4+ T cell counts < 200/μL. Cryptococcus is an opportunistic fungus found worldwide as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings.

Infection is initiated by inhalation of the yeast cells. The primary pulmonary infection may be asymptomatic or may mimic an influenza-like respiratory infection, often resolving spontaneously. In immunocompromised, the yeasts may multiply and disseminate to other parts of the body, but preferentially to the CNS, causing cryptococcal meningoencephalitis. Other common sites of dissemination include the skin, adrenals, bone, eye, and prostate gland.

Clinical findings include:

  • Chronic meningitis (Headache, nuchal rigidity, disorientation)
  • CSF pressure, protein concentration, and cell count are elevated
  • Cutaneous ulcers, granulomata.   

The diagnosis is made by the identification of Cryptococcus neoformans yeast cells in CSF with India ink stain or by the detection of cryptococcal antigen using a latex agglutination test.

Fluconazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of Cryptococcosis without CNS involvement. For HIV-positive patients with cryptococcal meningitis, Induction is done with Liposomal Amphotericin B with Flucytosine for at least 2 weeks and Maintenance therapy consists of Oral Fluconazole.

Newer triazoles like voriconazole and posaconazole are highly active against cryptococcal strains and appear to be clinically effective.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of lower limb pain, constant dull headache, and difficulty hearing. He says that his bones feel thickened and warm to touch. An X-ray of the skull is shown below. Which of the following findings is seen on a vertebral x-ray?
questions.solution:
Bone pain, headache, difficulty hearing, and Tam o' Shanter sign on the skull radiograph are suggestive of Paget's disease. Ivory vertebrae is the finding seen on vertebral x-ray in a patient with Paget’s disease.

Osteitis deformans is also called Paget's disease of the bone. It is a chronic disease of increased bone turnover in localized areas, resulting in enlarged and thickened bones. There is a significant increase in both osteoclastic and osteoblastic activity. It is usually asymptomatic but can present with dull aching pain. Bowing of leg bones may occur. There is an increased risk of pathological fractures and osteosarcoma. A diffuse and homogenous increase in the vertebral body opacity referred to as the ivory vertebra is seen in Paget's disease.

Other Options:

Option A: Bullet Nose vertebrae is seen in Achondroplasia. 

Option B: Rugger jersey spine can be seen in osteopetrosis and Chronic Kidney disease - Metabolic Bone disease. X-ray shows alternating bands of sclerosis and lucency throughout, resembling a Rugger jersey.

Option C: Vertebra plana is seen in multiple myeloma and eosinophilic granuloma (children).

questions.text: A patient with ectopia lentis presents with the following signs. Which of the following is true about the inheritance pattern of this disease?
questions.solution:
Presence of Walker-Murdoch (wrist) sign and Steinberg (thumb) sign strongly favors Marfan syndrome, as these are part of the systemic criteria for Marfan diagnosis. Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition and shows a 50% chance of inheritance. It is the most common systemic condition associated with ectopia lentis. Ectopia lentis is present in 50 to 80 percent of cases.

Image (a) shows the Walker-Murdoch (wrist) sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist, and image (b) shows the Steinberg (thumb) sign - the thumb tip extends from the palm in a closed fist. These signs can occasionally be seen in Loeys-Dietz syndrome(LDS), however, ectopia lentis is not seen in LDS.

Marfan's syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder that is caused by a mutation in a gene that codes for an extracellular matrix protein-fibrillin-1 (FBN1). The FBN1 locus is on the long arm of chromosome 15. It is a clinical diagnosis based on skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular manifestations. 

Skeletal manifestations: 

  • Overgrowth of long bones (dolichostenomelia) with an arm span-to-height ratio of more than 1.05
  • Pectus carinatum or pectus excavatum
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly), flexion deformity of fingers (camptodactyly)
  • Malar hypoplasia
  • Joint laxity 

Cardiovascular manifestations:

  • Thickened atrioventricular valves, valvular prolapse leading to mitral regurgitation
  • Aortic valve dysfunction due to aortic root aneurysm
  • Aortic dissection and rupture due to cystic medial necrosis of the aorta

Ocular manifestations:

  • Ectopia lentis
  • Myopia
  • Flat cornea
  • Retinal detachments
  • Early cataracts and glaucoma

Other systemic manifestations: 

  • Thoracic scoliosis
  • Spontaneous pneumothorax
  • Striae atrophicae in the skin

Diagnosis is based on criteria depending on the family history, aortic root Z score, ectopia lentis, mitral valve prolapse, and presence of FBN1 mutation. The flow chart that follows can be used to determine the pattern of inheritance from a particular pedigree chart.

Other options: 

Option A: Females and Males both can be affected by Autosomal Dominant inheritance pattern.

Option B: In the Y-linked inheritance pattern, only males are affected.

Option C: In autosomal recessive inheritance, heterozygotes are unaffected whereas heterozygotes are affected in autosomal dominant diseases.

questions.text: An infant presented with anemia. A blood test was performed where 0.36% saline was added to the blood sample. The control and test results are shown below. What is this test used for?

choices.text: Testing spheroidal red cell in spherocytosis
Red cell lysis for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria

questions.solution:
The given image shows NESTROFT i.e. Naked eye single tube red cell osmotic fragility test. It is a very useful screening tool for thalassemia, particularly in poor resource settings.

The principle is based on the decreased osmotic fragility of red cells in thalassemia. The normal red blood cells lyse in a test tube with 0.36% saline solution. If this test tube is held against a white paper with a thin black line, the line will be visible. However, in the beta-thalassemia trait, due to decreased osmotic fragility, the cells do not lyse in 0.36% saline solution. Therefore, if this test tube is held against a white paper with a thin black line, the line will not be visible.

NESTROFT Inference Reason
Lines visible (negative) Normal Hemolysis has occurred
Lines not seen (positive) Thalassemia Stable RBC, unable to lyse

The image given below shows the NESTROFT.

Thalassemia is a group of hereditary disorders in which there is a reduced synthesis of one or more of the globin polypeptide chains.

The hematological findings in thalassemia are:

  • microcytic hypochromic anemia
  • raised unconjugated bilirubin
  • reticulocytosis
  • reduced MCV, MCH, and MCHC
  • decreased osmotic fragility
  • hemoglobin electrophoresis will show increased levels of HbF and HbA2 with markedly decreased levels of normal hemoglobin.

Other options:

Option A- Demonstration of sickling in sickle cell trait is done under reduced oxygen tension by sodium metabisulfite which is an oxygen-consuming reagent. The patients with sickle cell trait have no anemia and have normal-appearing red cells. They develop sickle cell crises in hypoxic conditions. 

Option C- Osmotic fragility test is helpful in testing the spheroidal nature of red cells in hereditary spherocytosis. In hereditary spherocytosis, osmotic fragility is increased since spheroidal red cells lyse more readily in solutions of low salt concentrations. 

Option D- Red cell lysis in acidic pH of Ham's test is to demonstrate the presence of increased sensitivity of red blood cells, leucocytes, and platelets to complement in PNH.

questions.text: Identify the type of astigmatism in a patient with refractive error of -4D sphere with +1D cylindrical at 90 degrees.

choices.text: Compound hypermetropic astigmatism against the rule
Compound myopic astigmatism against the rule
Compound hypermetropic astigmatism with the rule
Compound myopic astigmatism with the rule

questions.solution:
The type of astigmatism will be Compound myopic astigmatism with the rule.

The given refractive error is a -4D sphere with +1D cylindrical at 90 degrees. Consequently, light rays entering the eye cannot converge to a single point focus but form focal lines. This is known as astigmatism, a type of refractive error in which the refraction varies in different axes of the eye.

Step 1: A spherical power means the same power in both horizontal and vertical axes, while a cylindrical power works on the opposite axis of where it is kept. That means a +1D cylindrical power kept at 90 degrees will act on the horizontal axis at 180 degrees. For the horizontal axis, the calculation will be -4D + 1D = -3D. Therefore, the final refractive error of the patient will be -4D on the vertical axis and -3D on the horizontal axis.

After calculating the final refractive error, we can see this is Compound myopic astigmatism as light rays in both axes are focussed in front of the retina.

Step 2: The more myopic the axis, the steeper (that is, more curved) it will be. If the vertical axis is steeper than the horizontal axis, then it is known as with the rule astigmatism. Therefore, the given type of astigmatism is Compound myopic astigmatism with the rule.

Astigmatism is of two types - Regular and Irregular.

  • Regular astigmatism - The refractive power changes uniformly from one meridian to another.

It is of the following 4 types based on the axis:

a)With the Rule astigmatism - In this type, the two axes are perpendicular to each other, and the vertical axis is steeper than the horizontal axis (as seen in this case ).

b)Against the Rule astigmatism - The two axes are perpendicular to each other, and the horizontal axis is steeper than the vertical axis.

c)Oblique astigmatism - The two principal axes are not horizontal and vertical, though these are at right angles to each other

d)Bioblique astigmatism - The two principal axes are not at right angles to each other.

  • Irregular Astigmatism - It is characterised by an irregular change of refractive power in different axes. It could be curvatural or index.

Clinical features of astigmatism are :

  • Asthenopia
  • Blurred and defective vision
  • Elongation of objects proportionate to the degree and type of astigmatism 

Option A and C: Compound Hypermetropic Astigmatism is when the light rays are focussed behind the retina in both the horizontal and vertical axes.

questions.text: Three patients from a slum present with tender inguinal buboes. A public health officer identifies the above insect in their homes and ascertains it as the vector for the disease. What is the insect and an effective insecticide for it?
questions.solution:
The given organism is Xenopsylla cheopis, the Rat Flea, which is the vector for Yersinia pestis, the causative organism of Bubonic Plague, which can present with tender inguinal buboes. An effective insecticide for Rat fleas is DDT dust.

Xenopsylla cheopis or Rat flea is identified as a small bilaterally compressed insect without wings and 3 pairs of legs and covered in backward directed strong bristles. It also has a chitinous exoskeleton.Fleas have four stages in their life cycle: egg, larva, pupa, and adult. They live on their host and in its burrows, hideouts, cracks, and crevices, feeding about once daily.

Fleas are blood sucking insects with specific hosts. Xenopsylla cheopis, the Rat flea sucks blood off the Rat. Various flea indices are used to calculate the risk of a plague outbreak.

Plague is an ancient disease caused by the gram-negative coccobacillus with bipolar staining, Yersinia pestis. Plague is caused in humans by the bite of blocked fleas. Blocked fleas are fleas in whom the plague bacillus multiplies in enormous quantities, resulting in blocking of their gut and stimulating the flea to bite multiple times to obtain a blood meal.Plague has a wild and domestic cycle in rodents. Humans are usually accidental hosts.

It can manifest as Bubonic,Pneumonic or Septicaemic form. Treatment of choice is with Streptomycin, alternatively, Tetracycline may be used. Chemoprophylaxis is given with Tetracycline 500 mg 6 hourly for 5 days. Flea control is achieved using insecticides like DDT 10 percent dust or BHC 3 percent dust. DDT resistance has been documented in some flea populations. In resistant populations, Carbaryl or malathion may be used. Rodent control is very important in Plague outbreaks. Important anti-rodent measures include:

  1. Proper sanitation measures
  2. Rat trapping
  3. Use of rodenticides like Rat squill, Norbromide, Zinc phosphide, Strychnine, and Sodium fluoroacetate. Zinc phosphide is an effective and cheap poison employed all over India. It slowly releases phosphine gas, which has a garlicky odour and hence repels humans but has no effect on rats. When consumed by them, it kills in 3 hours. It must be handled with gloves due to its poisonous nature.

Diethyltoluamide is an effective flea repellant that can be used on clothes.

Other options:

Option B: Phlebotomus sergenti causes Oriental sore. The insecticide of choice for Phlebotomus is DDT.

Option C: Zinc phosphide is a rodenticide, not an insecticide.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

Related Pearl: Flea Indices

They are useful in measurements of density of fleas.

They include: 

  • Total flea index – it is the average number of fleas of all species per rat
  • Cheopis index - it is the average number of Xenopsylla cheopis species per rat,hence it is a specific flea index. It indicates the maximum explosiveness of the situation
  • Specific percentage of fleas – it is a precentage of different species of fleas that are found on rats.
  • Burrow index – It is the average  number of free living flea per species per rodent burrow.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent palpitation and lightheadedness. An ECG was taken and he was diagnosed with Wolff-Parkinson-White Syndrome (WPW Syndrome). What ECG changes are seen in this syndrome?

1. Narrow QRS complex
2. Delta waves
3. Short PR interval 
4. Long PR interval
questions.solution:
The changes seen in ECG of WPW syndrome are

  • Short PR interval (<120ms)
  • Slurring and slow rise of initial upstroke of QRS complex known as Delta waves
  • Wide QRS complex (>0.12 sec)

Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is defined as a pre-excited QRS during sinus rhythm and episodes of PSVT.

The main pathophysiology involved in this condition is conduction from the atrium to the ventricle with no AV nodal delay, which impairs adequate ventricular filling. This is due to an abnormal accessory electrical conduction pathway called the Bundle of Kent between the atria and ventricles.

Treatment includes : 

  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs from class Ia (Procainamide) and class III (Ibutilide)
  • Radiofrequency ablation of the aberrant pathway

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant is brought to your clinic for routine vaccination. During the visit, the mother expresses concern about her child’s developmental progress and asks if the baby’s milestones are on track. On examination, the developmental progress is normal. Which of the following would you expect the child to be able to do at this age?

choices.text: Build a tower of two cubes
Pretend to drink from a cup

questions.solution:
By 10 months, an infant pivots while sitting, and this provides increasing opportunities to manipulate several objects at a time and to experiment with novel combinations of objects.

When the baby can sit unsupported and can rotate his body to reach for objects is described as pivots while sitting. These explorations are aided by the emergence of a thumb-finger grasp at around 8 to 9 months and a neat pincer grasp at 12 months. A major milestone at 9 months is object permanence, the understanding that objects continue to exist even when not seen.

Stranger anxiety and a demand for autonomy also emerges between the period of 6 to 12 months. At about 9 months of age, infants become aware that emotions can be shared between people. They show toys to the parents as a way of sharing their happy feelings.

Other Options:

Option A: A child speaks 4-6 words at around 15 months of age.

Option B: Children can usually build a tower of two cubes by 15 months of age.

Option C: Children usually pretend to drink from a cup at 12 months of age as part of Egocentric symbolic play.

questions.text: An elderly male with deranged liver function comes to the OPD with complaints of difficulty falling asleep. The resident doctor chooses to administer lorazepam over diazepam. Which of the following forms the basis of this choice?

choices.text: Metabolised by both phase I and phase II reactions
Reduced formation of water soluble metabolites
Metabolised by phase I reaction only

questions.solution:
Lorazepam is chosen over diazepam in this patient because it tends to get metabolized by direct glucuronidation leading to no active metabolites thereby advocating its use in the elderly and those with liver failure.

Other drugs that may be used include the shorter-acting benzodiazepines- Oxazepam, Temazepam, and Estazolam. These benzodiazepines are rapidly converted to inactive water-soluble metabolites that will not accumulate. They are also metabolized by direct glucuronidation. For this reason, short-acting drugs are especially useful in alcoholic patients or elderly patients with liver disease. 

Long-acting benzodiazepines, including chlordiazepoxide and diazepam, are metabolized in the liver to produce active metabolites. They are metabolized by phase I (CYP3A4) and phase II (Glucuronidation). This is responsible for a long duration of action. A disadvantage of long-acting drugs is that they and their active metabolites may accumulate, especially in patients with compromised liver function.

Other options:

Option A: Long-acting benzodiazepines are metabolized by phase I and phase II reactions. 

Option B: With Lorazepam, there is an increased (not reduced) formation of water-soluble metabolites, thus aiding its faster excretion.

Option C: Lorazepam is metabolized by direct glucuronidation (phase II reaction).

questions.text: A primigravida woman underwent a normal vaginal delivery at her home following which she presented with a perineal tear as shown below. Identify the grade of perineal tear:
questions.solution:
The image showing a tear in the vaginal mucosa, perineal muscles, and more than 50% of the external anal sphincter is suggestive of a grade 3b perineal tear.

Perineal tears are common in primigravida women undergoing vaginal delivery.

The first-degree tears do not require repairs but suturing of laceration prevents the vaginal orifice from becoming patulous. Second-degree tears must be immediately sutured after the delivery of the placenta to prevent the weakening of the pelvic floor and genital prolapse. 

Third and fourth-degree tears must be efficiently repaired to prevent flatus and faecal incontinence. Such tears are common in median episiotomies, incorrect usage of forceps in a persistent occipitoposterior positioned fetus, delivery of aftercoming of breech, precipitate labour and delivery of macrosomic babies.

The best time for repair of a complete perineal tear is within 24 hours of the injury. If not done within 24hrs, it is preferably done 3-6 months after delivery. If the perineal tear is untreated for more than 6 months, dense scar tissue forms and making the surgery difficult.

questions.text: Which of the following index and its component is correctly matched?

choices.text: Physical quality of life index: Literacy rate
Human development index: Life expectancy at age 1
Physical quality of life index: Life expectancy at birth

questions.solution:
The literacy rate is a component of the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI).

The three components of PQLI are:

  1. Infant mortality rate
  2. Literacy rate
  3. Life expectancy at age 1

In the PQLI, each component is given a score of 0 to 100, where 0 is the worst performance and 100 is the best. The average of all three is taken, and then the PQLI is scored between 0 and 100. In India, PQLI is 65.

questions.text: Which of the following pathway is caspase-independent?
questions.solution:
Necroptosis is a caspase-independent pathway.

Necroptosis, as the name suggests has features similar to necrosis and apoptosis. Like necrosis, it is characterized by loss of ATP, cellular and organelle swelling, the release of lysosomal enzymes, and rupture of the plasma membrane. However, like apoptosis, this is programmed cell death. This is a caspase-independent programmed cell death. It is also called programmed necrosis.

Mechanism:

  • TNF-α activates TNFR1 and, in turn, induces the recruitment of RIP1 and RIP3 kinase and other proteins to form a complex.
  • This complex includes caspase 8. But, caspase 8 is not activated in this pathway.
  • RIPK3 phosphorylates a cytoplasmic protein called MLKL. On phosphorylation, MLKL monomers assemble into oligomers, translocate from the cytosol to the plasma membrane, and cause plasma membrane disruption.

Other options

Option C: Pyroptosis occurs due to the release of fever-inducing cytokine interleukin-1 (IL-1). Cytoplasmic innate immune receptors recognize microbial products that entered the infected cells and activate the multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. Inflammasome activates caspase 1 and helps in the release of the biologically activated forms of IL-1. Along with caspase 1, caspases 4 and 5 also induce cell death. Unlike classical apoptosis, pyroptosis is characterized by the release of inflammatory mediators. 

Options A and B: The intrinsic mitochondrial and extrinsic death receptor-initiated pathways converge to activate a caspase cascade that mediates the final phase of apoptosis. The intrinsic pathway activates caspase 9 whereas the extrinsic pathway activates caspases 8 and 10. These caspases then activate caspase 3, and caspase 6. Activated caspases cause DNA degradation and nuclei fragmentation.

questions.text: A forensic expert was asked to conduct an autopsy of an HIV-positive deceased man with a suspected homicidal death. He decides to do an in-situ in-part dissection followed by en block removal of the organs. Which of the following autopsy techniques is he following?
questions.solution:
The autopsy technique the forensic expert is following is the Rokitansky technique. 

In the Rokitansky technique, a local dissection (in-situ) is started from the neck and is trailed down followed by removing the organs as a block (en bloc). It is preferred in patients with highly transmissible diseases such as HIV or hepatitis B. 

A medicolegal autopsy is a postmortem examination of a body to ascertain evidence contributory to the cause of death. It is important to complete the autopsy in each and every case. This is done by examining all the organs and opening all the body cavities. 

Universal work precautions taken during the autopsy of an HIV-positive deceased are - 

  • All infected bodies should be wrapped and tied in double-layer plastic bags and tagged as biologically hazardous.
  • Workers having external injury or dermatitis should not handle the body.
  • Personal protective equipment should be worn.
  • Avoid accidental pricks and cuts from needles. 
  • Specimen should be properly labelled, filled with 10% formalin solution and handled with gloved hands.
  • Gauze and cotton should be collected in double plastic bags for incineration.
  • Instruments used for an autopsy should be dipped in 20% glutaraldehyde for 1/2 an hour, washed with soap or detergent and water dried and then rinsed with methylated spirit.
  • Freshly prepared sodium hypochlorite / 1:10 dilution bleach is used for disinfecting the autopsy room.
  • Electrical oscillating saw is used to open the cranial cavity to minimise aerosol splatter.
  • After the autopsy, all body orifices should be packed and body is wrapped in double plastic bags.
  • Body should be incinerated or burnt.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

Related Pearl: Autopsy: Types Of Incision

Type of incision Procedure Indication Advantage
I-Shaped Incision Extends from symphysis menti to symphysis pubis, taking a curve towards the left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice It is simple and convenient.
Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the acromial process on the shoulder on either side of the chest, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum and then run downwards as in the "I"-shaped incision   Preferred in females It prevents cutting of the chest skin in the midline.
Modified Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the angle of mandible on either side, brought forwards, downwards to meet at the suprasternal notch . It is then run downwards as a midline incision up to the pubic symphysis. Preferred when a detailed study of neck structures required, e.g. asphyxial death due to neck compression.  It has better exposure and allows the study of neck structures. 
Elongated X-shaped Incision Used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries.  Should be practiced in cases of custodial death.  Helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of organisms and the fever caused by them is not correctly matched?
questions.solution:
Spirillum minus causes Sodoku fever, also known as Spirillary rat-bite fever.

It has an incubation period of 1-4 weeks and is similar to the streptobacillary type, associated with fever, regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. Spirillum minus is gram-negative but is better visualised by Giemsa or Fontana stains or by dark field microscopy. 

Coxiella burnetti causes Q fever (Query fever). Infection can be acute or chronic. Acute disease includes influenza-like symptoms (fever, chills, headache), nonbacterial (atypical) pneumonia, and hepatitis. Chronic Q fever lasts more than 6 months. Infective endocarditis is the most common form of disease in this phase.

There is no vector involved in the transmission of the disease to man. Wild animals can be the primary reservoir, and it is transmitted among them and to cattle, sheep and poultry by Ixodid ticks. Human infection occurs through handling wool or hides, meat or other animal products contaminated with the organism. It is a gram-negative, pleomorphic coccobacillus.

Other options:

Option A: Streptobacillus monoliformis causes Haverhill fever, also known as Streptobacillary rat-bite fever. It develops 2–10 days after a rat bite, associated with sudden onset of fever, headache and myalgia followed by petechial rash and arthritis. It is a gram-negative, non-motile, pleomorphic bacillus.

Option B: Bartonella bacilliformis causes Oroya fever, also known as Carrion's disease. Oroya fever presents as fever and progressive anaemia due to bacterial invasion of erythrocytes. Bartonella bacilliformis is a pleomorphic, gram-negative rod and is seen inside erythrocytes and in the skin lesions.

Option C: Bartonella Quintana causes Trench fever, also known as Five-day fever and Shinbone fever. It is characterised by sudden onset of fever accompanied by headache, malaise, restlessness, and shin pain. It is an exclusively human disease transmitted by the body louse. It is a gram-negative bacilli.

questions.text: A person presents with the deformity shown in the picture and is unable to move the thumb away from the rest of the hand. Which of the following findings would you not expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with ape thumb deformity is suggestive of median nerve palsy. Egawa's test is positive in the ulnar nerve injury, not the median nerve injury.

In a positive Egawa test, due to the weakness of the dorsal interossei, side-to-side movements of the middle finger is weak.

A positive pen test is seen in median nerve palsy. It tests the abductor pollicis brevis. A pen is held above the palm and the patient is asked to touch the pen with his thumb. If the patient is unable to touch the pen it signifies a positive pen test.

Benediction hand sign (attempt to make a fist gives pointed index and middle finger) and Ochsner's clasping test (attempt to clasp both hands show pointing index finger) are also used to test median nerve injuries.

questions.text: A patient who has been diagnosed with hepatitis C infection now presents to the hospital with reddish-colored urine. Urine analysis was performed, and it shows proteinuria and the presence of red blood cells and leucocytes in the urine. A renal biopsy was performed, and the obtained sample was stained with periodic acid-Schiff (image A) and methenamine silver (image B). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is diagnosed with hepatitis C, presents with proteinuria, hematuria, and pyuria and histological examination shows the thickening and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane, giving rise to the tram-track appearance. The most likely diagnosis in this case is membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. 

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is immune-mediated glomerulonephritis characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) with mesangio-proliferative changes.

Types:

Type I MPGN is commonly associated with persistent hepatitis C infections, autoimmune diseases like SLE or cryoglobulinemia, or neoplastic diseases of the lung, breast, and ovary. 

Type II and type III are mediated by the complement pathways.

Histopathology:

On light microscopy, type I MPGN will show the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane. At some points, the GBM splits showing the tram track appearance. Electron microscopy will show the presence of subendothelial deposits.

Type II MPGN can also have GBM thickening and splitting. The glomerular tuft has a lobular appearance. On electron microscopy, it shows dense deposits. Subendothelial deposits are generally absent.

Type III MPGN is rare and shows focal mesangial proliferation. The image below shows the thickening and splitting of GBM.

Other options

Option A- Crescentic glomerulonephritis is seen in patients developing rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. In this, the serum creatinine levels increase very rapidly. Microscopy will show the presence of crescents within the glomeruli.

Option C - Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. It is usually a primary disease, but rarely can be associated with diseases like Hodgkin’s lymphoma, allergies, or the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents. Light microscopy appears normal. Electron microscopy may show the effacement of foot processes.

Option D - Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis manifests as proteinuria. It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It can be a primary disease or occur as a result of HIV, hepatitis B, hypertension, Alport syndrome, etc. The biopsy will show the focal and segmental scarring of the glomeruli.

questions.text: A woman is undergoing a staging laparotomy for an adnexal tumor. On opening the abdominal cavity, the surgeon notes that the peritoneal cavity is filled with coagulated material with a boiled sago/jelly-like appearance sticking to the omentum, intestines, and even the instruments. The appendix is also enlarged. What is the possible diagnosis?

choices.text: Hydatidiform mole in the  peritoneal cavity

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Pseudomyxoma peritonei, which is a complication of Mucinous cystadenoma of the ovary.

Ovarian surface epithelial neoplasms may be primarily serous or mucinous. Pseudomyxoma peritonei shows histological similarity to mucinous cystadenoma and is believed to be the peritoneal extension of the tumor. On staging laparotomy, pseudomyxoma peritonei presents a boiled sago appearance with sticky mucinous material filling the peritoneal cavity and coating the bowel.

It is difficult to completely remove all the sticky material, and recurrence is the norm, hence, the prognosis is poor. The appendix may be incidentally enlarged or may harbor a mucocele/mucinous tumor resulting in this condition.

Pseudomyxoma peritonei may also arise from mucinous appendicular tumors/mucoceles of the appendix and cancer of the colon in males. Furthermore, mucoceles of the appendix are believed to induce secondary ovarian tumors. The surgeon may thus remove the appendix along with the ovaries in suspected cases of mucinous cystadenoma.

Other options:

Option A: Ruptured hydatid cyst presents with anaphylaxis-like symptoms and does not produce coagulative material.

Option B: Ectopic molar pregnancy is exceedingly rare, and this is not its presentation.

Option D: Tuberculous ascites have a completely different presentation.

questions.text:
Which of the following are elements of primary healthcare?
  1. Adequate supply of safe water and basic sanitation
  2. Provision of essential drugs
  3. Prevention of locally endemic diseases
  4. Use of appropriate technology
  5. Ensure community participation
questions.solution:
The elements of primary health care include:

  1. Adequate supply of safe water and basic sanitation
  2. Providing essential drugs
  3. Prevention of locally endemic diseases

Primary health care refers to essential health care that is universally available to individuals, acceptable to them through their full participation, and at a cost the community and country can afford.

The use of appropriate technology and ensuring community participation are principles/pillars of Primary Health Care.

Related Pearl: Elements and Principles of Primary Health Care

A. Elements of Primary Health Care

(Mnemonic: ELEMENTS)

  • Education about health problems and their prevention and control
  • Locally endemic diseases – prevention and control
  • Essential drugs
  • Maternal and child health care
  • Expanded programme of immunization against vaccine preventable diseases
  • Nutrition and proper food supply
  • Treatment of common diseases and injuries
  • Safe water and sanitation

B. Principles/Pillars of Primary Health Care

  • Equitable distribution
  • Community participation
  • Intersectoral coordination
  • Appropriate technology

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with chronic pain and stiffness in his hands, knees, and hips. On examination of the hands, Heberden's and Bouchard's nodes are visible. His knee x-ray is given below. Which of the following joints is likely to be spared in this condition?

choices.text: Intervertebral joints in the lumbar region

questions.solution:
The given clinical history along with Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes on examination and reduced joint space on x-ray is suggestive of osteoarthritis. The wrist joint is likely to be spared in this condition.

Other joints that are usually spared in osteoarthritis are the elbow and ankle joints. 

Osteoarthritis is the most common cause of chronic knee pain in individuals of age >45 years. In the early phases, there is episodic joint pain following overactive use of the diseased joint. As the disease progresses, there is continuous pain and may be associated with stiffness of the affected joint. Morning stiffness if present, is usually brief for around 30 minutes.

The joints involved in osteoarthritis are: 

  • Distal and proximal interphalangeal joints (DIP, PIP)
  • First carpometacarpal joint (base of the thumb)
  • Hip and knee joints
  • First metatarsophalangeal joint (MTP)
  • Cervical and lumbosacral spine

Clinical signs: 

  • Tenderness and inflammation of the joint
  • Crepitus when the joint is moved
  • Bony swelling
  • Decreased and painful range of movement 
  • Deformity and instability in severe cases
  • Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes - palpable nodules in the DIP and PIP joints, respectively (as shown in the image below).

Characteristic features of OA seen on plain radiographs:

  • Marginal osteophyte formation
  • Localized joint space narrowing
  • Sclerosis of the underlying bone
  • Subchondral bone cysts

questions.text: A middle-aged man complains of sudden painless loss of vision as if a curtain fell before his eyes. He also experiences flashes of light. On examination, pigments are found on the anterior vitreous like tobacco dusted over the posterior wall of the cornea. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis from the clinical scenario is retinal detachment.

Retinal detachment is the result of the accumulation of fluid between the retina and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). Retinal detachment is classified into the following depending upon the fluid accumulation:

  • Rhegmatogenous
  • Tractional
  • Exudative

Risk factors include myopia, previous intraocular surgery such as aphakia or pseudophakia, a family history of retinal detachment, and trauma.

Clinical features include sudden painless loss of vision, flashes of light or photopsia, floaters in the eye, and curtains in the field of vision.

Examination findings will reveal:

  • Normal or slightly low intraocular pressure
  • Marcus Gunn pupil (relative afferent pupillary defect)
  • Altered red reflex on the distant direct ophthalmoscope
  • Indirect ophthalmoscopy may show grey reflex of the freshly detached retina or breaks in the retina 
  • Vitreous pigments on the anterior vitreous (Shaffer sign)
  • Shifting fluid sign- Change in the position of the detached area with a change in gravity is the hallmark of exudative retinal detachment.

Management of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment includes sealing of retinal breaks, reducing the vitreous traction on the retina, and flattening of the retina by draining the subretinal fluid. Scleral buckling, pneumatic retinopexy, and pars plana vitrectomy can help in maintaining the chorioretinal apposition. 

Treating the cause helps in exudative retinal detachment. Enucleation can be done if intranuclear tumors are present.

Other options:

Option A- Stargardt disease is the most common type of macular dystrophy. It presents as decreased vision in the first or second decade of life. Fundus examination will show beaten bronze or snail-slime reflex in the macular area.

Option B- Macular edema is the collection of fluid in the macula. It occurs due to the leakage from dilated capillaries. Slit lamp examination will show loss of the foveal reflex and thickening at or around the macula. Fluorescein angiography is used to identify the areas of leakage.

Option C- Eales disease is the inflammation of peripheral retinal veins leading to recurrent retinal hemorrhages. Patients will have a sudden painless loss of vision and floaters. The examination will show hemorrhage and vascularisation of the retina.
