questions.text: A 6-week-old boy presents with low-pitched inspiratory stridor, present since a few days after birth. It subsides with prone positioning and increases with crying.  The observation made on direct laryngoscopy is shown in the image below.  What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of inspiratory stridor since birth with omega-shaped epiglottis, as shown in the image, is suggestive of laryngomalacia. The next step in management is expectant observation.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx. In this condition, the supraglottic portion of the larynx is excessively flaccid and subsequently gets sucked in during inspiration. This results in inspiratory stridor, a feature typical of laryngomalacia. It subsides on placing the child in a prone position but increases with crying. 

Direct laryngoscopy shows an elongated epiglottis that is curled upon itself, making it appear omega (Ω)-shaped. Other features include floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids.

Treatment of laryngomalacia is mainly conservative, as it self-corrects by the time the child is 2 years of age. Tracheostomy may be required in some cases with severe respiratory obstruction. Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

Other options:

Options A & C: Endotracheal intubation and IV ceftriaxone are immediate management modalities of acute epiglottitis, which is a medical emergency. It is characterized by sore throat, dysphagia in adults, dyspnoea, and stridor in children, which are both rapidly progressive and associated with fever up to 40°C. Thumb sign, that is, a swollen epiglottis, is observed on a lateral view x-ray of the neck.

Option D: Nebulisation with racemic adrenaline is the immediate management of acute laryngotracheobronchitis. It is characterized by a low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and a barking cough.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

questions.text: A boy presents with a 4-day history of fever, headache, and irritability. He had a mild viral upper respiratory infection two weeks ago. A brain MRI reveals extensive white matter lesions and some grey matter lesions in the cortex. CSF examination reveals pleocytosis and increased protein concentration. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Meningoencephalitis due to herpes simplex virus

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of fever, headache, irritability, poor coordination, and ataxia following a viral infection, along with the given MRI and CSF findings, strongly suggests acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM). 

ADEM is an immune-mediated demyelinating disorder that typically follows a viral infection or vaccination. ADEM usually affects children. MRI findings that favor ADEM include extensive and relatively symmetric white matter abnormalities, and basal ganglia or cortical gray matter lesions. The CSF findings include lymphocytic pleocytosis and/or increased protein concentration in most patients.

Treatment is with high-dose glucocorticoids. Patients who fail to respond within a few days may benefit from a course of plasma exchange or intravenous immunoglobulin. The prognosis depends on the severity of the underlying acute illness.

Other options:

Option B: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a late complication of a measles virus infection, typically occurring years after an initial infection. Typical MRI abnormality is periventricular white matter T2/FLAIR hyperintensity, predominantly affecting parieto-occipital regions of the cerebral cortex. In the late stages of the disease, there is marked generalized cerebral atrophy.

Option C: Meningoencephalitis due to herpes simplex virus would present with focal temporal lobe abnormalities on MRI. Examination of the CSF typically shows a lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and an increased number of erythrocytes.

Option D: Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is a peripheral nervous system disorder characterized by ascending weakness and areflexia. It typically presents with progressive muscle weakness and paralysis.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following routes of administration in the descending order of systemic absorption of local anesthetic.
  1. Subcutaneous injection
  2. Injection into brachial plexus
  3. Intercostal nerve blockade 
  4. Injection into lumbar epidural space
questions.solution:
Routes of administration in the descending order of systemic absorption of local anesthetic:

  1. Intercostal nerve blockade 
  2. Injection into the caudal epidural space
  3. Injection into lumbar epidural space
  4. Injection into brachial plexus
  5. Subcutaneous injection

Systemic absorption of local anesthetic is determined by the

  • Site of injection and its tissue blood perfusion
  • Dosage and volume of drug administered
  • Vasoconstrictor agent addition
  • The pharmacologic properties of the agent itself

Exposure to an area of greater vascularity would result in a greater rate and degree of absorption of local anesthetic. The clinical significance of this is that the use of a fixed dose of a local anesthetic agent can be potentially toxic in one area of administration but not in others.

Ex:- Lidocaine without epinephrine for an intercostal nerve block results in average peak venous plasma levels that are sufficiently high to cause symptoms of CNS toxicity. But the same dose of lidocaine when used for a brachial plexus block results in blood levels that are rarely associated with toxicity.

Related Pearl: Systemic Absorbtion of Local Anaesthetic in the Order of Occurrence

Systemic absorption of a local anesthetic depends on vascularity.

The highest blood concentrations are seen following:

  1. Intravenous (intraarterial) injection (maximum)
  2. Intercostal nerve blockade
  3. Paracervical block
  4. Caudal epidural block
  5. Lumbar epidural block
  6. Brachial plexus block
  7. Sciatic block
  8. Subcutaneous injection (minimum)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with severe left-sided chest pain radiating to his left arm, left side of his jaw and abdomen. He says he was asleep when the pain started and he has had similar episodes in the past which got better after a while. ECG showed an ST elevation. Angiography was done and did not reveal any obstruction of the coronary arteries. What is the most likely finding on serial ECG and what is the most appropriate treatment?

choices.text: Continuous ST segment elevation - Coronary reperfusion therapy
ST segment deviation persists followed by T wave inversion - Aspirin
Resolution of ST segment deviation within 30 minutes - Aspirin
Resolution of ST segment elevation within 30 minutes - Isosorbide dinitrate

questions.solution:
A young patient with recurrent episodes of ischemic-type chest pain with transient ST elevation points to Prinzmetal Angina which is treated with Nitrates or Calcium Channel blockers which helps in maintaining the myocardial blood supply. So, this patient should be treated with Isosorbide dinitrate and he will most likely have a resolution of ST-segment elevation within 30 minutes.

Prinzmetal angina is a syndrome of ischemic type of chest pain with transient ST elevation caused by vasospasm of coronary arteries. It commonly occurs in the younger population. 

Vasospasms can lead to ischemia, acute myocardial infarction, and ventricular fibrillation in some individuals. Persistent ECG changes are noted in acute myocardial infarction. Aspirin is not used in patients with Prinzmetal Angina because it is known to increase the risk of ischemic events in patients with Prinzmetal angina due to a decrease in prostacyclins.

questions.text: A 24-year-old worried woman presents with milky white nipple discharge. On taking history, she said she has been using a drug for her heartburn and dyspepsia without consulting the doctor. Which of the following drugs might she have self-medicated?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of galactorrhoea, which has occurred due to the side effects of Metoclopramide.

Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent, a D2 blocker, 5HT3 antagonist, and 5HT4 agonist. It is used to treat gastroparesis, nausea and vomiting, paralytic ileus, GERD, and hiccups.

Metoclopramide's property to block D2 receptors in the hypothalamus and pituitary leads to increased prolactin secretion, which stimulates the mammary glands to produce milk, causing galactorrhea. Other side effects include extrapyramidal effects (e.g., dystonias, Parkinsonian symptoms, tardive dyskinesia) and, rarely, methemoglobinemia in neonates. 

Prokinetic agents are the drugs that increase GI motility and the transit of material in the GI tract. These agents include:

  • Dopamine receptor antagonists- metoclopramide and domperidone
  • Serotonin receptor agonists- cisapride and prucalopride
  • Motilin
  • Macrolide antibiotics mimicking motilin-erythromycin
    • Miscellaneous agents: Sincalide (C-terminal octapeptide of CCK)
    • Camicinal (motilin receptor agonist)
    • Relamorelin (ghrelin receptor agonist)
    • Velusetrag and naronapride (5HT4 agonists)

Other options:

Option A: Rabeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) used in peptic ulcer disease, with side effects like B12 deficiency, hip fracture, hypocalcemia, pseudomembranous enterocolitis, pneumonia, and hypergastrinemia.

Option C: Vonoprazan is a potassium-competitive acid blocker (P-CAB) that decreases gastric acid secretion, similar to PPIs. Common adverse effects of vonoprazan include nasopharyngitis, diarrhea, constipation, flatulence, dyspepsia, headache, and abdominal pain.

Option D: Famotidine is an H2 receptor antagonist used to treat heartburn and dyspepsia by reducing stomach acid production. It does not cause galactorrhea as it does not significantly affect prolactin levels.

questions.text: During the examination of a gunshot victim, the skin around the entry wound shows marks from the grease, soot, and debris from the barrel of the gun. What is this referred to as?
questions.solution:
The skin around the entry wound showing marks from the grease, soot, and debris from the barrel of the gun is referred to as grease collar/ dirt collar/ bullet wipe.

While examining the clothing of a victim of a bullet injury, there is a deposition of various residues surrounding the entrance defect at various ranges, known as Bullet wipe. It helps in determining the wounds of inlet and outlet upon the body.

Bullet graze/ Bullet slap: the bullet just hits the skin only at an angle and goes off from the site, without any penetration or wound of entry. It produces an abrasion or a laceration depending on the thickness of the skin involved.

Bullet bruise: the bullet here just hits the skin only and drops down to the ground, without any penetration or wound of entry. It produces a bruise alone at the site of impact.

Fouling: refers to tiny lesions surrounding the entry wound which are caused by fragments of metal that are expelled by the discharge wither from the surface of the missile itself or from the interior of the barrel. A black ring around the bullet hole is seen in infrared photography.

Related Pearl: Types of bullets:

1. Ricochet bullet: Bullet first strikes an intermediate object and then after being reflected strikes the target. It produces a key hole entry wound .

2. Yawning bullet: Travels in an irregular fashion.

3. Tandem (Piggy Back) Bullet Effect: Two bullets are ejected one after the other; first bullet failed to leave the barrel and is ejected by subsequently fired bullet. This occurs due to defect in the weapon or due to faulty ammunition or with loaded firearms unused for several years. Tandem cartridge (also called duplex cartridge) is a single cartridge containing two bullets. 

 

4. Frangible bullet: Fragments on hitting the target.

5. Dum Dum bullet: Tip is chiseled out, fragments extensively on impact.

6. Tumbling bullet:  Rotates end on end during its motion. This produces an atypical entry wound .  

7. Souvenir bullet:  Bullet left in the body for a long time and covered with dense fibrous connective tissue.

8. Tracer bullet: This type of bullet leaves a visible mark or trace while in flight so that the gunner can observe the strike of shot. Rear portion of bullet is filled with mixture of barium nitrate, strontium nitrate and powdered magnesium which is ignited by the burning powder. Mixture burns and sheds red sparks which makes the projectile visible to naked eye which enables shooter to make aiming corrections.

9. Incendiary bullet: It is filled with white phosphorous and ignites the target.

questions.text:
As a part of the pre-operative evaluation of a patient posted for cataract surgery, you are asked to calculate the power of the intraocular lens to be implanted. What investigations would you perform?
  1. Biometry
  2. Pachymetry
  3. Tonometry
  4. Keratometry
  5. Gonioscopy
questions.solution:
The investigations commonly performed for calculating the power of the intraocular lens (IOL) include biometry and keratometry. 

The power of an intraocular lens (IOL) is calculated using a biometer, a procedure called biometry. Keratometry involves determining the curvature of the anterior corneal surface (the steepest and flattest meridians), and it is expressed in dioptres or millimetres of radius of curvature.

Optical coherence biometry is a noncontact method of measuring axial length. Modern biometry devices also perform keratometry, anterior chamber depth, and corneal measurement and can calculate IOL power using a range of formulas. 

 The most common method of determining IOL power uses a regression formula called the SRK formula, which is given below:

 P = A - 2.5L - 0.9K

Where, 

  • P is the power of IOL
  • A is a constant, which is specific for each lens type
  • L is the axial length of the eyeball in millimeters, determined by using the A-scan ultrasonography
  • K is the average corneal curvature, which is determined by keratometry.

 The images given below show a biometer and a keratometer, respectively.  

A-scan ultrasonography is used for determining the axial length of the eyeball. It can be acquired by direct contact or by using a water bath over the eye (immersion ultrasonography). Unfortunately, it is a slightly less accurate method of determining the axial dimension.

The sound beam must be aligned with the visual axis for maximal precision. Each reflecting surface is represented by a spike on the oscilloscope monitor. A-scan ultrasonography is shown in the image below.

Other options: 

Pachymetry measures corneal thickness. It is shown in the image below.

Tonometry measures intraocular pressure. It is shown in the image below.

Gonioscopy is used to visualize the angle of the anterior chamber. It also aids in the localization of the foreign body, abnormal blood vessels, or tumors in the angle. The given instrument below is an indirect gonioscope.

Related Pearl: Important investigations related to the cornea

  • Pachymetry: To measure corneal thickness
  • Keratometry: To measure corneal curvature (of the anterior surface)
  • Corneal topography: To measure corneal curvature, shape, and thickness
  • Specular microscopy: To assess the corneal endothelium
  • Anterior segment ocular coherence tomography: To assess different corneal layers

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presented to the emergency room with sudden pain in the right upper quadrant of her abdomen. Initial ultrasound evaluation showed free fluid in the peritoneum. The ascitic fluid is aspirated for investigations. Which of the following laboratory findings will point to a diagnosis of early-onset Budd-Chiari syndrome?

SAAG - Serum-ascites albumin gradient
questions.solution:
A laboratory finding of Serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) >1.1g/dL and ascitic protein >2.5g/dL will point to a diagnosis of early-onset Budd-Chiari syndrome.

A SAAG is used to differentiate between the portal and nonportal hypertensive ascites. It represents the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids and correlates with the hepatic venous pressure gradient.

It is given by the formula: SAAG = Serum albumin - ascitic fluid albumin.

Interpretation of SAAG:

  • SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. It reflects the presence of portal hypertension.
  • SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to infection or malignancy.

In cases with high-SAAG (≥1.1), ascitic protein level analysis further helps in identifying the etiology:

  • ≥2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing the passage of protein into the ascites. eg. early Budd-Chiari syndrome.
  • <2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer allow passage of protein. Eg. late Budd-Chiari syndrome.

Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS) is a form of congestive hepatopathy caused due to blockage of the hepatic venous outflow anywhere along the venous course between the hepatic venules to the junction of the inferior vena cava (IVC) to the right atrium. Hypercoagulable states due to primary myeloproliferative diseases are the leading cause of the disease.

Investigations for BCS include: 

  • Elevated bilirubin, liver enzymes with decreased albumin is usually seen.
  • Doppler ultrasonography of the liver: highly sensitive, specific, initial investigation of choice. Hepatic veins without flow signal, with spider-web appearance, collateral hepatic venous circulation and stagnant, reversed or turbulent flow are indicative of BCS
  • Magnetic resonance imaging
  • Hepatic venography: a spider-web pattern confirms BCS
  • Liver biopsy 
  • Echocardiography
  • Diagnosis of the underlying cause of thrombosis is important.

Management strategy includes:

  • Anticoagulation
  • Treatment of identified prothrombotic risk factors
  • Percutaneous revascularization, transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic stent shunt (TIPSS): to re-establish hepatic venous drainage
  • Liver transplantation in unresponsive patients.
 
5-year prognosis is >90% while the long-term outcome is influenced by any underlying haematological condition and development of hepatocellular carcinoma.

High serum levels of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) can be used to identify heart failure as the cause of high-SAAG ascites.

Low ascitic glucose level <50 mg/dL and high ascitic LDH level are indicative of ascites due to secondary peritonitis.

Ascitic amylase level >1000 mg/dL is indicative of pancreatic ascites.

Tuberculous peritonitis is typically associated with ascitic fluid lymphocytosis and elevated adenosine deaminase levels.

Other options: 

Option D: SAAG >1.1g/dl and ascitic protein <2.5g/dl is seen in liver cirrhosis, late Budd-Chiari syndrome, and massive liver metastases.

Options A and B are not possible. 

Related Pearl: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

The serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated as follows:

SAAG = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

It can be used to determine the cause of ascites following ascitic fluid analysis.
